description:
I came for a friend's birthday and opted for their full 11 course omakase ($168 per person). They do offer a smaller omakase for $98 per person. 

Every piece of fish was crafted perfectly. Each was unique and seasoned to perfection. The non sushi items like the Matcha Ushio-jiru, fish broth Umami soup and and wagyu dish were also excellent. My favorite will always be the Toro and it was sooo good. They have a great wine / sake selection as well. They surprised my friend with a nice dessert with a candle, so if you are coming for a birthday, let them know! Service was always on point and they always made sure that our sake glasses were filled. 

They do have some tables beside the sushi bar so make sure you request to sit at the bar! Being able to watch Kusakabe was amazing!
author: Daniel S.

description:
What a memorable birthday dinner! As a lover of fish, I can definitively recommend Kusakabe. Though I wasn't a fan of the dress code, I went in with an open heart. 

I love the long sushi bar and being in the front seat as my food was lovingly made. It was like watching art created right before our eyes and we get immortalize it by taking a bite. I remember the taste, flavor of every bite. 

If you're looking for a special night out for sushi, this is a great spot!
author: Christina D.

description:
My dining experience at Kusakabe was everything I expected it to be.

I had the Omakase prepared by Chef Ken. As with the other Yelp reviewers, I enjoyed the bar seating as half of the experience was getting to interact with the chef and witnessing the craftsmanship first hand.

I'm not going to go into detail of every piece I had, but I liked that not every course was nigiri. The menu included hot items such as matcha soup and the wagyu stew.

Overall, the tasting menu took me on a real trip. The courses were uniquely smoky, herbal, and buttery. One of my favorites was the torched chutoro so I also got the Ji Kinmedai, à la carte, which was also torched and as equally delicious as the chutoro.

I would highly recommend Kusakabe to friends and family looking for a quality omakase restaurant for a special occasion.
author: Sylvia Y.

description:
Maybe being seated directly facing chef Kusakabe put me in a very good mood, this is the best omakase experience I've had in a while! 
Toro aged for two weeks to accentuate the umami, tiramisu made with tofu and soybean powder, and everything is sliced/torched/seasoned just right.  
Servers are generally good and hospitable , except for this one lady with difficult attitude, she seems polite but I can still feel that she's impatient when I tried to ask her questions about the sake, quite difficult to talk to her. Sommelier or alike are quite important for the dinning experience, one that is not warm, knowledgeable or enthusiastic quite discounts the experience.
author: Kailin H.

description:
Came here for the second last Friday and it was once again a superb experience!  Again, this place is very deserving on its Michelin star! I tried the 11 course omakase last time so I opted for the petite omakase this time (8 courses...$98). I like the petite one because it was actually very filling and affordable but  I also had room to try some a la carte after . I got the liver Pate and salmon and boyfriend got the eel (fresh and never been frozen, flown straight from Japan that morning) after our omakase 

Everything was amazing!! We requested in advance to be seated by the bar and got lucky that we were seated by chef kusakabe's section and got to watch him in action throughout dinner. He was so sweet...we even got a picture with him!! Can't wait to come back again for another special occasion.

Everyone in your party has to order the same omakase. And a la carte is only available after your omakase...so you can't just walk in and order sushi rolls only.
author: Caitlin P.

description: Tried the $168 omakase. It's a ton of food and very filling. Also had a glass white wine. There selection of drinks was very complimentary to the menu. The experience is memorable the staff very attentive and friendly. Feeling of being transported back to japan. Overall good experience. Excellent place for special occasions.
author: Linda H.

description:
Its not like it used to be.   We always come here whenever we visit SF.  We spent more than $1000 here for my birthday and we were satisfied.  
Sadly, not tonighy.  It's still pretty good but some of the dishes are not as fresh as before.  Of course I am being super picky here because this is a Michelin star sushi restaurant and it's usually $200 -300 or more a person after alcohol before tips and CA fees.  

The wine pairing is quite disappointing at the end unfortunately.  Somehow I don't really feel sweet wine goes well with sushi but the first couple choices were awesome. And she would pour our next table full glasses Everytime but 1/4 or 1/3 when it comes to our table. 

The service is also another reason I am not giving 5 stars.   I think the attitude should always be nice and sweet unless the customers are rude and unreasonably.   I don't think requesting a japanese sake menu is unreasonable.   I only recognize the sakes in Japanese.  Anyways, I just remember the service was better, the food was better and the Atmosphere was more exclusive. 

Still amazing food but I am finally ready to try other places in SF.
author: Ada H.

description: Somehow I was under the impression that it's a sushi only restaurant but I was wrong! Their omakase menu was mainly sushi but there are a few dishes that are other cooked small plates of Japanese food. The cooked food was just okay in my opinion but the sushi was excellent! I got the full size omakase but I guess I will just get the petite one next time, it's $70 less and I can always get the a la carte sushi if I want more.
author: Jas L.

description:
I'm not even a big fan of sushi. Kusakabe left me savoring each bite and wishing I had enough room in my stomach to eat more. It was by far one of the best omakase experiences I've had in my life. 

We came here on a Friday night on a last minute reservation. They only do two seatings a day. The restaurant is on an unassuming street across from the Transamerica Building. It's worthwhile to call ahead to get a seat at the bar so you can watch the masters in action crafting your dishes right in front of your eyes. They have a larger table near the front of the restaurant for parties of 4+, a two-topper behind the bar area and a main bar area. 

The service was thorough and attentive. They bring you a hot towel and a glass of water the moment you're seated just like in Japan. We ordered the petite omakase ($98) and the yuzu sake (forgot how much this was). You can upgrade to the regular omakase for an extra hundred dollars. You also have the option to order a la carte after the omakase if you're not quite full or dying for seconds of a particularly good piece. We thought the petite was the right amount of food. 

Even though the meal lasted 2 hours, it felt like a blur. The quality of the fish was very high and super fresh. Every dish was impeccably seasoned. I struggle to remember the name of each piece of sushi but everything tasted incredible. We didn't realize that our chef was Kusakabe himself until the end of the meal. Dude is such a low key G. I highly recommend this place for a fantastic omakase meal in SF!
author: Laura Y.

description:
So, let's get this out of the way first -- best sushi I've ever had in my life. Great date night vibe. Prices are high, but this fine dining. So deal with it.

Learning from previous prefix experiences, we elected for the 'petit' menu and did not do the drink pairing. Both were the right choice because we just got a bottle of saki that we wanted - and were able to order ala carte rolls after the prefix.

I'm not sure if I'll return, if I could come back and just order individual pieces - I would do that without hesitation.
author: Ross H.

description:
We truly couldn't get over that TORO...

Superb quality and presentation!! 

Amazingly eloquent Omakase.. OMG - their toro just melted like butter, euphoric!!! ($14/piece).

We nearly missed our reservations due to our horribly incompetent Lyft driver whom left us stranded at the wrong address, Yuck-butt MORON....

So I was a little irritated after a 2nd Lyft driver had to shuttle us to the correct address. 

The service was wonderful and staff at Kusakabe was empathetic when we arrived late for our reservations..

I needed a sake shot upon arrival, just to vent out my frustration, WTS???

Their omakase was sophisticated, unique, ultra fresh, and worth the spendy experience. My fav was the toro, snapper, halibut, salmon, jumbo scallop. 

I only wished they had the giant clam, but no such luck.. We were both disappointed with their abalone sushi as it was overly crunchy and flavorless. Oddly, this was my only disappointing abalone sushi experience ever? I guess our expectations were too high, as they should be?? But we can overlook it, relative to our entire omakase experience..

And I luv their refreshing tarty tangy shiso yuzu & shiso leaf sorbet, such a palette cleanser..
author: Nine S.

description:
Everything was so delicious here. We sat at the bar with Patrick as our chef and he was great.  Super accommodating and thoughtful.  The service is pretty good here - really polite.  They emphasize arriving on time and confirmed the reservations along with a reminder voicemail that it's pride weekend so it may take longer to get there, which was nice.  

We had the petite 8-course menu and it took about 1.5 hours so don't be late!  Plan on getting there 15 min before and you'll be 5 min early probably.  Our fav was the amberjack, hirame, Japanese sweetfish with cucumber and the plate of assorted tapas. The tuna hand roll at the end was the best hand roll I've ever had - it had multiple layers and texture and the nori was so good.  Good experience sitting at the bar - be sure to request it when you make your reservation.
author: Chris L.

description:
I've been procrastinating to write this review because there is so much I want to say but at the same time I have no words. We went here for my birthday dinner / anniversary dinner during our trip to SF. I had heard good things about about this place and was looking for somewhere to eat omakase at.

We sat at the bar like I had requested and were greeted by the chef once we sat down. He went over what we did like, what we didn't like and asked if we had any dietary restrictions. I had filled out the food allergy part on the online reservation thing so either he was just asking to confirm or that information does not actually make it to the chef who is serving you.

I cannot remember his name but he seemed like he was the head chef there. Throughout our meal we talked about sushi we had, had before and various random things that came up into conversation.

He gave us a detailed description of each piece that was put in front of us and had instructed us to use our hands and not our chopsticks. I had remembered people doing this at the omakase we had been to before back home but our chef there did not mention anything about using our hands. Since my chopstick skills are not on point, this was definitely easier for me but also added to the experience.

Each piece of fish was fresh and you could just tell it was great quality. The meal left us both satisfied but also left a well worth hole in the wallet. You may see the prices for the omakase on the menu online but if you order drinks, the price of your total check jumps like expected. I would come here for special occasions or when you are ready to spend a lot on a meal. This was definitely a one of a kind experience and it didn't leave me feeling like I had to come back but more like I wanted to experience omakase at all the other sushi places around SF as well.
author: Emily J.

description: Probably one of the best sushi I have had. We were very impressed with this sushi place we went for the larger option and it felt like there was one chef per table. I would put this on the must eat list for san fran!
author: C A.

description:
Pretty affordable Omakase dinner compared to some of the equivalent restaurants in NYC. The BEST piece here was the kinki which was a torched fatty sea perch -- absolutely amazing!

Also their soup that comes as part of the Omakase petite special was off the heezy. Would go back in a heartbeat!
author: Jane N.

description: Still amazing and each dish a wonderful surprise. We did the mini OMAKASE and at 8 courses it's far from a mini repast. I opted to try the accompanying Wine Flights at $100. While very nicely paired and curated it amounts to about 2 full glasses over the course of the meal. That's $50 a glass for wine. Some of the wine pours were so incredibly small that after one sip for a tasting, there was nothing left in the glass for the course. Highly DO NOT recommend the wine flights, just get your wine by the glass.
author: Rob B.

description:
With so many omakase locations in San Francisco I was pleased to learn from a local friend that I made a correct choice in choosing this location!

We were able to book a month ahead of time with no problems online and were promptly seated when we arrived.  

Right from the get-go I can see this location has been tweaked into a well-oiled machine since despite the fact that there were easily 6+ sushi chef's working for the people at the bar AND for the people in the small dining tables, there was no sign of any chaos.  Everyone was busy but they communicated well and weren't bumping around or reaching over another person which was quite impressive to me.

We went for the 11 course omakase menu which was $168 per person (not including tip or alcohol) which may come off as steep to many people but one must remember that you're there for an experience!  All of the chefs and wait staff were knowledgeable and were keen to explain every little ingredient in every dish which was very much appreciated (though so expansive it started to go over my head after a while).  They must have sensed this as they brought me the ala cart menu to let me know exactly what we were having which was a nice touch.  

Our chef was young but very precise and I could see the focus he had on every dish.  Speaking of dishes, they were excellent and quite unique in flavor.  This establishment favors meshing of multiple ingredients to create a very delicate but complex flavor profile which is different from other sushi omakases I've been to.  

All in all my favorite was no doubt the A5 Wagyu beef, Uni, eel, and tuna.  I was quite happy (and full) by the end and they were kind enough to place a new copy of the ala-cart menu as well as the omakase menu into an envelope to bring home with you!

If you're new to the omakase experience you can always try their "petite" omakase which is 8 courses but at a more reasonable $98 per person!
author: Bob L.

description:
I thought I wrote a review for this place but I guess I forgot or it didn't save correctly...anyways, I came here with my boyfriend for his birthday back in July and we had a wonderful experience. The atmosphere in the restaurant had a nice and dark ambiance. We made reservations through the website and although the reservation time we had was only available at 8pm but we wanted to try it and I'm glad we did. They have 1st seating: 5pm - 5:30pm and 2nd seating: 8pm - 8:45pm. We got seated promptly at 8pm by the sushi counter and the chef/host greeted us. 

We did the omakase which was $168 (Yes, it is steep pricing but it's worth it!!) and we ordered yuzu drink which was delicious and crisp!) It was nice to sit in front of the sushi counter and watch the chef make the sushi in front. We were hella hungry the whole time and I literally felt like drooling the whole time watching him make everything lol! I forgot what our chef's name was but he carefully explained everything that was made to us. Each fish tasted fresh and the presentation was superb! 

Honestly, everything was delicious from the start to beginning. No complaints whatsoever. I wish we got to see the Mr. Kusakabe (owner/chef) but maybe next time lol. This is my favorite sushi place in SF and I would definitely love to come back here again!!!
author: Monica W.

description: Overall good experience 3.75 stars. I made reservations online two weeks beforehand for the second seating requesting to be seated at the sushi bar. We arrived promptly around 8:15p and were seated immediately at the sushi bar. The whole experience took 2.5 hours and it's a lot of food.
author: Nica N.

description:
I've been wanting to try omakase for a very long time, and spent some time researching what the top omakase restaurants were in San Francisco.  There were a ton of "top 10" lists and I narrowed the restaurants down to the "top 3" because if I was going to pay a lot, I wanted the best experience possible.

After looking at all the different omakase restuarants' menus, I eventually decided on Kusakabe.  I looked on their website, and the restaurant seemed pretty popular because most of the reservation spots were taken.

As I entered Kusakabe, I noticed right away that most, if not all, the staff spoke both really good English and Japanese.

I was escorted to my seat, and ordered the Omakase.

The Omakase includes dishes you will not see at a standard Japanese restaurant, and you'll be served one dish (i.e. sushi) at a time.  When you complete each dish, the chef will work on the next dish for you, and you can watch him make it right in front of you.  Some dishes included scallop and uni straight from Hokkaido, wagyu beef from Miyazaki, and other kinds of seafood that I've never heard of.  The food is top notch; the ingredients were fresh and the chef makes your food like it's truly a piece of art.

The service is also top notch.  After each dish was presented, the components of the dish were explained.  Additionally, my water was continuously refilled, and staff asked how my meal was so far throughout the service.

This was an experience of a lifetime; I enjoyed every bite!

I highly recommend!
author: Garrett F.

description: Honored to be served by Mr. Kusakabe himself. What an experience. Sushi will never be the same again. Each dish was carefully crafted and had a unique flavor and presentation. Very fresh fish. It's Omakase style and dinner took about 2.5 hours. We ordered the regular Omakase (vs Petite), I was extremely full after, dessert not included
author: Tiff W.

description:
Been here twice. Keep forgetting how good this place is. Not for the faint of heart, it's pricey. $98 for the petite 8-course and $168 for the 11-course. Once, I started down the 8-course and promptly switched to the 11-course. 

Notable sushi: usually hate squid and it was melt in your mouth. Their uni was so tender it was almost like liquid. The bonito was great and might be my new favorite. 

Great staff and mostly Japanese. Fine sake selection and I had a nice, crisp seasonal sake for $44 8oz. Splurging with no regrets.
author: Young Y.

description: I regret to dine at Kusakabe as it has spoiled my taste bud so much that I can never go back to regular sushi LOL. We sit at the sushi bar, facing directly to chef Kusakabe, and see how the magic happens from his hand to our plate. We ordered the petit omakase, which is filling enough and at the same time leaving my stomach with enough room for some a la carte dishes after. My favorites include the otoro, uni, wagyu nigiri and the tofu tiramisu dessert. The otoro and wagyu nigari just melt in your mouth, and then left a lingering, exquisite umami aftertaste. The uni handroll has everything: the creaminess of the uni, the crunchiness of the seaweed, and the softness of the rice. It created the WOW moment the second I put it in my mouth. Also the tiramisu tofu dish was so delicious, and it has this unique soy taste, reminiscent of some desserts in my hometown.  Overall the best omakase experience ever, and will definitely come back!
author: Yeya Z.

description:
I've heard of this place for a while and had it bookmarked. When dining at a sushi restaurant in Seattle, I asked the chef where I should go in San Francisco. He too spoke of Kusakabe. Made reservations for 4 to come eat here. Didn't see if there was any way to specify to eat at bar or at table so we sat at the table. A little disappointed for me but I guess we were able to socialize easier. Corkage fee is $25 so we brought our own sake bottle. The servers were super nice, attentive, and charming. We did the regular omakase. Every item came in a timely manner, not too soon or too late after we had finished the previous. It was a good pace. All the items we received were really light but so flavorful. Significant pieces were the baby snapper, wagyu tongue stew, eel from Tsukiji market, and of course the toro. We were celebrating my best friend's birthday and my boyfriend's birthday. The dessert was on the house for both of them. I didn't like the tiramisu that much but the creme brulee was excellent. It was a hefty bill at about $760 for 4 people, but you can splurge once in a while no? I was the only person in my part that didn't feel full so I was low key disappointed in that. Nonetheless, a wonderful experience. 

Service - 5 / Ambiance - 4 / Food - 5 / Price - 3
author: Veronica N.

description:
I took my husband here for his birthday and was really blown away by their omakase menu. We chose the full menu which was $168 person and it was completely worth it. 

We sat at the sushi bar with a dedicated sushi chef. Bar seating is recommended as it's a more intimate experience, they have a few sit down tables but not for large parties. Our sushi chef was a bit quiet however super skilled and professional. I've never had sushi quite like this, flavors are perfectly balanced and served just at the right temperature. 

Each course complimented each other and we were constantly impressed by the next. We even ordered additional uni and some of our favorite sashimi. I highly recommend this experience, only wished Kusakabe himself was present that night!

5 STARS
author: Karen L.

description:
Good, and definitely $$$$. We were promptly seated at 8:15pm tonight, and were lucky enough to get seated at the bar.

A5 Wagyu is a must. The scallops with uni were super delicious, but we had expected that ;) The 6 small plates from Chef's selection were unique.

The eel was delicious too. Hot and crispy on the top.

Everything was good though quite pricey for what it was... Torn between 4 and 4.5. (Sorry I rounded down!)
author: Cal C.

description:
I was in SF for work and wanted to have a nice sushi dinner when I was done with my conference. I started looking around for some sushi spots in the city. Kusakabe was actually my third choice! The first two I called had no reservations left. Let me just say, I was very happy how that all played out.

I didn't realize how amazing this dinner was about to be! We even had 2 seats at the bar, and had Kusakabe serving us himself! Talk about luck! He was so nice and accommodating, indulging me in all my questions and awe over every piece of fish he was handling.

Everything we had was delectable. One of the best omakase I've ever had. Every course was executed perfectly and was well balanced. Everyone was extremely knowledgeable, so any questions you have about the food or drinks, rest assured, you will get an answer. Kusakabe only has Omakase on the menu, but you are allowed to order a la care items after you have finished with your omakase. Let's just say we definitely over indulged in more of the toro and A5 wagyu. It was sooo frikkin good. They both just melted in your mouth like buttaaaaa. It was just ridiculous how delicious this meal was, definitely one I won't forget!

If you're in town and are looking to have a wonderful dinner and experience, I'd definitely recommend coming to Kusakabe.
author: Amanda E.

description:
This was the best sushi I have ever had, there was just a few misses. 
We opted for the full omakase experience. 
Almost Every course was well thought out and well executed. My favorites of the night were the toro, and the Hokkaido uni. The fried tofu soup, the fish jelly, and the shrimp roll - didn't care for them much. 
Service was good. 
We left very full and very happy.
author: Basil M.

description: Had the 11-course dinner, the omakase was not sushi only, it also included soup and other small plates which were cooked. Quality of sashimi was good in general, but as far as the cooked food go it was just okay. If I go ever back, I will probably get the 8-course omakase which didn't include the wagyu stew and a couple other dishes, and add a la carte sushi to encore. The price difference of 8 and 11-course 168-98=70, for 70 dollars you can get another 6 to 7 pieces of sushi of your choice which is a better option in my opinion.
author: Teresa N.

description: Super belated review for Kusakabe. I came here within a year of its opening, so it was a looooong time ago, obviously. Kusakabe definitely serves the highest of high end sushi. It's expensive, to be sure. But man oh man, you will enjoy every piece. The most memorable for me was actually the "deep sea" uni, which is very different from regular uni (if you can call uni regular at all). Deep sea uni tastes like an... UNI CLOUD! It's delicious! It's like a cotton candy fluff with 10x the uni flavor. SO YUM. The only reason I cannot give Kusakabe 5 stars is because of the price. For $100, you will leave hungry.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Great Place!
Highly recommend.
They do a Great Job giving you that French  food experience.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Chef Nori delivered us an INCREDIBLE meal! We made reservations a month in advance for a Saturday night 5:30pm reservation and got seated at the tables. We went for the $168 omakase set and we left impressed and semi full.

They source their fish from various parts of Japan and do a fantastic job at preserving the freshness. I've been to Tokyo and have eaten quality sushi straight from Tsukiji Market; Kusakabe paralleled in quality, taste, and presentation. You can tell Chef Nori and the other chefs care about what they do.

My favorite, was of course, the Toro (tuna belly). So rich and decadent! It was absolute amazing.

If you want to splurge on a true omakase experience, look no further!
author: Corinne L.

description:
I love sushi. I've done an omakase style meal before at a restaurant in Atlanta, but was really excited to see what San Francisco had to offer, which was a lot!  I ended up eating here at Kusakabe for Cinco de Mayo and selected their 11 course omakase. Long story short...it was amazing!

From the moment I walked in, I was treated very well by all levels of staff. The hostess was incredibly helpful and polite. Servers were super attentive; my glass was never less than half full. My sushi chef Patrick was very friendly and informative about each item that was presented to me.

The restaurant had a very warm, intimate atmosphere. Very inviting and good for a date night. There were all around little touches I really appreciated like the little hooks near your knee to hang any small bags, how when I came back from the bathroom my napkin was made up again, or the meticulous way they place and plate all your dishes/utensils (even positioning my pen I brought to take notes...what can I say, I'm a nerd!). They treat you right here!

As for the food...amazing. My favorites were the toro, golden eye snapper, sea bream milt w/ quail egg, wagyu beef, and scallop w/ uni. Really the only item I thought was just okay was the fried carrot and tofu cake in broth.  But that's just being nitpicky. They prepare these items very well. I still can't get over how tender and soft the scallop was; I never thought a scallop could almost melt in my mouth!  

After the meal they give you an a la carte menu where you can order more stuff if you choose (I ordered a second helping of the sea bream milt :)).  I really wanted to try more of the stuff on their menu, and am curious to see what all they offer during other seasons. This is an easy 5 stars for me. Kusakabe served some of the best sushi I've ever had in my life!
author: Alfie B.

description:
Very good omakase.

I went there without knowing they are Michelin rated, but surprised by their quality. They deserve it!
author: Ramos Z.

description:
Can I give more than 5 stars??? I was surprised with this place and I was amazed at how good it was! This place has been on my bookmarks for a loooong time and I was so happy I was finally able to try it.

We had to wait a little so our 8:15pm seating could all be seated at the same time but no worries. We had some complimentary yuzu sake while we waited. So refreshing! It was so good we ordered some at the end of our dinner!
Big shout out to sushi Chef Ken! He was very accommodating and friendly, chatting it up with us while he was preparing our fish. 

Ordered the Grand Omakase menu and it was so filling! I was dying by the end of the meal.... So it is definitely worth the price! Can't believe how accommodating they were. I was asked what kind of fish I like most, any thing I don't like, etc. I told him I didn't like green onions, cilantro, etc. When I received my soup and it had green onions in it, they were super apologetic and immediately made me another one. I was fine with it but they insisted!! Chef Ken also asked us our favorite sushi places and told us his. Definitely kept those in mind. At the end, I was asked if I wanted to keep a copy of the menu. I just said yes and they gave me this huge envelope to put the menu in with their name on it. So special haha!

I was extremely full and extremely happy after my meal! By the time we walked out the door, it was almost 12am... Can't believe we spent almost 4 hours here.... Nonetheless, it was very worth the experience and I will definitely be back to be served by Chef Ken!!
author: Kristie L.

description:
Ever since my wife has been pregnant, I've been seeking a delicious melt-in-your-mouth omokase meal that leaves you wanting more (and never fills you up). I've been to a couple other Omokase restaurants in the city and KUSAKABE has been a standard that everyone raves about so I was happy to snag a last second reservation on a Saturday.

Did it live up to the hype? Yes. Everything was so good that it's hard to choose a favorite--you're just going to want anything again. This is the best value omokase in SF (starting at $98) so don't miss out on it if you're a big fan of high-quality sushi. One thing I did miss out on is the A5 Wagyu Beef so be sure to get that (may not be on the $98 menu so get the more expensive menu ($165)or add it a la carte). Service is excellent and the ambience is best described as Japanese ceremonial (just not sitting on a tatami on the floor).

Pro tip: If you want a seat at the bar, make your reservation as early as possible and specifically request bar seating. Yes it's worth it because you can interact with the chefs and, more importantly, snap good photos of the sushi! The lighting at the bar is ideal for pictures (versus sitting at a table where it's a bit more dim (I sat at a table--see my posted pictures). Only do table if you're on a date and want to focus 100% on the other person. But, even if you were on a date you should probably do the bar!

Second pro-tip: Close your eyes as you bite into heavenly bliss for enhanced umami taste sensation!
author: Marlon T.

description: Made an appointment a few weeks ahead and we decided to come to kusukabe for my bf bday! We were seated on table and not the bar. We got the grand omakase which was 168 per person. This wasn't my first time having omakase so I knew what to expect. Staffs were so nice and customer service was definitely top notch! The dinner took about an hour and a half. The food was good but not great, the portions seems a bit smaller compared to Omakase (the restaurant). Overall it was a very enjoyable experience. Bill total was 364 for 2 people not including tips. We didn't get any alcohol or dessert :)
author: Tina C.

description:
This place is AMAZING! It is by far my favorite Japanese Omakase restaurant in the city. I came here before when they first got their Michelin Star and the service was just as phenomenal as the food. 

I think the price is definitely worth the delicious food and awesome experience!
author: Helen z.

description:
Nectar of the gods. This place was everything I dreamed it would be and quality was definitely on par with what I experienced in Japan.

Kusakabe is Kaiseki style - a Japanese  style of serving food as a multi-course meal. The service was exceptional and all the dishes were amazing. I can see why it's so popular. Be ready to throw down a pretty penny though. For two people with the Grand Omakase option and a couple drinks  I think the total bill came out to about $500 including tip and tax.

Toro, uni and the cod smelt were definitely the highlight dishes of the night. I never had cod smelt before and didn't even bother to ask, but was admittedly taken a back post swallow when I found out I had just eaten fresh cod sperm. Probably less surprised and more embarrassed since I had just seconds earlier expressed my excitement loudly to the chef about how "smooth and creamy" it was. Heeyyyyy. ‍
author: Joanna Q.

description:
I've gotten into the habit of marking every 100th Yelp review of mine with a Michelin-starred establishment, and I'm pleased to bestow whatever honor that's implied by my 2500th review upon Kusakabe. Although it lost its Michelin star for 2017, my experience here was first-rate, and I'm hoping it regains its star when the 2018 ratings for the Bay Area are announced this coming week.

Occupying a prime location directly underneath the Transamerica pyramid, Kusakabe is a sleek, modern venue dominated by a large sushi bar that seats about a dozen people. There are also small tables up front that seat another 10-12 people. Because of the limited amount of seating, reservations are virtually mandatory, although I lucked out by walking in as the first in line 20 minutes ahead of opening time.

Even though pricey omakase menus are a dime a dozen in the West Bay these days, I found the top-tier course to be an impressive value given the quality and quantity of the pieces of fish that came my way. In total, there were about 28 pieces to the omakase experience, including items like the amuse bouche, soup, and dessert.

To start, a modestly fatty series of nigiri that included zuke chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce), hirame (halibut), and katsuo (bonito) helped prime the appetite. Next, the relatively chewy sumi ika (Japanese cuttlefish squid) with uni (sea urchin) and sayori (Japanese half beak cured with ryuhi konbu) provided textural contrast. This was followed by a plate of hon maguro (center loin bluefin tuna), kasugodai (bamboo leaf cured young red snapper), and tairagai (ear shell clam) that offered a variety of contrasting seafood flavors. Next came a multi-course presentation of baby sea eel, wagyu rice cracker croquette, crab cake, Washington oyster with caviar, octopus with octopus roe, tuna cake, and egg cake, all of which offered unique tastes and textures.

This was followed by a palate-cleansing bowl of soup, which opened the way for a course of shima aji (stripe jack), a super-delicious piece of copper river king salmon, and ebodai (Japanese butter fish), followed further by bafun uni (Hokkaido short spine sea urchin) and a deliciously seared piece of shirayaki (fresh BBQ white eel with sansho pepper). Next came the ultimate in savory fattiness: a piece of toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and an exquisitely heavenly piece of wagyu beef. Then, a course of umimasu (lightly poached Tasmanian ocean trout), ji kinmedai (golden eye snapper) and gyoku (fresh lobster omelet with organic egg), followed by dessert, rounded out what was a truly indulgent omakase experience.

Bite after bite, everything was simply amazing. Service was also helpful and professional, and all in all it was fantastic value given the price, quantity, and quality of what I got. Highly recommended!
author: Vincent L.

description: I'm sorry to give this place a 2 but I've had way better sushi elsewhere. They use brown rice which takes away from the flavor of the fish. I get it, it's CA and they want to be health conscious but if I'm whipping out +400 with tip for me and my husband, I want good quality fish. I don't recommend the Omakase because they put in weird things like mushroom soup into the course.
author: Liz L.

description:
The Grand Omakase dinner was the best sushi meal I've ever had, even better than the Michelin starred sushi I had in Tokyo (seriously)! We had the pleasure of sitting at the bar, served by Chef Kusakabe himself. It was a pleasure watching him skillfully and meticulously prepare his kaiseki-style sushi. The chef was a very gracious host, patiently explaining in detail each beautiful piece of nigiri. 

Highlights of the meal included cod milt with uni. Milt is nearly impossible to find here in the US (I couldn't even find it in Japan). The chef gently explained that milt is "a type of egg." Since I knew what it was, I asked him if it was a "male egg" which he nodded. I've not had milt before, but I must say that it perfectly complemented the uni and it was incredible. Other favorites were the amazing toro, Hokkaido uni, and A5 Wagu beef. 

The service was friendly and efficient - our sommelier helped us choose some pleasant and crisp sake to accompany our meal, along with a nice pinot noir as the dishes got progressively heavier. 

Overall - the meal was very expensive, but also of incredibly high quality and was well worth it. HIghly recommended!
author: Allen T.

description: Definitely worth trying at least once since it is $$$. We made reservations in advanced. We came here for my birthday in April and went for the bigger omakase choice for $168 per person. Every piece was sooo good. I can't even find the words to describe how delicious and fresh each piece of fish was. We tried a sake and finished off with tea and free yuzu ice cream, which were all great! Our sushi chef was super nice and easy to talk to as well. Because of the price, I would have to think twice about coming again. But you definitely get what you pay for! They also have an a la carte menu but we were so full from the omakase already.
author: Kim N.

description:
An Expensive Disappointment

- Underwhelming Food -

I've had two transcendent raw fish experiences. The first was sashimi in a plastic box from Draeger's. The second was poke in a plastic box from Costco. The third was supposed to be Kusakabe's hyped-up fare served on their many mini marvelous plates. It didn't happen. I'm going back to the plastic boxes.

The sashimi from Draeger's was light and nuanced. The poke from Costco was hearty and so fresh that I could almost see it wriggling. Kusakabe could learn from both. Flashes of brilliance were overshadowed by an excess of salt and smoke. Fresh it (mostly) was not. At ten times the price of the plastic boxes, I expect better.

SF's gastronomist googlers can rip me for not knowing of what I speak. They may be right. I am just a blue collar stiff who, on rare occasion, experiences their everyday privilege. Even so, I also just know what tastes good. For the price, this didn't taste nearly good enough.

- Bar Seating... Good Luck with That -

We requested bar seating in the online reservation form. I then called the next day and requested bar seating with a live person. Many weeks later, we were the first at the door. It didn't matter. We got the distant corner.

We were then told that it's first reserved for a particular day, first served at the bar. I'm sorry if I missed it, but I didn't see that on their site. It would have been nice if they had told me that when I called in. We waited weeks for our reservation. We would have waited a few more to get bar seating.

If what we were told is true, your best bet is to make a reservation as far out as their system will allow. Having said that, I've now read some reviews that suggest their bar seating policy is inconsistent.

-  Excellent Service -

The service was outstanding. We loved every one of the staff. Well... except for the young lady who was just a tiny bit snippy. That nitpick aside, they were all extremely nice and very efficient.

Even so, the service didn't justify the price. Yes. I'm talking about money again. No. This isn't the first time we've paid hundreds for dinner. But this is the first time we were so disappointed.
author: Johnathan Y.

description:
I came here for a 10-course Valentine's Day dinner. I've been to Wako and Juni, and Kusakabe is my favorite.

I loved their serene, intimate setting, and well-balanced authentic Kaiseki cuisine. Their uni was on another level. I will definitely come back.
author: J R.

description: KUSAKABE serves kaiseki style omakase. I guess it makes sense that why all the nigiri taste so favorable (I even had a cucumber favor pic  lol). I was surprised by nigiri, but the kaiseki dishes were under-expected. And I prefer roasted wagy... if you wanna try different style of Nigiri, def recommend
author: Wong T.

description:
First time doing an omakase and I must say it was beyond my expectation! 

Each guest must order the omakase, whether it's the 8 or 11 course. My friend and I decided to go all out and did the 11 course. On top of that we each ordered sake. We're not to familiar with sake, so we asked our waitress. All she asked was what type of alcohol do we usually drink and she knew exactly what we'd like! I don't quite remember the name of the sake we had, but the one that I chose had a fruity after taste. It matched my taste bud and went well with the meal!

We had the pleasure of meeting Chef Kusakabe and we were lucky enough to have a seat in the center of the bar, so we got to see each chef prepare each dish.  It takes teamwork to shape the perfect experience for the customers and the staff here were definitely well trained. They're also really friendly; my friend and I had a nice chat with the chefs and got to learn about how they ended up at Kuskabe. Each plate was phenomenal and perfectly executed in a timely manner. The fish was very fresh, especially the uni. I've had bad experiences with uni so I was very hesitant to try, but the uni here changed my viewpoint. Although it says 11 courses, within each course were more plates. In the end, we had at least 17 plates of food. We were beyond full and could barely finish our dessert. However if you're still hungry, they do offer a la carte items! Since we came here to celebrate my birthday, they gave a free dessert so I chose the tofu tiramisu! This was fantastic because it was light and not too sweet. It was the perfect way to top off a wonderful meal.

OVERALL: Was very satisfied with my experience here and would highly recommend their omakase here to anyone! Just expect to spend at least $130!
author: Jennie Q.

description:
I don't remember whether I already review this one 
Food quality 8.8 or 9 of 10 
Service 9.5 

Sounding 9 of 10 
I don't know why they won Michelin star at 2016 
But not at 2018
author: Mr.Gong X.

description:
It was amazing experience at Kusakabe. Everyone was really nice, kind and polite. They call you before your reservation to check if you have any allergy while conferming your reservation. 

I loved their interior which had nice balance of wood tables including sushi bar with brick wall on the other side. Seperate tables were little dark compare to sushi bar. 

We had Grand Omakase $165 per person. It was totally worth it. worth every penny. I was just amazed how each dish tasted and enjoyed every single of them. I especially loved Wagyu beef for the course. MUST TRY. not sure if they make it everyday. 

I just loved this place. want to recomend people who wants to try something upscale version of omakase.
author: Jenny O.

description:
I'm a huge sushi fan and always wanted to try omakase. After researching a couple of restaurants in SF, I decided to come here for the "Grand Omakase" ($165, 10 courses). All of the courses were delicious and thoughtfully made, and watching the sushi chef create each piece made the dining experience even more wonderful.

Each course was amazing, with the perfect fish to rice ratio and just the right amount of sauce and garnish to bring out the true flavours of the fish. Moreover, I liked the different textures of all the dishes and how the dishes were ordered to make the eating experience really enjoyable. In particular, my favourites would be the bonito sushi and the wagyu sushi. I'd never had bonito sushi before, but its smokey and rich flavour stuck in my mind long after the meal. Moreover, the wagyu beef was so silky, decadent, and packed with umami that it was one of my favourites even though it wasn't fish. 

I was lucky enough to get a seat at the bar, and I'd say that half of the experience was watching the sushi chef work his magic! It was so enthralling to observe him assemble each perfect piece of sushi, and I also really enjoyed listening to the description of each course as it was being served. The servers are very professional, and the atmosphere here is upscale but not overly formal. Furthermore, the green tea that they serve tastes really good (I think it might be matcha).

If you're willing to splurge on high quality sushi and an amazing dining experience, Kusakabe is the place to be. Eating here isn't just about enjoying delicious food, but also observing and appreciating the skills of the experienced sushi chefs!
author: Karen L.

description:
Was able to snag reservations for a Wednesday night the morning of. I was pretty surprised since I heard it takes months to get reservations here. The reservations were for 8:15 but that was fine with me. 

My boyfriend and I were lucky enough to snag a parking spot right away and we arrived 15 minutes early. We were promptly seated. I love how kusakabe isn't too compact and cramped. 

The sushi chef asked us if we had any allergies and also asked for our preferences. I told him we liked fish on the buttery side. It's nice to know that the chefs can alter dishes.

We opted for the $98 Omakase. It was very filling but I felt like the selection in fishes lacked. Maybe we came during a season where the fish did not fit our taste buds. I was not fond of the halibut, mackerel nor the fresh water fish we had. Highlights of the meal was definitely the scallop with Santa Barbara Uni, the deep sea Uni and the O-Toro. I feel like that is standard on what's good in all Omakase spots. I was sad to learn that they ran out of akumutsu that night (my favorite white fish).

Service was friendly and we had some small talk with the chef. Overall this place is a 3.5 for me but since there is no in between I will have to give it a three.
author: Ada H.

description: This is a sushi kaiseki restaurant, the owner and head chef Nori is very nice, sushi rice is made with red vinegar, Katsuo is smoked, I like it very much. My favorite is the soft boiled wagyu beef tongue, very very delicious, high cost-effective restaurant, highly recommended.
author: 会懿

description: Best value omakase in its category. Nothing beats the freshly made nigiri piece hand delivered to you across the counter within seconds it's made. Every bite was a symphony of flavors in your mouth. Unforgettable experience.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
My stomach and my heart are both crying tears of joy, but my wallet...not so much. Still, this place was worth every.single.penny.

Amy T. and I made a reservation for 8:30pm on a Friday. We arrived at ~8:10 and was seated promptly. We were served by none other than the head chef and owner himself, Chef Kusakabe. 

We decided to go with the Grand Omakase because go big and then go home right? The Grand Omakase ($165) comes with 10 courses which ends up being quite a bit. Chef Kusakabe asked us what we like and we mentioned that we liked Toro and Uni and he kept that in mind. Oh my god. I don't know where to start, but EVERYTHING WAS SO GOOD. The starting Zuke Chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce) was absolutely divine. We were like damn if this is the starter nigiri, what the hell can be better than this? The answer was nothing because everything was delicious. We devoured everything so fast that I was sad when he told us we're at the last few dishes. He remembered what we said about the Tori and Uni because we finished our night with those two. I just wanted to cry eating those two. T_T Seriously, I can only say everything is good, but if you are reading this, you have to try everything for yourself to know! We were a good level full by the end of the meal, and they also give you a menu to order a la carte if you want more.

We also got two orders of Sake to go with our food as well. I totally don't remember what it was but they were both good! They offer a wide selection of sake ranging from cheap stuff to things I would never buy unless I was driving a Lambo or something.

Everyone here is a master at what they do. The knife skills, the plating skills, etc. It's really a wonder to watch them do their work so naturally. 

Kusakabe deserves its Michelin star and so much more. This is an insane omakase experience. They serve only the best sushi, sashimi and kaiseki. You will not be disappointed!!
author: Gabriel N.

description:
My friend took me here for my belated bday dinner.  I've been waiting all week to try this place.  I wasn't sure if i could do the 10 course or the 7 course.  But i knew i wanted to order a few items a la carte, so i went with the 7 course menu.  When they seated us, they sat us at the bar! I love sitting at the bar because that's where you get to watch all the action.  My chef's name was Patrick and he was a great host and chef the whole evening.  The way this place works, is that you are supposed to use your hands to eat the sushi.  There will be some dishes that will require chopsticks.

To start off the night, we got the sake flight.  It's 3 different types of sake- Junmai, Ginjo, and Daiginjo.  The Junami sake we got was the Heart and soul- this was my 2nd favorite of the three.  The Ginjo sake was the Flying dragon- this was my least favorite.   The Daiginjo sake was the Sophisticated Mind- this was my favorite and by far the strongest among the three.  

And now the begin the 7 course menu

The ichiban Dashi was like soup.  This soup had a very refreshing taste to it. 

Sushi Prelude- Zuke Chutoro and halibut was fresh and sweet.  The smoked tuna was ok, but i'm biased, i never liked anything smoked

Sashimi-Also fresh and felt like it melted in your mouth

Hassan- 6 kinds of chef's assorted les petit.  This dish included a clam in a creamy corn sauce, which i loved.   The soft shell crab was really good.  The beef tartar was on a rice cracker which made it the perfect combo.  Jellyfish and the asparagus with shrimp was my least favorite because i normally don't like jellyfish and asparagus.  The oyster was sweet and super fresh.  There was no particular way to eat this, so i did it from least to favorite.  Save the best for last right?

Soup- This fish soup was sweet and you can tell the spent time making this to get it to have this flavor, because i know that fish soup isn't easy to make.  A bonus to this soup is that it came with noodles. 

Seasonal Sushi- Yellowtail- really good,  Mackerel with egg yolk - this one was my favorite.  I love egg, so i loved how this was topped with egg yolk.  The first fish was a fish from a salmon family- this was ok, but it was really hard to top the Mackerel one! 

Finale- Scallop with Santa barbara Uni-  This one was tasty.  The scallop was so fresh along with the uni.  

A la Carte-  Bafun Uni- This was like a party in your mouth.  Yes, it did give you the melt in your mouth taste and i wished i had more. I wanted more, but i was starting to get full

Wagyu-  This was good, but i think i liked the uni more. 

For dessert I got the Cream Brulee- by far the best creme brulee i've ever had. It was perfect and not too sweet. 

Yuzu sorbet-  this was very refreshing and perfect if you're a yuzu lover.  

The service was great and attentive.  They comp. my bday dessert which i didn't expect.  I will really want to come back again, but next time i'll try the 10 course menu and try all their uni selections! So in comparison to wako and wakuriya, I liked this place more than wakuriya,  but about the same as wako.
author: Belinda C.

description:
I'm not sure how, but I was able to score Saturday reservations just under a week before the day I wanted to go. I think. Or that's what my emails tell me at least. The sushi stars aligned to make Kusakabe happen for the boyfriend's birthday *sparkles*

We planned to arrive early, not knowing how bad parking would be in the area, but we found parking easily! This meant we were about 15 minutes early, and when we walked by their doors were still locked. We strolled around the area a bit (nothing to see though), but it would've been nice if they had a sitting/waiting area for people who are early. Impossible with how small the place is though! They have enough bar seats for maybe 20-ish people, and then a couple 2-4 tops to the side. 

When they called to confirm my reservations, I asked for bar seating and I believe they said they had it available. I don't think there was an option to make a note when I made the reservations online. 

Highlights of the Grand Omakase:
- Bonito: This was smoked and topped with spiced radish. I'm not usually a fan of smokiness, but I remember really enjoying it. 
- Baby anago with quail egg: Very interesting! For a second, we were a bit creeped out since you could see the eyes but we got over it
- Hon maguro and kanpachi sashimi: The yuzu onion sauce was SO GOOD
- Red miso soup: YUM. The foam on top was such a nice addition, and the lime zest added the perfect hint of citrus. The meatball in the soup was super tender and melted in my mouth.
- Chiayu: The bamboo that came with this was so sweet, in the good way
- Nodoguro: I ordered this a la carte because we don't see it often. Such buttery, fatty goodness. 
- Yuzu sorbet: I LOVE yuzu, and this sorbet was so smooth and tarte. The perfect finish to the meal
- Creme brulee: The bf really enjoyed this as it was super creamy and not too sweet.

I didn't really care too much for the hassun (fancy assorted appetizer-looking dish) too much, but the crab claw was my favorite of the bunch. The fuji sake w/ cherry leaf had a bitterness that I didn't really enjoy, but I think it was intended. The wagyu was seasoned with salt, pepper and lemon juice -- a touch too much lemon juice IMO. 

Service was nothing less than what you'd expect at a high-end omakase restaurant. Our server was super friendly the whole time. I didn't catch our chef's name, but he was super sweet and chatted with us when he could. Like all omakase spots, each nigiri and dish was clearly explained to us. 

I'm glad to be able to check Kusakabe off my list of must-try omakase spots. Writing this review 4 months since our visit, I can't say that anything in particular stood out to me. It was a solid omakase meal in a lovely, intimate environment with great service.
author: Doris K.

description:
Kusakabe is the place to go for a special occasion! It's some of the best sushi not just in SF but period. I've tried numerous Michelin Star Sushi places in the city and the best Sushi spots in So Cal and this is by far my favorite.  Yes, it's better than even the sushi at the Tokyo fish market (albeit more expensive; but so is a flight to Japan).

Kusakabe blends traditional and modern perfectly. It provides multiple complex flavors with each bite. It's made to please everyone and it's quite different than Omakase's edomae style, for example. It's very San Francisco's and it incorporates things like avocado. That being said it still keeps the tradition of sushi and respectfully modernizes it and elevates the flavor profiles. Nothing quite like it.

Make sure to ask to be seated at the bar so you can converse with your chef and make it a personal experience (bonus points: ask for the main Chef, Mitsunori). Ask them about why they are there and how hard they had to work to get where they are. Trust me, it will change your perspective on sushi and you'll find a new appreciation for the art (oh and if you don't know proper etiquette, they'll teach you that, too). Already experienced at fine dining and sushi? You can have more complex conversations about the specific sushi, techniques, ask for the Wagyu Beef's certificate, etc. 

I've done table seating, too, and it's a completely different experience. That being said, if you want to minimize the interactions with chefs, the staff, and want to just eat your food in peace and privacy, you can go the table route.

The food is amazing, the pairings fit well, and the staff is perfect. 

So what should you get? I'd say if you are going, might as well get the grand omakase! And while you are at it, at the end go crazy and get things like toro with uni, gold flakes and caviar (if available). Their wagyu is also A5 Grade 12! Make sure to enjoy every bite. If you are more of an expert with a developed and specific taste, you can go with the regular omakase and get exactly what you want a la carte after to maximize the customization of your meal and have more of exactly what you want.
author: Mario B.

description:
3.5 stars
I made a reservation for my boyfriend's birthday online three weeks ago. Online reservation is very convenient, unlike some other restaurants calling them is the only way to make reservation. We were very excited for this meal because it was both of our first time having omakase. Seeing all the great reviews and mouthwatering photos of the sushi gave us really high expectation for this place. We were 30 minutes early(we though there would be traffic but there was none) but was seated promptly. We were given three menus: omakase/petite omakase menu, sake/wine pairing menu, regular sake/wine menu. The server didn't tell us there was an a la carte menu but I heard the server at the next table told his customers and explained the difference between the two omakase menu. I wanted to do the petite omakase and ordered from a la carte menu afterwards, but my boyfriend wanted to try the full omakase. It was his birthday so I let him pick whatever. We didn't do the pairing because we tried wine pairing at another restaurant on my birthday and I was buzzed half way through and couldn't enjoy the rest of the meal. However we did ordered an 8oz sake to drink slowly throughout the course. The first half of the menu was AMAZING. The fish were very fresh and flavorful. The second half of the menu was not as amazing as the first half. Maybe because I was getting full since I ate a lot in the morning. I should have thought it through. For the last 4-5 courses I was shoveling food down my throat without really spent time tasting them in my mouth. I was so full I had to give a few pieces of my sushi to my boyfriend. I am sure the sushi courses would taste a lot better if I had the appetite. However I didn't really enjoy the petit plates and the wagyu tongue stew no matter if I was full or not. Reading the reviews I know most people love these two courses, but maybe I have a different palate. I liked the fish a lot more. Honestly I don't think we would have missed out if we had picked the petite omakase. Frankly speaking Im not being entirely fair to the restaurant since I got full half way. So I asked my boyfriend if he enjoyed it and he said not really. The only thing he liked was the uni. But I will definitely bookmark this restaurant and come back here again with a very empty stomach so I can update a fairer review next time!

I totally forgot to take pictures of the second half courses. I was so full and just wanted to get them over with.
author: Lisa M.

description: Came here for dinner and got a table seat, which is more private and less interactive than a bar seat. This was my first Japanese Omakase experience, so I probably should've went with the bar seating. We chose the regular omakase and added the wagyu sashimi from the a la carte menu. The quality of the fish they used was the freshest I've had in the city! Everything was presented beautifully. We also got the sake pairing with our omakase, and unless you're willing to drink A LOT during this meal, I advise you to pass on this (it's not cheap either haha). We got a super generous amount of sake for every course, so much that I shamefully did not finish and avoided eye contact with the server every time she took away our glasses. Overall, it was a good experience. Next time, I'll definitely get a seat at the bar and no sake pairing.
author: Nancy C.

description:
My bar for sushi just skyrocketed! The ambience of this place is clean and cozy. We were greeted with a warm hand towel to clean our hands before the meal and then a cute little finger towel placed next to you, that was adorable.

This is the most unique and highest quality sushi I've had! They don't rush you with each plate either, and yet they're attentive to bring out the new dishes when you're done. The fish was fresh and each dish was intricately plated - I felt like I was eating art.
author: Eunice T.

description: You will not feel hungry after the omakase here. If you order sale with your omakase it will add up. So if you are on budget you can always just order the omakase menu. This place is really cute and not super upscale that feel stuffy. The food of course are amazing. If you can make the reservation for the  sushi bar.
author: L D.

description: This was a wonderful sushi bar. Very authentic and classy. Since it was just me (as usual), I was able to sit at the bar. The sushi they serve is very VERY high quality. I was fitted as soon as I got there. PERIOD!!! Amazing dining experience. I'm impressed. Reason for the 4 stars: slightly expensive for the amount of food I ordered. Regardless, I recommend to anyone who is a fan of truly authentic Omakase sushi.
author: Olive R.

description: Best omakase I've had. I can't go back to eating cheap nigiri at regular sushi restaurants anymore! Every piece of fish was buttery smooth. I enjoyed the broth and all the other small dishes of raw delicacies which I can't remember the names of. To end this meal, me and my friends ordered extra wagyu and toro nigiri a la carte. You will end up leaving satisfied but not overwhelmingly full.
author: Sui N.

description:
Trying to not be biased.
Trying to not be biased.
Trying to not be biased.

I had the best omakase meal (BEST MEAL OF MY LIFE) in Japan. Knowing that anywhere else would never compare I was excited to try Kusakabe with a grain of salt. 

We did the Grand Omakase ($165) and I had the Sake Flight ($50). It was a mixture of sushi and special Kaiseki dishes. Highlights were the A5 Wagyu, the Uni, and this fish (I forgot) topped with Uni. While the meals were of high quality and delicious, we were still hungry after our meal. 

Service was excellent. Chef Ngai made sure to note allergies and was fun to watch and interact with as he prepared our courses. Service given by other staff made sure our dinner was enjoyable. 

I don't mind paying for a great meal, but something about this experience did not WOW me. Maybe my omakase experience in Japan did alter my expectations, so maybe my review is unfair. But eat sushi in Japan and come back and tell me you don't feel the same.
author: Catherine T.

description:
My BF took me here for my birthday and I have heard mixed things, so I was not sure what to expect, but Kusakabe was a treat - a damn good treat. We enjoyed the entire experience and so did everyone around us. We had a couple next to us visiting from NY, which has TONS of food, but they still thought Kusakabe was good.

They do a 7 course omakase for $98 or a 12 for $165. Near the end of your omakase, they give you an a la carte menu, so you can always order more! We did the 7 course and both got a  wagyu nigiri from a la carte and that was such a good amount. GET THE WAGYU NIGIRI!!! This was mind-blowingly good. We still talk about it and we regret not getting another 1....or 2...or 7 lol the sake creme brulee was so good as well.

I really liked our sushi chef, who took time to answer any questions and who gave me the best dang uni ever haha he must have heard the longing in my voice when I was talking about how much I love uni, because for our last course, he subbed out the fish and gave me uni!!! They recommend you eat all the nigiri with your hands so that was super fun. We didn't take too many pictures because we couldn't help ourselves from devouring everything right when it was placed on our plate....hey.....don't let the freshness go to waste!!!

Yes, Kusakabe is $$$, so it's not a place I can eat every month, but it is a nice place to go and celebrate something. TREAT YO' SELF!!!!

Disclaimer: Kusakabe does change their menu and I have heard of folks getting some MEH menus!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Since Kusabake is an omakase restaurant, I was hoping we can sit in front of the sushi bar to see how they prepare the sushi and serve it right in front of us. However, it was disappointing to find out party of two or more were not able to sit by the sushi bar and we had 4 people. I feel like that is part of the experience if I was to dish out $200 bucks for a meal. 

We were seated promptly by our reservation time at 8:15 and we chose the Grand Omakase because of the delicacy menu options (Truffle, A5 Wagyu beef, Hokkaido Sea Urchin, Eel from Tsukiji Market and Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly). An important thing to point out is we were NEVER served the Toro bluefin fatty tuna belly like the menu stated. Instead we were served Negitoro, which is minced fatty tuna with micro onion on a roasted seaweed. Those are two very different things, I wanted to ask why we were served the negitoro instead of the fatty tuna belly, but since my friends didn't mention I didn't want to be particular. Now that I think about it, I am quite angry that the manager didn't mention anything at all about switching our menu. 

Anyways, a review on the food that we DID have. It was a 10 course menu (with 2 soups) and it was more than enough. A tip for everyone, if you want to do a la carte towards the end, I suggest you choose the regular Omakase with less courses. Actually with the Grand Omakase, there is a course with non-sashimi/sushi dish. So if you here for the sushi/sashimi definitely choose the regular Omakase then do a la carte at the end. 

One thing to note about the sushi here is that they seasoned all their rice. At first it looked like brown rice, then we realized every piece of rice has soy sauce seasoned so the flavor is even throughout. My favorite sushi would definitely be the Oshinogi with Scallop+Uni sushi, Nata with poached egg on spoon, the uni sushi and surprisingly the Shima Aji (stripe jack) which is the chef's choice of sushi. The Hassun which included 6 small plates was also very tasty, I love how the food is like art. The wagyu beef tartare was one of the most delicious tartare that I ever had. The most disappointing course would definitely be the seared A5 Wagyu sushi, they over-seasoned it with too much pepper and salt overpowering the taste of the wagyu. It felt like they wasted a perfectly fine piece of meat, except the meat itself had a bit too much lines in it. 

Overall, I highly recommend Kusakabe for Omakase on a special occasion or if you are visiting from out of town. It seems like a popular date place, you can impress somebody by bringing them here and eating in front of the sushi bar. It's a shame we didn't get to sit there to watch as the sushi chef prepare our dishes. There might have been 1 or 2 disappointment, nevertheless it was a good experience. And I figured out why they lost their star; it was not perfect like it should be.
author: Gloria C.

description:
Grand Omakase is certainly the legit way to open up this great Japanese gem, as one gets to experience the carefully made sushi pieces, but also have an opportunity to try some of the kitchen made dishes. Michelin one star for the past two years, yet was taken away the star this year, unfortunately.

Plus: all their uni was from Hokkaido (I personally did not like Uni from the west coast - it was big in size yet less flavorful), so made it a great combo with either the scallop or the vinegar rice itself. Also, the wagyu beef was seared just to the right level of tenderness, and carried a little smooth texture on top, very unique taste!

Minus: the cooked sweet fish was a bit bitter that I did not find myself quite fond of. 

This is my first Kaiseki in the west coast and pros certainly overweighted cons. Kusakabe definitely worth a star in my opinion, compared with some of the east coast sushi places. 

Last piece of advice - don't miss the dessert part, as it was not included in the Kaiseki fixed menu.
author: Elaine H.

description:
This was my third omakase in SF, the one with the middle price range ($95, 7 courses) but I must say it was hands down the best, and I was thoroughly impressed. 

We began with a fish broth - clear but flavourful. Not super light, but not heavy either. 
Next was the sushi starter, brimming with rich, citrusy, and smokey flavours.

--- Chef's assorted "les petit plats" ----
The following act was an assortment of 5 dishes. I loved how each element brought something a little different to the table. 

- Mackerel: I felt like it may have been a touch dry (not sure if that was the intention or not, but I think if I had to say anything about the whole experience, this was the only thing that wasn't super amazing, though it was still tasty). 
- Oyster with caviar is definitely the best oyster I've ever had. Of course, no unwanted particles (no sand whoot), and the oyster was not super briney, but rather smooth and citrusy. 
- Croquette was interesting. Sweet miso on top.
- Baby eel bowl: the flavours was very clean, crisp, and clear. The eel itself was like noodles, and it was kind of cute being able to see the little eyes as I munched away haha. 
- Barracuda sushi was the first (and last) roll sushi of the day. It was good, no complaints here. 

--- Soup and Sushi ---
- Red miso was rich but not heavy, and the duck meatball with foie gras in the centre was interesting. 
- Ika and uni with rice and sandwiches in between some seaweed. 
- Fatty toro was the finale. 

--- Condiments ---
- House made soy sauce: made with shiitake mushrooms!
- Japanese seaweed salt
- Citrus juice: lemon, line, and yuzu.

Everything presented at Kusakabe was such an experience: beautifully presented and exploding with flavours - worth every penny. I would definitely come back again!
author: Joanna C.

description:
Worth every single dollar that you have. Kusakabe is the best restaurant experience of my life. 

We came on a reservation. Be sure to sit at the bar as it heightens the experience. Once seated, the server will ask for any allergies and any fish that you like/dislike. 

Once that is finished, you start your dining experience right away. The have to menu's to pick from, one that costs $98 per head or the one that costs $150 per head. We opted to go for the $98 per head. The menu is a 20 course meal with a chance at the end to order a la carte. 

I will not explain every singe course but it was just a symphony of flavors that took you on a dining journey. Kusakabe will have you experience all types of emotions. There was times where I caught myself laughing for no apparent reason. The food here will make you feel some type of way. One sushi that I do highly highly recommend is the A5 wagyu. The wagyu is absolutely the best thing that I put into my mouth that night. It was an indescribable moment, it is just something people need to have when here. 

Kusakabe is the best dining experience that I've been to, and it will be yours as well.
author: James L.

description: This was probably one of the best omakase I have ever had. The environment is very nice and the staff were very welcoming. Our sushi chef Nathan was very nice and would talk to us often during our meal. The staff were also very polite. The food was also very beautiful and tasted like I was in Japan again. The seafood was very fresh and almost melted in your mouth. The price isn't that bad either. Although it may not stand out on the outside, the inside experience is like a heavenly experience. Highly recommend going here. You will not be disappointed.
author: Kristin H.

description: Amazing food. I am not really sushi person and don't like raw fish, but the food here really doesn't make you feel like raw fish at all. Super fresh food, nice presentation and approachable chef. My favorite of night is the one with Yuzu and eel. Only improvement I can think of is that the seat was quite small and there is only one female chef there. Diversity matters. Also, I think the big tasting menu was too big for me. I would actually prefer small one and maybe some more variety of food instead of just sushi. Good food!
author: Anya C.

description: This was such a great omakase experience and we were lucky to be served by chef Kusakabe himself! It's kaiseki style so some of the courses are actual plates and prepared in the kitchen. Everything was amazing and so fresh. Sitting at the bar is the best way to go if possible, because you can see everything the chef does to create your next course and realize just how many different things go into that one beautiful delicious piece of sushi. The toro was probably one of my favorites and of course the uni, which our chef put into at least three of the courses since we told him that was our favorite, and the eel was so good! They get the eel fresh from the Tsukiji market in Japan which is really awesome. The whole dining experience probably took close to two hours. It's expensive but probably worth it.
author: Jeana Y.

description:
LATE REVIEW! Got served by the head chef himself -- except we didn't know that until the very end of the meal!! Got a photo with him too; he was very friendly and responsive to each of our questions and we had a light conversation throughout the entire meal -- he and the waiter serving us took great care in explaining each dish.

Total price for two was around $500, including the sake (I've never had an appreciation for dry sake before this, but man oh man). Let me tell you that this experience was life-changing. The food was phenomenal: there were a lot of firsts thrown in there that my boyfriend and I have never tried before or expected to be on the menu; the plating was simple but impactful; the course was designed around each other in perfect, delicious symphony.

I believe we had the spring seasonal course. We enjoyed some of the dishes so much that we had to call back the waiter to tell us what it was again -- and then we took notes because we loved it so much!! Here are some of the notable favorites:
- Japanese amberjack with plum base, cured kelp, and mountain yam
- Kasugodai (cured) with bamboo leaf and red snapper
- Two week aged otoro (fat of tuna)

This was an anniversary dinner and they gave both of the desserts we ordered on the house! Dishes were cleared in a better than timely manner -- it was like they were reading our minds! We were served at our own pace but each meal was made just in time for the plating. Also, we befriended the couple next to us, even exchanging contact information; goes to show that good food will bring people together.

Thank you, Chef Nori, for introducing us to fine dining in the most elegant, humble, and sumptuous way! We will be back again.
author: Angelica N.

description: I had a great time tonite, they serve well , food were amazing , although I am a big fan of sushi, they still surprise me. They also offer the desert for my bday girl , deeply appreciate. This is a Omakase place that I would love to be back
author: Kenny C.

description:
Defiantly a fine dining experience for your eyes and taste buds. The chef takes your a wonderful sushi dinner experience with omasake menu options. It was just an incredible experience something I would love to do again. 

First I must say the severs are just so well versed in the history of the food and all the menu items. They went into detail explaining what we were eating. It is traditional to eat with your hands. They start with providing warm hand towels to clean your hands and then they leave you a tiny finger cleaning cloth. The first dish is a warm soup a pallet cleanser. Very mild flavor but still very good. Each dish was beautifully plated and served. It was like honestly hard to eat it because it was like food art. Each dish was incredible, I just can't put into words how wonderful each piece of sushi was. The fish was fresh, flavorful and just melted in your mouth. The flavors on each were do dynamic and different. They offer a drink pairing with each dish but we had their house matcha instead. It was incredible. The hot tea was perfect for keeping us warm and for prepping our palate for the next serving. 

Overall a beautiful and incredible sushi experience. This is definitely for a real sushi lover. These are not Cali rolls or the fancy baked ones. It is just pure fresh fish and ingredients. Not dressed up, just in the simplest most delicious form. The chefs are just amazing here. The beauty they create visually and the amazing flavors on your tongue. I would definitely come back!
author: Karen H.

description:
Made a reservation two months in advance for the bf and I. We celebrated his birthday and were lucky enough to get bar seating. We chose the 8:00pm seating time, figured it would allow us to eat at our own pace and not be rushed for time. 

The place itself is beautiful, clean, and the service was amazing. Friendly hosts, servers and sushi chefs made the entire experience even more enjoyable. We were so happy to get bar seating. We checked in early around 7:30 hoping that if we came in early it would determine our seating place. However, it looks like it depends on how early you make your reservations and your party size. The smaller the party and the earlier you reserve, you'll likely get a bar seat. 

We started with a nice warm hand towel and then the dashi broth which was honestly one of my favorite parts of the meal. We decided to chose the regular omakase and order a la carte afterwards. Some highlights from our meal was of course the dashi broth, blue fin tuna, red miso broth, and the list goes on. Everything was wonderfully made and delicious. I found myself closing my eyes and thinking holy crap with every bite I had. To finish our meal we tried the wagyu beef which is a must!!! It's included in the grand omakase and available on the a la carte menu. Definitely worth the $14 for each piece. 

All in all, this is a must if you're a fan of sushi or if you're celebrating an event. From the service to the food to the overall experience, it was amazing. I seriously felt like I was on a high because it was just such an awesome time. I was dreaming about my meal for days after and I can't wait to have an excuse to go back.
author: Melissa M.

description:
