We came to kusakabe to celebrate the end of Q3. The restaurant is fairly small so reservations in advance are probably a requirement. I didn't specify sushi bar or table at the time I made the reso and was placed at a table. I regret not specifying sushibar. Oh well. 

Food was beautifully presented and my bf really liked the taste. He's one of those picky Hong Kong foodies. I thought I was a picky eater until.. 

You have the option of picking the cheaper $100 menu or the more expensive $150? Menu. The difference isn't too big so we went with the cheaper on. While we didn't leave full, we also didn't leave hungry. We went to Safeway and contemplated second dinner but decided against the idea after walking around. 

If you're in your early 20s with a great metabolism, you'll probably want to make plans for second dinner. Otherwise, I think kusakabe was a well-balanced, tasty kaiseki dinner.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Kusakabe is an experience. You go for the chef-led omakase and are presented with course after course of beautifully-formed, high-quality dishes that take your palate on a little tour of Japanese flavors and techniques. The dining room is small and reservations are required, but I got to come with a group of seven friends, and it was a great experience trying and discussing all the different courses together. This is not your typical, run-of-the-mill sushi, so be prepared to splurge (the base menu comes at a hefty $98/head), and come with an appreciation for the quality and cost of purveyance of the ingredients. 

Course #1: a subtly-flavored dashi broth. Nothing unusual (after all, there are only three ingredients in this fish-based broth), but very clean tasting and a nice way to start the meal.

Course #2: The zuku chutoro (bluefin medium fatty tuna) was seared on one side, giving the fish a great texture to complement its flavors. The hirame halibut with its own liver had a slightly spicy kick, and the cold-smoked bonito (katsuo) resounded with the flavors of the wood smoke.

Course #3: Bluefin sashimi and poached amberjack (a surprising favorite of mine). These pieces were served simply with soy and yuzu onion sauces, and came with little slices of fuji apple and radish. You had some of every flavor here--sweet from the apple, bitter from the radish, salty/umami from the soy, and tart from the yuzu. 

Course 4: By far the most beautifully plated, the "Hassun" came with an oyster with caviar in the center, surrounded by five small dishes--Japanese sardines with mushrooms and broth, the Wagyu beef fritter (mostly potato, but it had the distinctly funky aroma of raw Wagyu), the jellyfish (paired with crunchy pinenuts and cucumber), and a sweet tai (red sea bream) sushi roll with asparagus in the middle. But my favorite dish was definitely the soft-shell crab, which was so creamy on the inside and delicately crunchy on the inside!

Course 5: Red miso soup with a duck and lotus root meatball, layered with soy cream foam. Delicious, umami soup with layers of flavor that change as you sip, and the lotus root adds an unexpected, pleasant chewiness to the meatball.

Course 6: My favorite sushi of the meal was the shima aji, the stripe jack with daikon radish, which was so buttery in texture and had a scallop-like flavor. The cherry salmon and the kasugodai (red snapper with crystallized egg yolk) both melted in your mouth as well. Unbelievable!

Course 7: a finale of toro (fatty Bluefin tuna) and a nori roll with bafun uni (sea urchin) and ikura (fish roe). The toro is definitely the best I've had in the US, but there was too little uni in the roll to really appreciate its briny flavors.

Course by course, everyone is served at the same time, and the staff explain each and every component--the work that goes behind each of these dishes/components is indeed immense! After the omakase meal, we were given an a la carte menu, from which we could order even more sushi or sashimi. I got the aori ika (big fin reef squid), which was extremely creamy in texture, though not particularly vibrant in flavor. 

And then we went for dessert! We ordered one of each item to share, and each of the desserts was so unique. The yuzu and shiso-leaf sorbet was nice and refreshing (slightly acidic and herbal flavors), the (unsweetened kome koji) ice cream had sweetness imparted to it from the same fermented flavors that you find in sake, and the Daiginjo sake kasu crème brulee had the same fermented flavors as the ice cream, but was much sweeter and decadent.

Overall, a great meal and definitely something to experience! The restaurant itself is small but homey and authentic (the bathroom even features an automated Japanese toilet). The service is the epitome of Japanese hospitality and the prices are exorbitant, so make sure to come with an appreciation of the work, care, and quality that goes behind each bite of food.
author: David K.

description:
"No question ....An amazing place! The best sushi and Japanese dining I've ever had!
I got omaase and sake pairing .
I took my time to enjoy every bite....Respect  them !!!"
author: Jenna K.

description:
As everyone is saying, go here before they get their star! 

An old friend and I went here for dinner. It. Was. Oishiiiiiiiiii. Desune. We sat at the bar and were down one person (unexpected death - not our one person but the one person's colleague!), but the restaurant kindly accommodated us without a penalty. Superb. Service.

We sat at the bar (as most patrons do in this small space) awaiting our omakase experience. If you like sushi, seafood, and Japanese. Eat. Here. 

Part of an amazing dining experience for me is the delight in seeing each one of the dishes come out. So, I don't want to spoil it for you by describing in a long review each and every dish we ate there... but I'll tell you this. Ask your sushi chef questions! And note that they take any dislikes and food restrictions quite seriously. Make your preferences known (politely, of course), then embark on a wondrous two-hour dinner. Our sushi chef was fun and knowledgeable. Good. Times!
author: Daphne C.

description:
One of the most accommodating restaurants I have EVER dined at. If I could describe the feeling of being cradled and rocked to sleep as an adult, it would be my experience at Kusakabe.

We got stuck in awful traffic coming up the peninsula and ended up getting to the restaurant 45 minutes after our reservation time. The most stressful part of the trip was not being able to get a hold of anyone at the restaurant because their phones shut down after 4pm. I left a message anyways to let them know my situation and they ended up calling me back to confirm. When we arrived, they seated us immediately and didn't give us too much crap for being so late. :-)

The main reason for dining here was to celebrate the BF's birthday and eat his favorite food, sushi. My sushi tolerance typically doesn't extend beyond a rainbow roll so it was exciting to see what really good sushi should taste like. I also let the restaurant know in advance what the occasion was and they were FABULOUS about making the evening special for him.

We went with the Omakase ($95/pp) option and an 8oz of the Kenbishi Junmai sake (yum).
- First brewed broth: Great start to the meal to cleanse the palate with gentle flavors from the dried Konbu (kelp)
- Zuke Chutoro (bluefin fatty tuna) was my favorite. I ordered another one a-la-carte at the end of the meal.
- Loved the fried fish and crab claw that came with the oyster dish!!
- We ordered the Houji-cha ice cream for dessert and brought it out with a candle so I could quietly sing happy birthday :-) (also comp'd the dessert)

At one point, I dropped my chopsticks and before I could swoop down to pick it up, the chef made a few gestures and a new pair arrived...magic. I also mentioned to our server that it would be hard to remember all the names of everything we ordered so they packed the menus for us in a large envelope and wrote 'happy birthday' on it.

From the quality of our meal to the thoughtfulness of our chef and the entire restaurant staff, they went above and beyond to make this event truly memorable and special.
author: Kat C.

description:
4.5/5. I came here for my birthday and the experience was great. We were literally the last ones in the restaurant the night before the news broke that Kusakabe lost its Star. Compared to Wako, Kusakabe was probably not as worth the money and the fish at Wako was of slightly higher quality than here, hence the -0.5 stars. However, it is still a reasonable meal at $98 for the quality of the fish and craftsmanship of the nigiri. I would definitely recommend trying to get a reservation if you have a special event to celebrate. 

[Omakase]
A-la-carte menu is always the best part of omakase, in my opinion. I go to experience the A5 wagyu beef nigiri, and it blew my mind. My other favorite roll was the Toro. I didn't know fish could taste like this (I guess it does at $15 extra per piece). I also really like the Sashimi. Oyster set was very creative. Since it was my birthday, the restaurant gave me a sorbet on the house that I thought was really nice! Otherwise, desert is extra. I did still feel hungry after my regular Omakase, so I would recommend maybe upgrading to the Grand.  You're going to want to spend more on extra nigiri at the end anyway so you might as well.

[Service / Decor]
Our chef was great. He explained each piece to us and, sitting at the bar, we were able to watch the nigiri come to life right before our eyes. I really like the decor of the restaurant. It was slightly larger than the overage Omakase, but still cozy and well lit. 

Overall, I think Kusakabe is a great restaurant that offers great Omakase with pricing in line with comparable restaurants. I did like Wako slightly more, but both are still worth trying.
author: Alice Z.

description: Beyond excellent. I've been here twice and have had the omakase meal with same pairing each time.  Definitely request to be seated at the bar when you make reservations.
author: Wendy C.

description:
My boyfriend and I have Grand Omakase, which contains 11 courses. It mainly has sushi and with A5 Wagyu and soup. All of them are pretty good. 
Recommend tofu tiramisu~
author: 碧晴

description: Excellent.....Excellent it was kinda last minute reservation but I couldn't pass up a restaurant I've been wanting to try for months lol, the sake flight and the omakase full were all amazing..the fish and ingredients used were top notch and the service was spot on,example each component of the dishes and where the fish were sourced..if you every get a chance don't hesitate
author: jonathan h.

description:
Celebrated my birthday on 2/22 and it was just as good as the first time. This time with Chef Ken! Same thoughts as my original review, except I managed to spend $20 less this time. Whoo! Went with the Grand Omakase at $150(?) and still managed to do a la carte + dessert. Definitely had a few of my a la carte pieces comp'd by Chef Ken, thank you!!

Total: $260 per person with tip.
author: Fanny W.

description:
reservation time: 5:30pm on Saturday. We sat at the sushi bar. 

Food: we ordered the $98 Omakase. It is really awesome. I think there are 7 pieces of nigiri and 1 nori roll. The condiment of each nigiri is so well-matched. My favorite one is the Scallop with Santa Barbara uni on top. OMG, it is really amazing. The portion of the rice is not a lot which is really what I like and should be what an authentic nigiri be like.  
For other places i've been to like Hinata, they put too much rice for nigiri. 

The environment is comfortable but the table is kind of too high. 

Reason why I gave 3 star even though the food is really good is below. 
I got there at around 535 and my friend hasn't got there yet. I explained to the staff saying that my friend will be late for maybe at least 30 mins because of the traffic. And she looked unhappy. I told her that I could just sit down and order for my friend. I said the chef could just make two portion of the sushi and put my friend's portion in a plate or something. After my friend comes, he could just enjoy it. 

She was like, there's "no place" to put the nigiri. we don't do to-go box. And then she kept suggesting me that my friend has to be here before 6 otherwise, they can't serve us. I was like.. THIS IS CRAZY. I already got here and do i have to just waste money and eat nothing? She explained to me that the second-seating guests will come at 8pm so there is no enough time for the chef to serve us if my friend comes after 6. I told her that we eat very fast. But then she pushed back again saying that even if you guys eat fast and chef can't make the food fast. It still has to depend on the chef. She even said that if my friend comes after 6, then the chef won't have enough time to serve all the food ( even if we paid the same price as others....

At the end, my friend came at around 5:50PM. And then she took us to our seats. We finished at around "7PM". ( i was like.. how come there won't be enough time if my friend come after 6..) Also, there's a small plate in front of everyone. But she said that there's no PLACE to put nigiri if I sit in and order for my friend first.

I totally understand that she wanted us to enjoy an authentic and comfortable eating environment for omakase. But i feel the way she communicated to me is like.. "YOU can't eat until your friend comes and you are going to just throw your money to trash can WITHOUT eating anything if your friend doesn't come before 6 even if I AM already here" 

Also,The bathroom is broken and the staff told me that she will have people take me to another bathroom. 

Based on the experience with the front staff, suggest people have to be arriving at exactly the time you reserve and no one in your group could be late. 
For me, I will not come again even the food is REALLY awesome.
author: Tina H.

description:
One of the best sushi experiences I've had in the US. We opted for the regular Omakase course and almost every single piece of sushi we had was as amazing as the next. The flavor and texture of each nigiri was exactly the way I like it, and I really enjoyed the rice which was more tart than some sushi places. The ginger also tasted less sweet and more sour which I enjoyed as well.

The stand outs for me were the Shima Aji (stripe jack) and the Katsuo (bonito) which was lightly smoked with cherry wood. The subtle smoky flavor was aromatic and complemented the perfectly fatty fish topped with the momiji oroshi (grated daikon radish with chili peppers) which added a hint of spice. My mouth is watering just thinking about it! 

We were lucky enough to score a reservation at 5:30pm but arrived a bit early and were seated at the sushi bar. I don't think I would want to dine here unless I was guaranteed the sushi bar. It really makes a HUGE difference in both the service and the taste and flavor of the sushi and when you're paying the same amount, why not opt for the option that's twice as better? 

The excellent service, GREAT sushi, and the glass of rosé I had puts Kusakabe in the top 3 best sushi experiences I've had in the US! The ONLY reason why it may not be number 1 was because the bafun uni had a slight ammonia flavor which I couldn't get past. I have an EXTREMELY sensitive sense of smell so to others it may taste perfectly fine! 

Overall I highly recommend this restaurant for any special
occasion or if you're in town looking for great sushi. It is on the pricy side but much more affordable compared to high-end sushi places in Manhattan or LA.
author: Sarah A.

description: Came here for my birthday celebration with my girlfriends. We all did the 7 course tasting for $98. High quality fish, it was worth the price. We all had an amazing time, staff was really sweet. The entire restaurant (staff and guests) all sung happy birthday to me. It was a sweet gesture from the restaurant to include the other guests.
author: Tuuyen N.

description:
Kusakabe definitely delivers a fine dining experience. Just the quality of the food and service should automatically give this place more than 5 stars. Reservations must be made in advance and I believe there are 2 seatings - one at 5 and another at 8. I made my reservation months in advance.  This place is very small and a little hidden but has a cute entrance through a curtain. The inside had a very nice ambiance going on and was very intimate. There was bar seating and a few table seating on the side but I suggest you choose the bar seating (or hopefully you get lucky enough to get bar seating) because you get the watch the sushi chefs make your omakase and have them explain each and every piece to you.

Their omakase menu changes from time to time but their dinner is priced at either $95pp or $150 pp for their grand omakase. I say you should get the grand omakase because it's so much more worth it if you're already going to spend $$$$ - might as well go all out! I also recommend that you try both the a5 wagyu and the toro... AND the UNI!! I can tell you that their uni here is to die for!! Specifically their deep sea hokkaido uni - it literally melts in your mouth and taste like heaven for a few seconds. (It is also their most expensive item on their ala carte menu) everything on their menu was just mouthwatering.

The service here is incomparable to other places - they treat you like a king and queen from seating you and even putting your coats on. They are also quick to refill your drinks/clean your tables and all other manners they are quick to address. Please do make some time if you come to the later seating. We sat down at 8pm and probably did not leave the restaurant till 11pm. Also if it's your birthday - tell them in advance!  They will comp you a item from their dessert menu. :)
author: Sherry L.

description:
3.5. I've had many sushi places in the city and this place is a like or dislike place. Some people love it some people were just meh. 

I do recommend the sake pairing (if you're up for it) and I think some of the food in the menu is good. Definitely book ahead though because it's hard to get a place here.

The place was sort of loud, and definitely (GET THE BAR) because the if you're in the tables, the sushi has travel time from the chef to you and it tastes different.

The rice is on the dryer side so I'm not big of a fan on that part.

Overall 3.5 for me.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Wow the food here is amazing!! Everything is well thought out and I literally disliked NOTHING. All of the dishes were unique and crafted so nicely.

I celebrated Valentine's day here with my boyfriend and we went all out and ordered the grand omakase. The omakase started out with a bang. First, we got the chu toro... It was the best I've had. Then... A really soft textured jellyfish unlike any I've had before topped with uni. It was delicious. A few seared items came next, the golden eye... We even had our nigiri topped with crystallized egg yolk. One of our boxed presentations had eels that tasted like noodles and toro in croquette form! The bafun uni was one of my favorite uni... We ended the omakase a bit differently, as one of our options. I ordered toro to end my meal... My boyfriend ordered the a5 Miyazaki wagyu beef. Although his last choice was good I preferred the lighter taste of fish. 

The chef's were a lot of fun to talk to as well. I had a great time here. Would definitely recommend :)
author: Lyra C.

description: Definitely one of the best omakase places in SF. There are two menu options: petit omakase ($98 for 8 courses) or omakase ($168 for 11). The biggest difference is the wagyu dish. We chose the omakase. While there are technically 11 courses, some come with multiple pieces of sushi or bites of food. Overall, I was very happy with the quality and preparation of food. It is comparable to some of the best places I've been in NYC. My only complaint is that for $168, it should have included dessert. We got the yuzu shiso leaf sorbet which was light and refreshing but feel it should have been included. My husband's favorite course was the wagyu; mine was the scallop
author: Musetta S.

description:
What can I say about Kusakabe that hasn't already been said before? Nonetheless, I want to share my thoughts on my experience on one of the best meals I've had.

With a part of three, we made reservations a couple months in advanced to sit at the bar for the full omakase experience. Doors don't open until exactly 5:00PM. Through the curtains is a narrow hall and doorway. Upon entering, the host will ask for your reservation and you will be seated in your designated spots. The space is narrow, with not very many seats, hence the limited reservations each night and it usually doesn't get too loud. 

You'll get a chance to look over their two menus: the first for omakase ($95 or $150) and the other for drinks. We opted for the $95 and some sake, of course. They started us off with some dashi broth, which was really nice on a cold, rainy evening. Then came the sushi. While there are chopsticks provided, we used our fingers for the most part. There's a bit of cloth for you to wipe your fingers on between pieces and some food items are much easier to handle with chopsticks, so there's no pressure. Each piece of sushi was so special and the taste so unique. The Zuke Toro was the most unforgettable one, so much that later on, we ordered another round a la carte. Super excited that there was some uni involved as well. Chef's assorted Les petit plats was just so pretty to look at and even better to eat.  We finished off with some tea and creme brulee. 

Our Chef Matt was very willing to answer our questions about sushi, the restaurant, his experience as a chef, etc. and interacted with us. Definitely added to our experience and understanding of what we were eating, so I would recommend sitting at the bar. 

If this is what heaven tastes like, just kill me now. Definitely worth every damn dollar and definitely will make a point to come often.
author: Monica V.

description: Best sushi I had in the Bay Area! The Omakase menu was enough to leave with a full stomach. All the red smoky fish were really good! There were two white sushi that were kind of a miss but at that point I was already blown away so I didn't really care. Excellent service and I loved everything about this place!
author: Jennifer K.

description: My boyfriend and I came here to celebrate our two-year anniversary and had the BEST omakase experience. I would say it was just as good as, if not better, than the sushi we had in Japan. Each piece of sushi takes you on a flavor journey that you wish could last longer than just the one bite! My personal favorite was the toro, but honestly every course was amazing. I ordered the Hokkaido scallop and A5 wagyu as a la carte options, and loved them as well. We ordered the yuzu sorbet for dessert which was tasty and super refreshing- I loved it! Also, they were so nice and comped it since it was our anniversary. I can never go back to eating mediocre sushi after dining at Kusakabe! It is quite pricy at $98/person (or $165/person for the grand omakase), so I would recommend coming for a special occasion!
author: Chloe Z.

description: I definitely feel that Kusakabe is totally hyped up...However, service was outstanding and food was cool...but why the 3 stars? I've been to numerous omakase's in the past, but I felt the food was just ok. We had the honor of sitting right in front of Chef Kusakabe himself. My boyfriend & I ordered the $98 omakase that included the 8 dishes. Every dish was executed in a very timely manner. The starter soup was very good & soothing especially for the cold SF weather. As for the nigiri, Kusakabe's style has more of a hickory smoked/ bonito flavor and the other dishes were beautifully presented to us...but after a while I felt like it tasted ehhhh...the ratio of the fish and the marinated rice tasted the same dish after dish....we ordered a few more items such as the organic lobster omelette and the Miyazaki wagyu....Wagyu was lightly salted and it was good...I felt like we could skip on the lobster omelette because we couldn't taste any lobster....despite my rating on the restaurant itself....everything else was impeccable! Tables, lighting, and fantastic service! We don't have an issue splurging on a meal...I expected a little more since I was blown away by Omakase on Townsend St.     :(    After $500 I expected a little bit more... Maybe I should give Kusakabe another chance to bump up my review.
author: Hang H.

description:
I made reservations online for my husband's birthday for 8 PM. On his actual birthday, the night that I made reservations for, the restaurant called me at 4 PM to tell me they had a scheduling error online and that I'd have to come in at 5 PM or try to do walk-in at 8 PM and see if they can accommodate me. I was super irritated. There was no way I could get off work on the peninsula and get to the city by 5 PM. The lady offered to cancel my reservation without charging me a penalty fee. It was THEIR error!! I had to scramble to make birthday reservations elsewhere. I was not a happy camper. Blahhhhhh!!

Fast forward a month later, we made reservations again and it worked out. We got the regular Omakase and it was absolutely amazing. The staff was completely attentive and accommodating. The best way to forgiveness is through the deliverance of an amazing meal! I look forward to coming back for the grand Omakase someday.
author: Mee V.

description: Came here with my family on a Father's Day. Ordered Omakase Petite. It was excellent. The dishes were beautiful and tasty.
author: Y C.

description:
4.5 stars. My friend and I came here last night for the 8:00 p.m. seating and got the Grand Omakase menu for $165. The sushi was probably some of the best sushi I have ever had in my life. The fish was really the star and all the additions added did not overwhelm what you are ultimately here for, which is the fish. Kusakabe did a brilliant job of elevating high-quality fish through the use of umami soy sauce, shiso leaves, yuzu etc. These ingredients brought out the flavor of the fish and gave it something extra.

The stars for me was the Kegani which was Hokkaido crab with quail egg (this is usually served with shrimp but since I don't like shrimp, they substituted with crab), Hotate (Hokkaido scallop topped with uni) and Zuke Chutoro (bluefin tuna).

Dishes that I was not too crazy about were les petit plats and the wagyu rib cap (tasted too fatty and oily...yes, I like marbled meats but this was too much). The Miyazaki wagyu they served later nigiri-style was much better in my opinion. 

We definitely felt full afterwards and felt that we had a very enjoyable and special experience. We have both lived in Japan and been to various kaiseki/omakase places and we agreed that this was pretty top-notch.
author: Joan S.

description:
Came here with my family with a reservation we luckily got day of! 

The interior has a classic clean Japanese look with light wood panels. It's has a classy but relaxed vibe and I didn't feel like you needed to dress up formally. Mostly small tables so good for groups from 2 to 6 at most.

We all had the $100 regular omakase and it was amazing! Definitely the best sushi I've had so far in San Francisco and it was better than many ones that I've had in New York at the same price point. Most importantly, the sushi is very fresh. The seasoning and garnish is just enough that there's a unique taste but it doesn't break from the traditional clean Japanese style of preparing sushi. However, the Hassun is a showcase of how innovative Kusakabe can be.

The staff is also super nice and helpful in making recommendations, accommodating food preferences and explaining the different dishes that come out that you may have never seen before.

Even with the hefty price tag, I thought the experience was 100p worth it. Would definitely come back here again at any opportunity if I was to spend $100 at a restaurant.
author: Kyle R.

description:
I love trying Kaiseki style restaurants because that way, you can have a variety and try a little of everything! :) We made reservations and I recommend making them at the bar so that way, they serve each nigiri to you one at a time and so you can also chat with the chef! There is street parking and some pretty cheap parking garages close by. We sat in front of Chef Ken and had an amazing time. 

For drinks, we started off with the sake flight ($50) and some Koshihikari Echigo beer ($9), which I really enjoyed - I've never tried it before and I've never seen it in any Japanese restaurants I've been to. We decided on the Grand Omakase ($150 per person), it comes with 25 items. They start off by asking if you have any allergies and what your favorite type of sushi is, then you start your dinner! 

You wipe your hands with the towel they provide and the chef explains that you eat the nigiri with your fingers and they seasoned it already so there's no soy sauce. You use chopsticks for everything else. It's really fun because they explain what they're serving you each time and they wait until you're done before they serve the next item.

I won't go into too much depth because their menu changes a little every night depending on what is fresh. I tried so many different things and even though we were served some sushi that I'm not usually a fan of, I decided to try it anyways and it was worth it because everything is so fresh and tasty. 

At the end, if you choose the Grand Omakase, you get to choose between toro or wagyu. I decided on the toro and then decided to try the wagyu from the a la carte menu afterwards. I HIGHLY recommend trying the wagyu if you haven't tried it before! Don't get me wrong - I love toro and I always order it where ever I go, but only a few places have wagyu so I recommend giving it a try! I can't even describe the incredible taste... It was lightly salted, a little sweet, semi- seared...just amazing, trust me and give it a try!!

At the end, we had Daiginjo Sake Kasu creme brulee for dessert paired with some dessert wine, Sauternes Chateau Laribotte, Bordeaux, France 2009, which was so delicious and a great way to finish off the night. 

This restaurant can be pricey depending on what you order (if you choose to order a la carte, drinks, etc.), but the regular Omakase menu is $99 and you can always order a la carte if they don't serve you an item you want to try! Our total for 3 people was about $730, including tax & tip. Overall, I highly recommend because of the fresh food and excellent service. I'll be back!
author: Letty H.

description:
We were fortunate to enjoy a decadent dinner prepared by Chef Kusakabe a few days ago. Very good experience, from the chefs greeting everyone to the personalized touches such as the favorite fish and the birthday ice cream. 

I photographed a few of the servings. I wish I had gotten a good pic of the pretty combination dish. I'll just have to go back :P.
author: Paulina F.

description:
A friend had recommended KUSAKABE to celebrate a special occasion. My bf decided to take me here for my birthday. 

They have 2 omakase menu choices. The regular omakase menu starts at $95pp for 19 items and the grand omakase menu is priced at $150pp for 25 items. We had original opted for the the regular omakase menu since I get full fast but after the first piece we were served, my bf quickly changed his mind an wanted us to upgrade to the grand omakase menu. It was so worth it.

I was full but I wasn't so stuffed that I couldn't keep eating more. The entire dining time was about 2 hours or a bit more. Each course was presented beautifully and timed perfectly. They also offer an a la carte menu for after if you find yourself still hungry. Since the finale is a choice of either Toro or A5 Wagyu, my bf order a la carte the one that we didn't select for our finale. Both are priced at $12.50 each for a piece.

Everything was so delicious. Before you get started, the chef will ask you if there's any type of fish that's your favorite or what you don't like so they can avoid serving you something that you wouldn't want to eat. 

There was just so many pieces that I don't even remember the names of each, sadly. So I can't pinpoint a favorite but each item was to die for.

I highly recommend for anyone who loves sushi and is looking for a place to celebrate a special occasion to make reservations for KUSAKABE.
author: Lena V.

description:
This is my all time favorite fancy sushi spot compared to all the other ones I've been to (Maruya, Wako, Kiss Seafood, etc) which makes sense because I used to go to Sushi Ran all the time back when Kusakabe was still the chef there and Sushi Ran was my ALL TIME fave. 

Came here with my cousin and we got a seat at the bar. You can make a request but they don't really promise you a seat at the bar/table I think. We did the grand tasting which I would NOT recommend because we were both ready to vomit by the end of the meal and we were so uncomfortable. Its an absurd amount of food and for $70 more than the regular omakase, you could just order whatever you wanted off the a la carte menu instead and it would be cheaper and you'd get what you actually wanted. 

We shared a bottle of sake which was plenty especially considering how full we were after all the food, If we got the sake pairing we never would've made it out of there alive. The service was not that great actually compared to Sushi Ran but it wasn't bad either. Just very whatever and aloof but the guy at the sushi bar was super friendly and nice. 

I think it was around $500 for the two of us. mmm delicious.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
I did the $98 omakase menu and I found it worth it. However with what I saw around me, I wouldn't have thought the $165 is worth it.
We started with the soup, and had a piece of chutoro, medium fatty tuna. The sashimi and the non sushi courses weren't too memorable. We definitely ended with a bang. The second to last piece was scallop uni, followed by otoro. My favorite sushi is always uni but that scallop was so sweet I didn't even taste the uni. Wow. On their menu they had 3 types of Hokkaido uni, so we asked our chef which one was on the scallop, and that we each ordered the 2 other to try. One of them, bafun uni, BLEW. MY. MIND. We ordered another round lol All in all, great experience, good service. If you know what you like, go with the omakase and get extra pieces at the end. If not, the grand omakase works too. 
Side note, all the chefs and everyone behind the sushi bar is relatively young, ranging from 25-35? Not to say they are not skilled, but I'd prefer an older chef for a more expensive menu.
Side side note, our chef was very very cute, which added to our experience =)
author: Crystal Y.

description: A simply incredible and divine culinary adventure of extremely creative Japanese delicacy. You're truly lucky if you get to experience Chef KUSAKABE and his extreme attention to umami, texture and insanely creatively perfect combinations. Eat slow. Savor every bite.
author: Ajay N.

description:
Instead of going to our Company holiday dinner this year, Lily T. & I decided to skip that and go here instead. It took us 1.5 months to find a decent reservation and the wait was so worth it. This restaurant is amazing- definitely worth the Michelin star. Reservations are super competitive though, so don't expect to last minute plan it but keep hopes!

We had the opportunity to seat right in front of Chef Kusakabe which was amazing because he explained every little detail about each fish and we saw all the finishing touch. Lily T. & I opted in for the $150 grand omakase which included 25 items. Each piece of nigiri was a die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and also added with some citrus and wasabi depending on the nigiri. I love for a fact the Chef also asks you if you're allergic to anything and if you had any favorite fish so they can do a little remix. 

Metered street parking was easily found before 6 pm. The nearest garage is 2 blocks away at the Embarcadero Garage ($3/hour after 5 pm).

Some of our highlights were:
Fatty Tuna
Uni from the North
Golden Eye Snapper
Japanese Squid with Uni
& the sushi finale: toro & A5 Wagyu beef. (OMG, melt in your mouth....) 

Nice interior, excellent food, and above & beyond customer service. Not once did I need to flag down a waiter down for tea. Everyone had a smile on their face.  Major props! Kusakabe was my first Michelin star restaurant and I definitely felt the "VIP" treatment.

Thanks, Kusakabe! I'll be back.
author: Danny L.

description:
Very rare I disagree with a yelp 4.5 star rating, but I'm totally confused by this one.  We were a party of four with two from Southern California and two from Hong Kong so very familiar paying a premium for high quality sushi, but everyone was left perplexed.  Before knowing the price (friend and I were trading meals), I thought it was a solid 3 to 4 star meal as there were some highlights, but also low lights, but then when I learned it was over $800 per couple (including sake pairing) then it became one of the most overpriced meals of my life.  As mentioned, some courses really shined, though they use sauces or smoking that overpower the fish rather than letting the product truly shine.  Also, the wagyu was some of the most stringy fatty rather than marbled I've ever had.  Overall, very disappointing meal and have had way better for significantly less to boot.

PS - Who has ever heard of a 4 ounce wine pour?!  My wife was one of three around us who made the same complaint after receiving a glass.  Talk about nickle and diming.
author: Matthew C.

description:
5 star all the way.

Anybody who ranks it lower is not talking about the food. World class sushi, sashimi and kaiseki. 

If you are a sushi rookie, go get yer Philly rolls somewhere else. If you can appreciate unique and fabulous- Kusakabe will deliver.
author: Jeff S.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to come here to celebrate his early birthday and our anniversary because we both love sushi. We never had an omakase experience before so we were very excited to try it out. Made reservations online and thankfully they had it on the day we wanted to go. 

Our reservations wasn't until 8:15 but when we got there at 8, they seated us right away at the bar. We ordered the regular omakase thinking that we can just add more at the end if we're still hungry. We ended up being super full and only ordered 1 extra each. I had the A5 Wagyu at the end and my boyfriend had the Kaisui uni and both were very delicious. At the end, they gave us a yuzu dessert to celebrate our anniversary and that was very thoughtful of them. 

Definitely a great experience and the fish were fresh and delish! I had a great time and enjoyed everything that was served. I personally never liked oysters, so I was scared to try the Japanese raw oyster, but it was so good and ended up being one of my favorites. Definitely recommended and will be coming back!
author: Janice L.

description: Underwhelming Omakase with a weird pricing structure. While not bad food, at this level and with the competition in the SF sushi/Omakase scene, I expect more.
author: Ofer G.

description: Kusakabe is the Bentley of sushi in San Francisco - the high end of the high end. They serve you multiple course dinner that is based on the principle of Japanese "Kaiseki" cuisine (so this is not the place to go to grab a quick California roll). Expensive, but worth every penny.
author: Drew S.

description: Highly recommended.  Very unique Kyoto (kaiseki) style approach.  The sake sommelier is fantastic and the sake pairing worth the price of admission (expensive).  As you know, a five star sushi review from spoiled me is a big deal!
author: Jefery L.

description:
Hands down top 2 omakase spots I've ever had.
Did the sake pairing and I would definitely recommend if you are into Sake.  

All the dishes were fantastic:
- intro dish was amazing.  The halibut with liver was out of this world.
- Jellyfish was wow.
- Scallop with Uni was the best scallop I ever had.
- Bonito was the best I ever had.
- After the 11 course omakase, I ordered a few of the favorites to enjoy even more

- Didn't get to try their sweet shrimp, maybe next time.

Truly an experience.  I will try to get a bar seat next time.
author: Electric E.

description:
Delicious! My bf took me here for my birthday with a reservation, and we both loved every item from the preset omakase menu. Each piece was crafted with care and precision right in front of us

We were served one and by one with a brief explanation before we ate. I loved everything. In total, we had 20+ pieces each. 

Service was excellent. The chefs were talkative and friendly. They even provided a birthday dessert with a candle and sang. 

Location wise, parking is probably hard. We took uber, and we'd definitely come again if the occasion calls for it.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Before I start - definitely sit at the bar. It's such a delight to watch everything being prepared.

I went to Kusakabe with the boyfriend a few weeks ago for an anniversary dinner and it was just fantastic. It was the first time either of us had omakase and went with the Grand Omakase menu. Definitely come with an empty stomach because we were just STUFFED by the end of it.

We were seated at the sushi bar and our chef asked us for any favorites/dislikes/allergies. We personally didn't have any dislikes, but one person seated next to us apparently didn't like uni, and the chef was mindful of that through the entire meal and substituted other fish for her.

Every piece of fish is thoughtfully prepared and oh so tender. It's awesome to hear about each piece, what fish it is, and what preparation had gone into it.

The only thing that I was a little less impressed with was the A5 Wagyu beef with a poached egg; it came out on a hot, mini-cast iron skillet, and had a sauce poured over that was supposed to sizzle and help cook the meat. Unfortunately, we were the last of three couples who were being served at the same time and our skillets had cooled down where it barely sizzled and all the ingredients were a little more under cooked than I think it was intended to be. It was still pretty tasty and honestly a fairly minor thing.

If you're looking to step up your sushi game, I highly recommend it. It is 300% for sure worth the higher price tag and I'm already trying to think of the next special occasion to have an excuse to go back.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Best of that I've had in years! There's no point in me repeating what others have written. The omakase meal was (we didn't go with the grand 11 course one) was delicious. The fish was fresh and prepared like art. Definitely a fine dining experience. Will go back soon.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Love this place! Got 17 dishes and was totally full in the end. The sushi here is very good, the desserts also surprised me. I would recommend this place to my friends and will definitely come again.
author: Fang Q.

description:
$165 for grand omakase

Taste: 4 stars
Creativity: 3 stars
Staff: 3 stars
Environment: 2 stars

Value paid ($500 for 2 people) vs 
Overall Experience: 3 stars 

Likeliness of returning: Low

First time visiting Kusakabe. For a "kaiseki" styled sushi I was expecting much more creativity with the plating, flavor creativities, and texture creativities. Other than the Hassun (6 mini platere) I wouldn't call the rest "kaiseki". If kaiseki is the value customers are paying then Kusakabe needs more creativity on the flavors and efforts on the presentation. Sequencing is also important. Avoid soup / noodles in the middle of the menu; it is really filling after all the rice from sushi, difficult to enjoy the rest of the dishes if you get too full... The taste was good overall, thus the 4 stars. However, hamo/eel had a small bone that pierced through my gum when I bit into it. Restaurant waived my dessert as an apology.

There was a big turn off for me very early on... as soon as I got seated, there was a small fly flying around. Landed on my water cup, on the table, even the cutting board! (the chef turned around to work on other plates - it had since flown off, so he didn't see it landed there, so the next thing I know was pieces of sushi being placed on the same board where fly landed). 

My chef was very friendly, 5 stars for him. I gave the staff overall 3 stars because I kept on having to dodge the server for water refills. Ideally, he could've waited until the water was at least half way down, or find a gap and ask if we'd like the water refilled. I almost hit his arm once or twice because I wasn't expecting an arm to come in between to refill the water when it was at a 60-70% level. Nice/friendly server, though lesser refills would be great. 

Prior to this, we had been to Wakuriya and sushi Kashiba, had really high expectations coming into Kusakabe, maybe bit too high on my end. My fiancee enjoyed it at Kusakabe quite a bit, mine was so so. For fine dining, experience matters. How much attention to detail matters, reaction of customer (case of frequent water refill) and environment (fly) really matter. Food can be good, chef and server can be friendly, it only takes a bit to ruin the 5 star experience. Perhaps my review may be on the harsher end, I definitely had very high expectations after all the good reviews. Customers want to make sure the cost is equals to the value expected. I hope Kusakabe continues to improve. Who knows, maybe I might just come in on a wrong day? Maybe I should give it one more try?

Thank you chefs, staff.
author: Sonya M.

description:
Le bf and I used to love coming to Kusakabe. Our first experience was for my birthday. It was our first time eating omakase. Boy was it a special experience. We interacted a lot with the chef in front of us as we sat at the bar (the only proper way to experience omakase). 5 stars all way. That experience was when they still had their Michelin star. The food was phenomenal 

Our next experience was after they lost their Michelin star. We still liked the place, the food was still good, but the service, not so much. We also didn't get seated at the bar, even though we had requested it. We were told that because we sat at the bar last time, we couldn't sit at it this time. We were promised that if we came back, we would be guaranteed bar seating. I don't think there will be a next time. 

In general, the omakase experience is completely different when you sit at the table. You should get a discount if you sit at a table. 

In short, there are way better omakase places in SF for around the same price. I won't be back for the opportunity to sit at the bar. You blew it, Kusakabe. I won't be back for the terrible service.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Very expensive but what a fantastic meal!
So nice
Not surprising that they have two Guide Michelin stars
author: Pellson B.

description:
After many months of long wait, had an absolutely phenomenal omakase experience at Kusakabe! Came with a group of seven on a Saturday night with a reservation made a few months in advance. We arrived for the 5pm seating and received a very friendly welcome from the staff as we entered through the door.
 
We ordered the $98 regular omakase, which was a fantastic, well-decorated, seven course meal. Every item was unique and delicious - prepared extremely carefully by the wonderful chefs. Some of the highlights of the meal: amberjack sashimi (very meaty), raw oyster and caviar (extremely fresh), akadashi soup with duck and soy cream foam (savory, rich broth and duck flavor), and the toro (phenomenally fatty and fresh). The servers were friendly and very detailed in describing each of the items in the courses.
 
After the omakase, they present an a-la-carte menu so that you can order additional pieces of nigiri. Hearing very positive reviews about their A5 Miyazaki Wagyu nigiri and after tasting fantastic Kobe beef in Japan, definitely knew I had to try a piece. My expectations were high and the Wagyu nigiri blew past them with ease. The beef was super marbley and tender, and the umami and fatty juices just burst in my mouth with every bite. This is definitely my recommended must-try, extremely worth the $14 for the piece.
 
Afterwards, we ordered a couple desserts to share. We started with the yuzu and shiso leaf sorbet, which was very refreshing and tangy. Next we had their kome koji (ingredient used to make sake) ice cream, which was very unique, although unsweetened. Finally, we tried their daiginjo sake kasu creme brulee - also great, very rich and sweet creme brulee with a bit of sake kick. Very great to share with a group.
 
The bill came out to be about $115 per person pre-tax/tips. For the high quality of the food, and the very attentive and friendly staff, definitely felt the price was worth the unforgettable 3-hour experience I had at Kusakabe. Big 5 stars, highly recommend a try for sushi lovers!
author: Alvin W.

description:
I have not had this good sushi for a long time, since two years ago when I dine at Sushi Immamura (1 michelin star) in Tokyo.

The restaurant is quite spacious, seating around 25 people (around 10 people on the sushi bar and 15 people on the table), and the atmosphere is relaxed. The chef who took care of us, Ken, is very friendly and he explained every course carefully. 

The sushi is not traditional, as the chef Kusakabe explained, sushi in Keiseki style. He created the dishes with his own signatures and they are very refreshing. 

The service is great. The waiter are all very polite and friendly. 

Highly recommended.
author: Thanapat W.

description:
One of the most amazing dining experience ever! I must say I was impressed. I booked a month in advance for my mom's birthday dinner, we sat at the bar and Chef Kusakabe was the one serving us (super awesome!). 

We ordered the Grand Omakese and I highly recommend getting that one since there is more to try (25 items). Chef Kusakabe asked us what kind of fishes or nigiri that we like and he will customize it with the meal. Each nigiri was mouth watering, fresh and tasted very authentic with it's own style. I honestly couldn't think of ONE thing I DIDN'T like at all. If I had to chose my most favorite was the scallops topped with uni nigiri and A5 wagyu beef nigiri. We also ordered a dessert at the end and got the creme brûlée, OMG it was so good. All desserts are homemade and the creme brûlée was so unique, it had a hint of sake flavor. The whole restaurant and the chef sang happy birthday to my mom, it was very thoughtful and sweet :) They also told me at the end that the dessert was on the house! :D

Thank you so much Kusakabe for making my mom's birthday so special and memorable! We definitely will be coming back again!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Got here about 10-15 minutes before our reservation at 8:15pm on a Friday (made a month in advance). They were able to seat us promptly even though we were early.
We sat at the table right next to the door partition. It was a smallish place, so it was a bit tight for the servers to get past me. I felt bad since I didn't realize this until we left. They were all nice enough not to say anything! 

They had two choices: the regular omakase (8 courses) or the grand omakase (11 courses). We opted for the regular $98 omakase menu. After we ordered, they gave us the dashi broth, along with warm towels and other eating utensils. We had more than one server bring us our food, and each one explained what they had placed on the table. I got too excited when they brought the sushi out so I didn't get to take pictures of the first sushi course. It was a piece of cured bluefin chutoro sushi that had a wonderful smoky flavor, paired with a piece of fresh fish served as is (not cured, marinated, etc.). You have one piece that was heavily flavored with soy sauce contrasting with another that was light and fresh, no frills. It was a very thoughtful pairing that not only didn't overwhelm my palate, but brought out the flavor of each piece of sushi. This theme continued throughout the meal with the sushi plates. 

Eventually, after a few rounds of sushi and sashimi, they brought out the Hassun, which consisted of 6 tiny dishes, and was the most beautifully plated out of all the courses. I loved that you got a tiny bite of everything, rather than one entree. I won't go over everything, but wasn't blown away by the taste of the overall dish. I'm sure people who love clams would like the cold clam soup. I felt like it really brought out the flavor of the clams. I didn't particularly like it, but that's because I'm not a huge fan of clams. There was a lightly fried shrimp and taro, like shrimp and taro karage. Tasted like what you would expect. It also came with something that tasted like wagyu croquette, covered in crispy rice. It was quite small, so it was difficult to taste the wagyu. 

We ended the meal with more fresh and melt-in-your-mouth sushi: a fun and delicious DIY hand roll served with scallop sushi topped with uni. They brought out an add-ons menu if we wanted to order anything a la carte. We were pretty satisfied, so we didn't add get anything else. After that, they came out with what I think was a yuzu sorbet, with a candle, on the house! I had forgot that they called ahead about a week before to ask if we were coming for any special reason. I had mentioned to them on the phone that it was my boyfriend's birthday. It was a nice surprise. The sorbet itself had a nice citrusy flavor, and came in a really cute little tea cup. 

In general, I really liked the quality of the sushi and sashimi, along with the their flavors and the little additions and sauces served with them. This was the main reason fo coming here. There warm dishes and soups weren't bad, but they definitely weren't the stars of the show. The servers were also all really nice and professional.
author: Christine L.

description:
This place is truly an experience! Get the grand omakase, your wallet will hurt after but it will be worth every penny :)

Favs from the omakase were the uni, kobe, and otoro. Service and vibe is on point as well.
author: Michelle N.

description:
After trying many different places, Kusakabe is my favorite Omakase restaurant in San Francisco. I've been to Kusakabe twice now, first time because Ino Sushi had just retired, second time to celebrate our wedding anniversary. 

Both times we ordered the $95 menu and everything was fantastic. Kusakabe is not for those looking to get super traditional food. Instead, they provide you with extremely fresh fish that is paired with little additions that make each bite a whole new (and special) experience. For me, the food included in the menu is not enough and always need to order 2 or 3 more portions so wish they provided a bit more food but I guess that's what makes this menu less than $100.

Highly recommended!
author: Nuno S.

description: This is my best high end sushi experience ever. All flavors burst in my mouth at the same time. This is the moment you know exactly the difference between good sushi and ordinary ones. My husband and I both chose the 11 course dinner, and we were so full. Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Lingnan C.

description:
Came here for a special celebration dinner and made reservations a month or so in advance. Make sure to request bar seating (I called in closer to the date of the reservation to confirm) for a better experience.

The Omakase menu price is very reasonable - $95 per person - and we (surprisingly) did not leave the restaurant starving (although I could have probably stuffed a couple more pieces of sashimi down my throat if I wanted... but that's what the a la carte menu is for). The menu has 8 line items and our sushi chef asked us what kind of fish we liked and catered some things to us for some of the later dishes. The whole menu is pretty set, but for the last item we had a choice between toro bluefin fatty tuna or grade a5 miyazaki wagyu beef - you really can't go wrong with either. Since there was two of us we got one of each (:

Some of the things on the menu strayed away from a traditional Japanese omakase menu - for example the bone marrow gelatin and a lamb croquette bite. I thought it was creative and added variety to an otherwise standard Japanese tasting menu, but if you're expecting something traditional like you would get in Japan, this might catch you off guard. 

Overall a really great experience, but the meal as a whole didn't really blow my mind. If you want to go all out for a Japanese dinner I would recommend Omakase over Kusakabe, or at least go to Kusakabe first to temper your expectations.
author: Megan K.

description: It was our first time at Kusakabe and it did not disappoint. The clientele was made up of 95% Asians. The Omakase was creative and very tasty. The sashimi with umami soy sauce, the blue fin fatty tuna and the oysters in the petit plat were intensely delicious. We were looking for more of an Asian dessert and they only had "fusion" kind so we were slightly disappointed.
author: Tina C.

description:
I have always loved Japanese food for its delicate and umami flavors. The level of detail and care put into all Japanese dishes has always astounded me. I am a huge fan of donburis, udon noodles, and of course, sushi. However, a couple of months ago, I had a totally new, mind-blowing, and quite frankly, life-changing culinary experience with Japanese cuisine. For my birthday, my friend took me out for omakase style sushi in San Francisco. The term "omakase" is a Japanese phrase that means "I'll leave it up to you(the chef)." The whole sushi meal is decided by the chef, and is tailored towards which fishes are in season at the time, and whatever flavors the chef wants to present that night, so it is a meal you should go into with zero expectations. 

We went to KUSAKABE, a 1-Michelin starred omakase restaurant placed in the heart of San Francisco, California's financial district. This meal consisted of 15-20 different types of nigiri, or slices of raw fish/meat over rice. We were seated at a simple, wooden bar, and were assigned 1 chef for the entire night to take us through the omakase experience. Every piece was placed in front of us, one at a time, after we had finished each previous piece. Everything was extremely simple and clean, but it was some of the most fresh and most melt-in-my-mouth sushi experiences I had ever had. I practically melted along with each piece of sushi in my mouth. 

Priced at $165 per person for the "Grand Omakase" dinner, you better bet you're going to get a mind-blowing food experience. I can go on and on for hours about each piece of sushi I had that night, but I will just point out some of my highlights:

- One of the most memorable and unique pieces was the Tsukiji fish market squid nigiri with crystallized egg yolk and a single yuzu leaf. It was almost "rubbery" in texture but extremely smooth and silky, the egg provided a creamy accent, and the yuzu was a pop of fresh lemon taste. This single bite was the most unique, and most harmonious pieces of food I have ever eaten. 

- The next piece that truly stood out to me was the A5 wagyu beef nigiri. It was a raw piece of A5 wagyu beef placed on top of rice, and torched so it was seared on top, yet perfectly rare in the middle. A5 is the highest possible grade of beef, and it was marvelous and extremely "meaty" tasting. I had never had beef that was so fatty, pure, and clean tasting before, and I'm not sure how many more times in my life I'll be able to have beef that good. My jaw physically dropped after this one. 

KUSAKABE provided a life-changing Japanese food experience and I hope that everyone has the opportunity to try omakase sushi at least once in their lives, especially if they love sushi and Japanese culture. Even if you don't love or know much about Japanese culture, though, this would be a great introduction. If anyone ever wants to learn more about omakase too, and the history of it, I would highly recommend watching the documentary "Jiro Dreams of Sushi," which is about a famous sushi chef in Japan whose restaurant takes reservations 1 year in advanced because it is so well-known for its omakase. I hope to try different omakase restaurants in my life when I am older and have more money to do so. But for now, I will just fondly remember and dream of this KUSAKABE experience
author: Alana L.

description:
I rarely go out to eat dinner (especially since I work 7 days a week between 2 jobs) and it's even rarer for me to write a review. But I must say this was a very pleasant experience for me. 

The food was excellent and I loved how observant the staff was (especially when they noticed that I was getting full near the end and I was passing my food to my guest since they can eat more than I can but I don't eat much to begin with). We had ordered the Grand Omakase and everything looked  and tasted good. There was a very minor incident but they were very accommodating and very friendly to work with us on correcting the issue. So I think this review is long overdue for their kindness. 

If I am able to time to eat out again, I would definitely want to bring my friends and family to experience this.
author: Kaitlin C.

description:
4.5 stars because I wasn't able to get bar seating, but rounded up. We were first on waitlist and got the call 2 days before that we had gotten seats, but no guarantees are bar seating. Since we actually came at our reservation time, we were seated at the table. Found out later that a party didn't show up, but those seats were given to a walk-in an hour later. I was pretty butthurt, but it's okay, meal was worth it and I would definitely go again just so I can sit front row.

We settled with the $95 omakase and intended to order some a la carte pieces afterwards. Everything was amazing, the service, the ambience, and especially the food. The atmosphere was warm and inviting, but also exclusive and refined at the same time. The lighting focused on the chefs and the food at our table. The service was amazing, explained each course with detail. Even brought out another beer free of charge because they had brought the wrong drink the first time. 

Highlights of my meal:
- Halibut with its own liver
- Scallop sashimi with the yuzu and garlic sauce: delicate and sweet, counterbalanced with the sauces
- Snap pea soup: different textures, the fried fish added crunch and the broth was so good.
- Wagyu beef: AMAZING, beautiful marbling
- Toro: my favorite of the night, it was melt-in-my-mouth deliciousness
- Kaisui Uni: deep ocean Hokkaido sea urchin was my 2nd favorite.. so creamy and sweet.
- Bafun Uni: Hokkaido short spine uni was firmer in texture, not as sweet, more ocean-y taste.

Overall, it was a delightful dining experience. Would have been amazing tenfold if we had bar seating, but all the more reason to come back.. Also, to get the Grand Omakase next time around. Definitely worth a pretty penny.
author: Vera N.

description: Was here to celebrate my son's birthday. Loved the ambiance and a nice atmosphere. Superb service and excellent food Kaiseki style.
author: Julia I.

description:
In an ideal world, I would like to have a well-orchestrated sushi omakase dinner on the regular for the following reasons.
- Raw fish is delicious.
- When a chef knows what s/he is doing, I'm more than happy to have the chef execute their well-thought out prix fixe menu.
- I don't have to order. Ordering is not my forte, as I am indecisive by nature. 

Needless to say, Kusakabe does an excellent kaiseki.
Reservations here are highly recommended, and require a credit card to reserve. They are only open Mon- Sat, with 2 dinner seatings a night (5pm & 8pm) and a capacity of 29 guests. 
The cancellation policy is very strict. 
- Cancellations w/in 48 hrs result in a charge of $30 per person.
- Cancellations on the same day or no shows result in a charge of $95 per person.
I have to admit I was glad that they do not accommodate children under age 5. Apparently the venue is not large enough for strollers and high chairs, but we all know that a crying infant or hyperactive toddler could ruin any dining experience. 

Mr. Joy and I were a few minutes late for our reservation, but they were very nice about it. They hold reservations for latecomers for 15 minutes. Our empty seats and place settings were waiting for us when we arrived. The dining area consists of a very long sushi bar and a couple of tables by the door. Our sushi chef explained that the restaurant design deliberately omitted the glass fish case so the patrons can easily see the chefs prepare food. The tables are also deliberately the same height, so even people who do not sit at the sushi bar can get a good view of the sushi chefs. So thoughtful.

Our server asked us the usual 'Do you have any food allergies?' We replied 'No.' She also asked if we eat raw foods, and we confirmed we do. I'm sure that is part of their protocol to double-check everything, but it would be a pity if someone who does not like raw food made a reservation here and wasted a seat.

You can choose between the Omakase ($95) or the Grand Omakase ($195). They are very similar, but the Grand Omakase is more robust in volume. Both end with toro & A5 wagyu.  Everything was presented beautifully and seasoned excellently. There is no soy sauce or wasabi, so that's one less thing to think about. Most people eat the sushi with their hands, as is the traditional way, but they do provide chopsticks too.

Of course I enjoyed the buttery toro (fatty tuna). The wagyu had beautiful marbling. The zuke chutoro (medium fatty tuna) was also excellent with a light sear on top. All the accompanying flavoring agents were excellent. I especially enjoyed the yuzu onion sauce. The only thing I wasn't so fond of was the squid and mountain yam. Once your omakase has concluded, they offer you the a la carte menu of sashimi. Each order comes with one piece. 

Our chef was truly friendly, entertaining, and hilarious as he shared stories about being a sushi chef. When he brought out the blowtorch to sear the wagyu, I wanted to take a picture, but he was too quick for me. The couple next to us also wanted a picture, so Chef Ken turned on the blowtorch just so we could document the moment. When the chefs weren't busy preparing bites of perfection or entertaining guests, they were collaborating with each other. I was surprised to see three chefs working together to put together the presentation for one dessert. 
The food was very delicious with a very solid fish selection. What put it over the top for me was the amazing hospitality that made it a great experience.
author: Joy W.

description:
Food: 3 stars
Service: 4 stars

Took one of my bff's here for her b-day last night and while we were seated with the head chef, I had an overall OK experience (my friend had a great one). While some of the food was good, others were terrible, and none were particularity memorable. I'd like to give this place more stars for their service, but the length of time it took to bring out some of the courses was just unacceptable.

While the nigiri portion was good, nothing was O-M-G-I-NEED-MORE status. I also disliked how some of the sushi was drenched in ponzu. When it comes to omakase, pre-saucing is great, but I like the fish to speak for itself. My friend on the other hand, had the best experience of her life. RICE A+.

The fish from the sashimi portion of the omakase was good, but the fish was WAY too cold due to being served on a bed of shaved ice. It was really hard to enjoy the fish, though I could taste the freshness of it.

....................my least favorite part of the meal with the box of assorted small plates. I'm sad to say the oyster was EXTREMELY fishy and dry, and the squid was so ridiculously fishy I had to spit it out :( Everything else in this box was just whatever to say the least. They really need to think about omitting this filler of a course in their omakase menu. NO bueno.

Service upon arrival to the end of the meal was spectacular. BUTTTTTTTTT the length of time between each course was just outrageous. One gap took 22 minutes... 22 FREAKING MINUTES!!! The entire meal was inconsistent. I was not a happy camper :( I'd like to note that they gave us creme brulee on the house for my friends b-day, and the entire restaurant sang happy birthday to her :)

I really wanted to like this place, but I was unimpressed and underwhelmed. Needs a lot of work and tweaking of the menu IMO. If this is your first omakase experience, I think you'd love it. Don't get me wrong, the food was good and I appreciate the effort and art that goes into each course, but was still disappointed with a lot of minor things that just added up as the night went on.
author: Anna M.

description: Amazing sushi, great service, lovely experience. They only have one set menu, so you just sit back, relax and enjoy whatever they serve you. In addition to sushi and sashimi, they also serve other Japanese delicacies. I believe for the grand finale, you get to pick between a fatty tuna belly nigiri or a Japanese wagyu nigiri, both were heavenly! If you are still hungry after you finish the set menu, you may order from the a la carte menu. Everything was executed perfectly; the sushi rice was superb and the fishes were exceptional!
author: Sam M.

description: I'm in love. This is the closest experience to omakase (based off of food taste and quality and critical methodology to serving perfect dishes) I experienced in Japan, albeit bougier. The service as soon as you enter the door is impeccable. Our chef was Brandon and we were next to the couple being served by Chef Nori so we were able to hear some of his information as he served them. If you go, get the Omakase, unless you have a very small appetite I don't think the petite Omakase is enough! Also don't miss out on the wagyu tongue- hot damn. Every piece was worth it and savory. Our last piece of fatty tuna was decadent. A couple fun facts: they get fish deliveries daily, their rice is brown because they use red vinegar in their sushi rice (traditional method), and they make a point to know if you're celebrating something. I really felt that they hosted my husband and me very well. I also loved that their bathroom has a toto Japanese toilet seat. Don't get scared that the seat is warm lol. I do recommend the sorbet and tofu "tiramisu"- the sorbet is palette cleansing and the tofu tiramisu is just tasty without being overly sweet. I'm coming back soon!
author: Krizelda M.

description: Honestly this place is very expensive. I dont understand what sets this place apart from the $$ Japanese restaurants. I would probably not come back again, cannot afford it to be honest. Ignore my review if you have a lot of money to burn.
author: Lydia O.

description: As if they need another review from me to acknowledge their accomplishments in the world of culinary expert for tease as it pertains to sushi however I still must post because it was so fresh and delicious and we were treated like rock stars! Ask the chef to make what he felt like my favorite way to eat sushi and we had the most delicious selection of Ocean fresh unbelievable sushi. Cannot say enough good things about the quality of food for the experience:-)
author: Peonia E.

description:
If you want to go somewhere more intimate, Kusakabe is definitely not the place. It is a lot bigger than most places I have been too. Fully packed on the weekends and weekdays. I was told that their menu just changed!  Twice a year the menu changes so it's great to try something so fresh and recently created. 

Right away you notice how they have 3 times the more chefs at the bar than the normal 2/3. If I were you, request for the bar when you make reservations. I though this might be a drawback, but it wasn't!!  One thing I really like about Kusakabe is that they even make all the hot dishes/non-sushi dishes in the front!  It always make the experience better. Talk to the chefs. The head chef does stand at the front and the rest of the chefs follow. It's not ranked -- I asked. 

Typical pricing $95 for the normal omakase and $150 for the upgraded version.  

Same review: 
Kansan Sui - $40 dry and sweet. I asked for a little sweet, but it did come out a little sweeter than I like. Great first sake. Goes down smoothly like you are drinking water. 

Tedorigawa Kinka -$33. Dry and little sweet. I honestly like this better than Kansan.  Make your money's worth and try this out.

Ken - $53. Served in a wine glass so you can swish and see the colors. Taste more like sake. More dry less sweet. I would definitely rate this behind the tedorigawa. 


Omakase review: 
I honestly had high expectations from this place bc I have heard 'okay' reviews, but the ratings on Yelp were really high. I ended up trying the grand omakase which supposedly has higher grade fish/seafood. The sushi plates at the beginning were awesome!!! I would say that the sashimi dish was okay but definitely have to rave about the ankimo. Great quality...melt in mouth type of experience. The sashimi section came with 5 different sauces that are to compliment the sashimi pieces. I think that the sauces were creatively made and tasted very good. I believe the fish can stand on its own with a ponzu sauce, but this is definitely a different experience. After the sashimi dish, there was a soup that was AMAZING!!  it was mixed with vegetable purée and Agedashi soup base with some type of fish. Probably my favorite dish of the night. 

We finished off the course with more sashimi. There wasn't a cleansing palette dish afterwards. However I ordered the Yuzu sorbet which was nice and refreshing. 

Overall I had to rate the place 5/5. The service is great and the food was great. Based on my friends' previous reviews, I do believe that our menu was different from there's. I can't complain. I would definitely come back again and enjoy another experience at Kusakabe.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Surprised Erick T. with reservations back in October 2015 for his 27th birthday, and KUSAKABE has remained as one of my favorite omakase restaurants in the city since then. It was $95 pp, but I heard that they now offer a $150 prix fix menu. Definitely another reason why I need to come back. :']

It's a rather small restaurant (12-15 people), and I love how the majority of the seating is at the bar. My favorite! Lighting was also amazing, and the service was indeed Michelin star worthy.

Some of my favorites were the Zuke Chutoro, Ocean Trout, Striped Jack, Red Snapper, and A5 Wagyu. I especially loved the torched fish/A5 - the perfect amount of smokiness flavor and felt like it melted in my mouth like butter. What differentiated this restaurant from others was how the chef managed to mix the perfect amount and selection of oils/sauces to best emphasize the true taste of the fish. Some even had wasabi mixed in beforehand! Traditionally, you don't need to dip the fish in the soy sauce, and you're supposed to eat the nigiri with your hands (Erick T. actually did this). But... I ate most of my nigiri with chopsticks and dipped my fish in soy sauce anyway because I love soy sauce. I actually think the sushi chef got a bit offended when he saw me do this. Whoops, sorry! 

The one thing I actually really wished was not on the menu was the box of assorted small plates (oyster, squid, etc.) I have a very picky palette, and they were all honestly just too fishy for me. I ended up giving most of them to my boyfriend. Maybe it won't be on the menu when I come back?

Ordered sake pairings for the both of us ($75 pp), which I highly recommend! I thought their selection of sakes in comparison to that of other omakase restaurants was far more tasty and unique. But if you don't drink much, I suggest only ordering one tasting. Surprisingly, they pour you BIG shots/glasses, and I died halfway through my meal. Don't want to be stumbling out the door like I did. Our waitress was also able to answer all my questions about the choices of sake for each dish and was very informative. Thank you!

Overall, Erick T. and I were blown away by how delicious everything was for the price and how shockingly full we were! But who knows, maybe it was the sake that filled us up.
author: Christina L.

description:
My bf and I celebrated our anniversary at Kusakabe! I've had this bookmarked for quite some time, just never had a reason to go.

I was pleasantly surprised as I had no clue where we were going to celebrate! 

We ordered the grand omakase with two hot sakes. The grand omakase consisted of 25 pieces, displayed on 7 "dishes". The entire dining experience was amazing from the start to finish. We first started off with the Ichiban Dashi, a small soup. Next was the sushi prelude, then a sashimi plate, hassun (beautifully plated), soup with a cube of tofu with umami tamago - so goood, sushi chic and lastly the sushi finale which consisted of fresh white eel and your choice of either toro bluefin fatty tuna or A5 grade wagyu beef. 

After the omakase, there's an a la carte menu. My bf and I ordered 2 additional pieces each. One from the omakase earlier and a spoonful of uni. 

Although we were pretty satisfied, we wanted to end the meal with dessert! They over heard that we were celebrating our anniversary so they gave us all three desserts on the house. So sweet! Love it. 

Overall, I was pretty blown away and kudos to the services as well! Can't wait to be back :)
author: Jessica Z.

description: This place is good. The fish is fresh, the flavor is there. The problem is the service. If I'm paying a premium for service I expect good service. Unfortunately you get none of that here. The chef acts like you're a bothersome. The staff acts like they want you out. The food is good but when you're paying for omakase you're paying for an experience. The one here was terrible. Don't waste your money.
author: Charles G.

description:
Amazing Omakase Experience!  If you can get a reservation, make sure you sit at the bar so that you can watch the chef at work- they are so meticulous with their work.  Everything was so fresh!  And it was my first time having turtle in the turtle soup.  

Dined here for my Birthday for the $95 Omakase menu- everything was so fresh and beautifully presented! After adding extra Wagyu A5 and Hokkaido Uni and drinks, this place will surely make a small dent in your wallet.  Thank goodness it was my Birthday! =)  Great place to go for a celebration!
author: Melanie N.

description: Great fresh sushi directly from Japan.  Chef only prepares 3 nights a week so book in advance. Favorites were the hakaido uni and baby shrimp with quail egg. Could be top 3 sushi meals of all time (tho I admit I have never been to Japan).
author: Josh N.

description:
Kaseiki/omikase experience was outstanding.  Our party was two couples, half of whom supplemented with the sake pairing and the other half with the wine pairing.  Which we all shared, of course!

Dishes worthy of 5 stars.  Service 3.75.  Our server was efficient, if somewhat robotic and cold.  Atmosphere is clean, simple and serene if a touch non-descript.
author: Brian W.

description:
This place is amazing. This review is a bit overdue since I came here back in December, but I promised myself I would write a review because it was just that good.
