We had a reservation for their 8 pm session (you have a choice of 5 pm or 8 pm) and had called in a few days beforehand to request bar seating. Bar seating is definitely recommended, as it makes for a much better experience than sitting at the tables. We had chef Ken, and he would speak to us throughout the meal and ask us how we enjoyed the food. He was funny and would joke around, and we got to see him make everything in front of us. 

We opted for the $95/pp omakase, and each piece was DELICIOUS. Super smooth, fresh, and perfectly seasoned. They also had the most amazing tuna EVERRRR

I'll definitely be coming back again. The dining experience was amazing and service was perfect, so the price was well worth it. Will be trying the grand omakase the next time around!
author: Michelle C.

description:
great quality but I had higher expectations for service 

The food was great. I could taste how amazingly fresh everything was. At times, some items tasted SUPER salty to me. My other friends had disagreed with me and didn't notice the saltiness at all, so it may have been me. The plating was also very beautiful and I would definitely say that it was fairly priced. It was $95 for the omakase that night. Something that I really liked was that the chef asked us what were our favorite items. He made sure to feature it at the end. 

Something that I felt that was lacking was the service. Maybe I had had too great of an experience at Omakase where the chefs were joking and laughing, but this is definitely a more calm and quiet kind of environment. I would have liked to see more personality. That's nothing to take a star for, but personal preference. I'd definitely come back just for the quality.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Kusakabe is such a special place. First of all, the food is delicious and reasonable priced for what you get. We did the "grand" omakase for $150 but we got 22 items! 22! (Disclaimer: this may not always be the case.)

In my opinion, I felt that the sushi was the star here. They have non-sushi items as part of the kaiseiki but there are places like Wakuriya that really excel at that. To me, these items at Kusakabe were a little mild for me, with the exception of the beef croquette.

My favorites: zuke chutoro, toro, barracuda, Copper River sockeye salmon, BBQ white eel, beef croquette, and Canadian ebi (we added this). You can't add any items from the a la carte menu until after you've finished the omakase so if you don't want to gamble, do the $95 omakase and get more of your favorites later.

What I love most is the relaxed ambiance. I highly recommend you sit at the bar so you get your one piece of sushi at a time. It really helps you appreciate the beauty while it's on its little pedestal. And of course you get to converse with the chef making your food. That's always nice.

I giggled when I saw at the bottom of the menu that they make rolls upon request. Our chef said he hasn't received that request in the 1.5 years that he has been working there.
author: Shannon L.

description:
5 Stars for KusakaBAE, this place definitely has a place in my heart!

I live to eat and I love sushi. A few people recommended that a sushi fanatic like me should try Kusakabe, since I'm always missing the Japanese cuisine that was served in Hawaii (which I still think is the best place to get authentic Japanese cuisine here in the US). Anyway, I gave this place a whirl back in October of last year and have highly contemplated going back--and will. This review is long overdue but I've decided to write my dining experience here since I stepped foot in the intimate restaurant last Fall. 

Upon arrival, you are greeted by their hospitable staff, there's only 2 rounds per night--so do sign up early. Since I was eating with my family, we chose a weeknight, and only had to book 2 weeks in advance. We were given some type of kelp-y/seaweed-infused tea, which we were told was a palette cleanser. I thought it was delicious, I love snacking on seaweed (yes, it's a thing Asian people do). 

Anyway, once most of the people arrive +/- a few late birds, the chefs start prepping. We didn't get seated in front of the master, but we did get the second most experienced chef in the restaurant, which was great. He was very informative and friendly and taught me a few things about how and why this restaurant is slightly different from "traditional" omakase places. And the way the menu is set up is that every few dishes after amazing nigiri, will be a warm dish. And this is because it balances the digestive system so as to not overwhelm it with just nigiri/raw/food that is served in a cooler temp range. I thought that was really neat and interesting. 

I couldn't remember the names of all the different fish that were served unless I jot them down on my phone, but seriously--what kind of a dining experience would that be? I decided that posting the date I went to the restaurants would be somewhat helpful because the fish served on the day could be seasonal. So that's for any seafood/sushi connoisseurs out there. But check out that glisten and shininess of those nigiri pieces! It's AMAZING, and a sign for amazingly fresh fish. 

Overall, I really enjoyed the experience and the chestnut ice cream I ordered at the end had small chunks of real chestnut in it (yay!) I love how that fitted into the seasonal theme of the menu. 

Oh, and my motivation for finally writing this review? I plan on going back soon and don't want to mix up pictures for my next visit with the last.

Cheers! Or more like, Kanpai!
author: Denise L.

description: I didn't want to give this rating but I expected so much more. The first half of the Omakase was amazing. Second half very blah almost kinda junk. The Otoro and uni was most disappointing.
author: Expert F.

description:
Greatest sushi restaurant I've ever been to ,
Be sure to do the flight along with the omakase menu, But make sure to uber or lyft to and from As the Sake is amazing. The whole wait staff is very knowledgeable, And friendly we loved our experience
author: Michaelangelo P.

description:
Really good quality sushi, some of the intermediary courses are doused in ponzu and sauces.

Still love the welcome tea.  

Bluefin tuna, fishy.  Bonito, wish they would replace.  

Favorites now:
-Hotate 
-zuke chutoro, can be overseasoned
-bafun uni
-sardine 
-Hirame 
-toro 

The cooked items are really just an afterthought and the sushi while good, not many are wow.  Splurge on the toro and most of the time the A5 is on target.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Michelin star means that I have high expectations of this place to be exceptional. 

I thought it was the norm of gourmet sushi, sashimi, sake and nigiri, but the proportions was a bit lacking for the price tag - I am talking about their omakase set.  

Quality was there, but it didn't stand out as spectacular to other upscale sashimi, omakase offerings that I have tried.

Their A5 Wagyu was not of the most marbleous that I have ever had.  Top notch - don't get me wrong.  However, not the best.

Their omakase nigiris were of the standard.  Again, it lacks the feeling of amazing!  Not too much creativity either.  Let me rave about it the next day, kind of feeling that I usually have on dazzling food spots!  It took me awhile to express myself about this place as you have read thus far that I left quite unimpressed. 

Sake was nicely fragrant and complimented well with the nigiri.  I was disappointed that they didn't include Hokkaido uni to their omakase set.  We had to order it as an addition.  I loved the freshness that you can taste from the uni.  Downside, it wasn't on the omakase set as it should have since it was such a delight to taste and would have been overlooked if we didn't order it.

As much as I want to really flatter this place, it didn't spark me as oh my, I have to return for their almighty sashimi, sushi and so forth.  It's a tucked away small spot and discrete.  Reservations are required and you have to tell them ahead of time that you want the chef's counter.  

I left feeling: yes, it was fine dining splurge.  Great celebratory restaurant to attend to.  Not the best sashimi ever, but you get it Michelin style.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Kusakabe definitely deserves its Michelin star because the food and the customer service here is phenomenal. My dining experience was nothing short of exceptional. 

::Food
First of all, I enjoyed the $95 Omakase course very much but if I had to do it again, I would definitely pay a bit more and go for the $150 omakase course. The additional courses that you get for the latter is definitely worth the extra $50 ! Go big or go home ! 

The dinner experience went by so fast like a blur (probably because everything was delicious and it felt like floating on clouds in heaven). My favorite is hands down the toro - you can never go wrong with toro- but every single nigiri and sashimi serving was incredibly fresh. The kussi oysters and the croquette are my second favorites and lastly, if you didn't order the $150 omakase, I would definitely order the uni off of the regular menu. The uni was so light and wasn't overwhelming at all (like most restaurants). The almond ice cream was also a great finishing touch so definitely order dessert because there should always be room for dessert. 

::Service
The servicing was incredibly. Everyone was very attentive and knowledgeable. Sadly, we didn't get a chance to sit at the bar, though the experience was just as nice to have our own table. I would definitely recommend getting a bar seating to learn more about the dishes and get a first seat experience at how the dishes are prepared. Reservations aren't that hard to get if you're booking for a party of 2 but anything more than that will take a long time. It took me about 2-3 months to get a reservation for a party of 4. Definitely worth the experience and I can definitely say that I'll be back again.
author: Tram N.

description: Extremely disappointed/upset with Kusakabe. I made a reservation awhile ago for my boss to have a high level business dinner at Kusakabe this last Monday, 7/23. The reservation was set for 5:30pm, which was confirmed in advance. When my boss showed up to the restaurant, the host had given away his table to someone else, and claimed that the restaurant was overbooked and that he could be seated at 8pm if he wanted to wait 2.5 hours. My boss was left scrambling to find a last minute dinner spot, for a high end business meeting, which set a bad tone for the rest of the night. For a restaurant that you have to book far in advance, and makes you put a deposit down, this is extremely unprofessional. I will never rely on Kusakabe ever again, and will be telling other people to avoid for high level dinners. Terrible customer service.
author: Danielle W.

description:
Took my sister here while in town for work.  We had the Grand Omakase and Grand Sake pairing.  The overall foods, I would say between 3-3.5 in terms of flavors, presentation, and quality.  

We sat next to a lively couple so they kept the sushi chef talking through the entire meal.  After they left, I asked the sushi chef to pick up the pace because we were waiting sometimes 5 minutes between each bite.  The timing was horrible.

Service overall is sufficient.
author: Kayla N.

description:
Chef Nori Kusakabe is phenomenal.

I took my husband here for his 30th birthday.  I made the reservation a month in advance and I am not sure if that is why but we were served by Chef Kusakabe that evening.

I took my husband to Sushi Yoshizumi for his 28th and that was amazing too but...we liked Kusakabe better.

We went for the general ($98) Omakase because I had wanted the option of ordering a-la-carte after the omakase.  Ultimately, our bill was $350 including tip for the two of us (yikes) but we ordered several a-la-carte items and it was well worth it.  

Looking back, there were some courses in the omakase that I thought were great but not phenomenal as the a-la-carte items turned out to be.  For example, if I were to come again...I could do without the sashimi and the plate with 5 different stuff inside.  They were great, but were not in the same caliber as some of the a-la-carte items we ordered after the omakase, in my humble opinion.

One thing I did not appreciate was the overuse of phones and talking of the guests.  That was a bit annoying.

The dishes that really stood out to us were the following:

-uni with scallop on top
This is an amazing combination.

-ika (a-la-carte)
Chef mentioned that the squid was aged for 10 days.  This was something I had never had in my life.  Well worth the $10.50/nigiri in my opinion.

-kyoto style(?) eel (a-la-carte)
This was phenomenal.  I can't describe it.  Best.

I wish I could order a-la-carte alone.  Maybe if we spend tens of thousands of dollars and become a regular, we can?  One can hope, right?
author: Gina C.

description:
This was an unforgettable dining experience. 

My girlfriend and I went for her birthday, we drank sparkling sake and ate all of the glorious creations the chef prepared right in front of us. 

Everything about this experience was fantastic!

Highly recommend you try it out
author: Jon L.

description: This was one of the best sushi restaurants I've been too. I love the omakase places and this was a great one. There was a lot of very unique seasonal fishes  which sets it apart from some other places. The waiters there are extremely attentive and knowledgeable, we had a wonderful experience will def be back any time I'm in San Fran
author: Jennifer V.

description:
My experience at KUSAKABE was truly unforgettable. I tried shirako for the first time, which I later found out was fish ballsack, but more on that later. 

So for all the wine-ing and dining Shawn C. has been doing, I couldn't have thought of a better way to return the favor than with a reservation here for his birthday. I somehow managed to secure a Friday reservation just two weeks before via OpenTable. Based on other reviews, reservations here seem to come with a hefty wait, but luckily we didn't have to experience that. 

The omakase is $95pp, with the option to order a-la-carte items at the end. It was worth every single penny. Everything was pretty amazing, mind blowing, orgasmic, you get the idea. 

I won't go through everything, but here's the special mentions:

- Every piece of nigiri was to die for. Perfectly seasoned, no soy sauce required, and skillfully made one-by-one in front of you (if you're sitting at the bar of course). Jing was our chef for the night, he's pretty awesome. Shout-out to Jing!

- Our soup, the Yaki-Goma Dofu & Kyoto style Saikyo Miso with snow crab, was unlike anything I've ever tasted before. Sweet and savory at the same time, the dofu was textured like mochi with a hint of sesame. SERIOUSLY SO GOOD.

- SHIRAKO AKA FISH BALLSACK, or milt, "the male genitalia of fish when they contain sperm, used as food." Thanks, Wikipedia. The dish was actually called Yuan-marinated Hokkaido cod with its own Shirako & Satsuma Imo. Yes, I ate fish sperm, and yes, it was 9287473 times better than what I thought it was going to be. Perfectly fried on the outside, yet so creamy and oozy on the inside.. Okay, I'll stop now. 

- Sushi finale.. dat toro. Oh my god, it dissolved in my mouth. 

We received a complimentary yuzu sorbet for Shawn's birthday, and all the employees sang happy birthday to him! He turned bright red - mission accomplished! 

Thank you, KUSAKABE! Your food is pretty amazing, but it was your service that was the cherry-on-top of this amazing dining experience.
author: Laverne N.

description:
Had one of the most amazing dining experiences of my life here last night!!! The $150 was SO worth it. Chef Nori was so kind and willing to adjust the menu to what me and my boyfriend like and he was great at explaining each dish to us. Whenever we asked him questions, he was very willing to answer them and explain too! We learned a lot about where they source their fish and the insanely quick shipping they have from Japan to SF. 

Overall, the service was on point and the food quality was just amazing - The Kaisui Uni was literally THE best uni I've EVER eaten in my life. The finale of toro and A5 wagyu was so delicious too - seriously, melt in your mouth good! We also ordered the shrimp a la carte which was huge and you get to eat it in two ways, the body quickly poached over rice and the head deep-fried! I also really enjoyed the BBQ eel with sansho pepper, super fatty eel and no bones in it at all.

This experience was more than I could've asked for and I 100% will be back!! Deserves more than 1 michelin star for sure! Chef Nori, food quality, service - all A+++++, well worth the $400 meal.
author: Cynthia H.

description:
Tips:

Recommend bar seating.
Try both the toro and the wagyu sushi, you won't regret it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hands down one of my favorite sushi experiences yet! I came here on the Monday after Valentines day for the 8pm seating and I had an amazing time.

Service:
- Pace of dinner was perfect: not too fast, but not too slow.
- Staff are extremely attentive and helpful. Answered all our curious questions and explained every dish to us. I never felt intimidated or out of place.
- This was my first Omakaze experience at the bar seating and our sushi chef helped us survive through it! (Thumbs up for Patrick our sushi chef!)

Food:
- Absolutely delicious. Everything from the sushi to the warm dishes to the soup.

I would absolutely come back and recommend coming to Kusakabe for all of my friends.
author: Alice H.

description:
One of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF!! 

You have to make a reservation to get seated since they only have two seatings a night. The omakase is only $95 per person, which is super affordable compared to a lot of other options in the city, and the quality is still exceptional. It's definitely not the most extensive omakase menu, but I left feeling pleasantly satisfied, rather than too full to move. And, if you want more of a particular fish, or just want something that wasn't included in the omakase courses, you can also order additional things a la carte.

The omakase has a good mix of warm dishes, quality fish, and other courses. The non-nigiri items were really unique. Two that I remember were a soup with a small meatball / dumpling and a fish marrow gelatin type thing (part of a mini 4-course plating). For the finale, I would definitely recommend getting both the wagyu and the toro options!! You do have to pay extra in order to have both, but definitely worth it. Sooo delicious.

For dessert, I got the pumpkin pudding with caramelized sugar on top. Kind of a twist on a traditional creme brulee, with a slightly different texture. It was unique, not too sweet, and a great end to the meal.
author: Tiffany P.

description: AMAZING food here. The ambiance of the place, the attentive service, EVERYTHING was phenomenal. Will absolutely be recommending this place to people I know.
author: Sarah M.

description:
The Omakase sushi etc. was all excellent.  It was customized based on our favorites. 

...And we were served by the famous Nori himself, which we only just realized. Arigato gozai mas Nori for a wonderful dinner last night.
author: D K.

description:
Thank you sushi gods for finally bestowing upon me sushi that will save me from having to haul to Sushi Ran with...the former chef of Sushi Ran! Now all that is saved from gas and tolls can go towards even more yummy goodness.

Atmosphere: 
Warm wood counters and about 4 small tables in a perfectly minimalist setting setting that to me is an absolute must so you can focus on the main event: the brilliant show at the bar and eating. Do sit at the bar though! They also have a full on Toto with full flush sounds and motion sensor for you truly hardcore Japanese aficionados.

Service:
Superb, friendly, accessible, not stuffy. Very accommodating to my two dining partners who each had a litany of dietary idiosyncrasies. 

Food
Yum. Kaiseki so you get a great variety and don't have to use any brain power. Definitely the best sushi in SF proper that I've had. 

Cost:
You have the regular omakase  ($95) and grand  omakase for I can't remember how much, it was more courses and more fish options but we weren't hungry enough, though we were quite stuffed from just the regular omakase so you'd better bring your A eating game if you plan to do the latter. 

Overall:
The best sushi and one Michelin star in SF that will leave you fat and happy =)
author: Snuffles B.

description: Wonderful sushi - especially the smoked/ cured nigiri. Extremely fresh - standout were the hotate (scallop) and other seasonal fish (baby snapper and yellowtail). Polite, lovely service as well rounding off an excellent evening. Omakase never comes cheap but this is great value for what you're getting - arguably the best value omakase in SF.
author: Ruo Ting G.

description: This was a WONDERFUL dining experience. That's really what it was, an experience. We got the 11 course meal experience and our chef was knowledgeable and engaging, we sat at the bar. love that he told us about every fish we ate and followed up asking what we thought about and his view on it. We ate a lot of tunas on the night we went which are my fav!!! The website says Sami formal attire but not everyone adheres to that. Making a reservation well in advance is a must!! This was a great date night. The menu is set and you must get one of the two set course offerings for the evening but you can order individual pieces at the end of your meal. Not a place for kids or picky eaters. The chef did ask if there were any allergies however I'm not sure how many substitutions they could make with the set menu already prepared for the evening. But this place has definitely earned that Michelin star!!!
author: C P.

description:
Kusakabe is an interesting place. You get lots of stuff you probably haven't tried ever and that's good. But the staff rushes through the description that half the time you don't really know what you just ate. I had 10 courses and I could maybe tell you about 5-6 of them. The freshness of the fish is unreal, but again, weird, as some fish had little to no taste. Then there where whoppers like A5 and uni that were total flavor bombs. If I had to sum this place up as a band it would be Fugazi. Slow parts that make you almost tired and question why you are there and then all of the sudden you get smacked with this wicked over the top noise and feedback. Fugazi shows cost 5 bucks, this didn't. Like I said in the first line, interesting place.

PS-I don't like to get dressed up, for this I did, a little. But, there is absolutely no dress code here.
author: Katenryan B.

description: Pricey, but worth it! Everything about our evening was special. We sat in front of the chefs and were able to watch their magical fingers. The kitchen area is small and the way the chefs moved around to prepare the sushi was like watching a performance. They never bumped into anyone and their movements were fluid. The staff was welcoming and communicated well what the next course was and how it was prepared. When we first sat down, we were asked if there are any food allergies or food dislikes. We chose the petite menu and added some al a carte items after we finished. We had the paired wine with our meal and the wine certainly complimented the wonderful food we were eating.  We ended the night with a shared dessert, which wasn't very sweet but capped off the night.
author: Robin A.

description: Impeccable, incredibly fresh ingredients make for a special dining experience. Some of the courses came in formats I had never had before. It was fun to watch the preparation while sitting at the counter. Every course was a well anticipated surprise. This place books up; reserve as far ahead as you can!
author: Jill K.

description:
I took my boyfriend to KUSAKABE for his birthday back in February, and it was quite the eye opening experience!

I've always been a fan of sushi, but this was our first time trying omakase. KUSAKABE took my love for sushi to the next level. Eat with your hands, and no need to dip the nigiri into soy sauce or add any extra wasabi; the chef puts it on your plate, and you stuff it into your mouth. Have a bottle of sake (or two) while you're at it!

My favorites were the toro, A5 wagyu, and Kaisui uni (a la carte). Birthday dessert, accompanied by all of the servers and chefs singing "Happy Birthday," was a nice touch. :)

Can't wait to be back!
author: Jennifer K.

description: Wow. Just wow. I honestly loved every bite. They cater to your preferences. Fish so fresh that it ruins you average run of the mill week day sushi place. Amazing service. Amazing food. GO!
author: K K.

description:
Kusakabe is definitely pricey but worth the experience. Superb service and had extremely fresh ingredients. As a resident of Vancouver I have extremely high expectations for sashimi and Japanese food and Kusakabe did not disappoint. The toro served at the beginning and the otoro at the end was extremely delicious. It just melted in my mouth and my taste buds were in heaven. I also had the pleasure of tasting the Shima Aji which I highly recommend!!! Its my favorite fish and usually it tastes a little fishy at restaurants that don't treat it well but it was perfect here with balanced flavors with the topping and rice. 

Did I mention their rice varies? This is not just your regular sushi joint with fresh fish! Each piece has other spices, toppings or different rice that accompanies the fish which was surprising and delicious. 

Overall, for two people I came in just around $400 for the grand Omakase + two beers.
author: Evelyn Y.

description:
This was my first Michelin starred sushi restaurant so I was pretty excited about coming here. 

We sat at the bar, which is the ultimate Omakase experience. 
However, I thought the sushi was mediocre. Some of the pieces were great but others were just mediocre. I also didn't like how there was a combination of warm and cold dishes rather than being consistent. 

Meh, this Michelin restaurant didn't leave a huge mark for me to want to come back again or rave about. I'd much rather go to Sushi Yasuda in New York for half the price, also one Michelin starred.
author: Leilani Y.

description: Me and my husband's favorite restaurant! We are very familiar with this type of cuisine and love trying out different restaurants, but we have yet to find one in the Bay Area that matches Kusakabe. The food is always fresh and well presented, and the meals are well thought out and well timed so it never becomes boring. The service is great, they are very careful about food allergies (my husband is allergic to many thing on top of gluten), and they wash their hands when they switch between working on my food and his food. I am sure we will keep going back!
author: Wooptydoop L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for our 3 year anniversary. This is our first time having Omasake and it was amazing! The staff even called a couple days in advance to ask if it was a special occasion and wished us happy anniversary on arrival. 

We opted for the 19 piece basic omakase which was $95 per person, and it was worth every penny! Every single dish was beautifully crafted, and delicately flavored. While sometimes it was hard to understand the waitstaff, they were the perfect balance of helpful but not intrusive. 

I was also such a sucker for the matcha tea which they refilled generously, and I subsequently had to use the restroom multiple times throughout the meal. On a side note, the toilet is really awesome as well. It opens its lid and greets you upon entrance. Super neat! 

The omakase set itself was filling enough, but my boyfriend and I have the biggest sweet tooth and decided to order dessert as well. I've normally experienced creme brulee in its too sweet and too riche state, but Kusakabe's rendition was so good and definitely put creme brulee in general back into my good graces. Can't wait until the next special occasion to splurge on some delectable Japanese bites again. :)
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I was... underwhelmed to say the least. I went to Kusakabe a few months ago (back in Octoberish of last year), and decided to finally get around to writing a review.

I heard GREAT things about Kusakabe, especially after learning that the chef was originally from Sushi Ran (probably my favorite sushi joint currently). I went in with high expectations, especially because Kusakabe had 1 star at the time. I've been to Maruya before, and I'd have to say, I think I'd rather go back to Maruya next time (or try a new omakase spot) instead of returning to Kusakabe. This might be a personal preference, but I prefer my nigiri completely raw... where a lot of the nigiri at Kusakabe was partially seared or torched. I ordered the grand omakase menu, and although it was yummy, it didn't quite hit the spot for me. 

If you're looking for simple, fresh, raw nigiri - this place isn't it. It's definitely more for the type of people who might not be used to completely raw fish, and still prefer a bit of searing or torching. They also have a lot of small appetizer type of dishes (delicious) in between. I guess I'm a bit picky with sushi, but I definitely did feel pretty underwhelmed. I was full by the end, but I expected something else when it came to the nigiri.

Kusakabe is a great place for people who might just be getting into the sushi/omakase craze, who might not entirely love raw fish. But for people like me, (raw nigiri all the way pls) it didn't live up to the hype :[ Back to Sushi Ran or Maruya for me.
author: Li S.

description:
Thank you Kusakabe staff! You made our 15 year wedding anniversary incredibly special, and also incredibly tasty. Looking forward to seeing you soon, thank you again! 

PS: incredibly fresh fish, perfectly presented, and absolutely delicious, and don't forget excellent service.
author: Jack M.

description: Best sushi I have ever had in my life. The waitress was extremely knowledgeable and the food was really sublime.
author: Margaret P.

description:
Kusakabe is easily the most I've ever spent on a single meal, and I don't regret a single penny. Even if you're a peasant like me, they treat you like royalty there. I am a big sushi lover, and after having seen half of Jiro Dreams Of Sushi, I wanted a more authentic experience.

Every single course was exploding with layers of flavor and the fish couldn't be any fresher. Besides that, the whole experience of Kusakabe is unlike any other. If you sit at the bar, you can watch this food art come to life while chatting with the friendly, wonderful chefs. The hospitality is superb, and you can tell that you're in a service-oriented restaurant. I loved every minute of it.
author: Liz Z.

description:
East Coast Native, and this is my first Michelin star exp so maybe I had too high of expectations? 

My friend who lives here took us out because she wanted to try it. I liked the experience, small, good service. Great presentation. Surprised it actually took 2 hours - bonus it didn't feel that long. 

The food was good. My favorite was this turtle egg soup thing (I should have taken a picture of the menu). Very good. Overall quality of fish was good except for a few misses. My other favorite was the wagyu beef. IF YOU GET THE TORO, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE $12 PUSH TO A LA CARTE TO TRY THE WAGYU BEEF. It is seriously that good. Melt in your mouth good. 

I think I expected better quality fish. I picked the fatty tuna/toro option but it wasn't melt in your mouth tender at all... it was really chewy.... 

That being said, it was a good experience, but I don't recommend going out of your way. For $150 I did expect higher quality fish... especially for the fatty tuna.
author: Elaine N.

description: If you are contemplating whether or not to go, definitely go! The sushi is extremely fresh and the presentation is beautiful. The chef presents dishes that tend toward very clean flavors with touches of citrus, like yuzu and shiso leaf. Things were slightly inconsistent with a little too much wasabi here and there, but overall very enjoyable. The Hokkaido uni, my favorite, really transported us back to Japan. The service is also impeccable. They were so kind, accommodating and efficient. There was a small hiccup during the service and they apologized immediately which I really appreciated. They comped us some dessert which was also delicious. They made our anniversary truly memorable. I can't wait to return!
author: Karen K.

description:
RIP Michelin Star. Still a life changing experience.

Me and my girlfriend came here when she visited America, weeks before the new Michelin restaurants were announced. She's never been a lover of raw fish (or so she thought), as sushi in China usually isn't the best. I think the other reviews cover everything, but I wanted to share a story of the service I experienced there - spoiler alert, it was impeccable.

During the part of the Omakase where they bring out a plate with oysters and tempura, they serve an onion sauce. My gf, who was enjoying the experience immensely, excitedly took photos and was enjoying the presentation of the food, when she noticed this eyelash in her onion sauce. Honestly, if she wasn't the detail oriented person that she is, I don't think we would have ever seen it.

However, she mentioned it to the maitre d' and he immediately took it away and replaced it with a new sauce. Everyone who worked at the restaurant apologized to us (including Kusukabe, *swoon*), and suddenly we were being treated to another carafe of some ridiculously expensive sake ($200 a bottle !!). It was just an eyelash! I was impressed with the service and then hospitality we experienced, possibly because of the extra alcohol we were served.

Side note, I think that this course of the omakase kind of broke up the flow of the meal in a bad way - you are eating sushi and it is awesome, then you suddenly wait for a period of time for the next course to come out, and it's this collage of different dishes together on a plate that you spend some time working through, and then you resume your sushi experience. I'm not sure how to improve it, but I felt like it threw me off my rhythm a little.

Also - for those of you getting the sake tasting, it's a ton of sake. We shared 1 tasting and I ended up drinking most of it, and I think if we had bought two I would have stumbled out of the restaurant.
author: Albert C.

description: Just wow! We've been here twice and have left absolutely blown away both times. Kusakabe will provide you with a culinary experience that will make you really appreciate the art of sushi. Each sushi chef caters to about 3-4 people so it is a more intimate setting and you have the opportunity to converse with your chef. While I highly recommend the omakase, there also opportunities to order other items at the end in case you are hoping to try something else. Each course is thoughtfully created and unique. It's also great to see the cohesiveness of the team as they all work together to help keep the timing and flow of the night run smoothly. The hosts and hostesses are also very pleasant and attentive. Kusakabe is our favorite sushi restaurant in the West Coast!
author: Michelle H.

description: I had an exceptional experience at Kusakabe with my boyfriend. Everything about each dish was perfect! We ordered the seven course prix fixe menu as well as a la carte paired with wine. The visual presentation was beautifully put together and absolutely delicious! The atmosphere itself is more intimate and traditional of Japanese culture- which is perfect for conversation and appreciation of the cuisine.
author: Camellia S.

description:
Breathtaking meal from start to finish, with the best seats in the house - the s/o and I had the privilege of sitting and watching Chef Nori prepare dinner. I felt like I scored a 2 for 1 deal: delicious omakase dinner and front row seats to a live cooking show.

Since I didn't know that my s/o was taking me out to eat at Kusakabe for my birthday (surprise dinner!), I didn't get a chance to read about Chef Nori. But after doing some research (not to sound creepy but I know I will come off creepy anyway), I'm not surprised at the number of awards and accomplishments that he has received.

My favorite piece of the night was definitely the fatty toro. Melt-in-your-goodness. I could probably eat 10 pieces of that alone. After two hours of indulging delicate, beautiful pieces of art, the restaurant gave me a complementary cream brûlée to celebrate my birthday :,) Such a sweet gesture and the cherry on top of a life-changing meal. 

Thank you for making my birthday a memorable one. We will be back to try the Grand Omakase!
author: Annie S.

description:
Book your spot already! The best sushi I ever had in my life outside of Japan. 

We had to make a reservations weeks ahead. They have a really strict cancellation policy too, if I did not recall wrongly it's about $65 for cancellations/change. Pretty harsh policy. 

We arrived slightly late and were promptly seated at the bar. We were assigned to the head chef, Chef Kusakabe himself! 

Our meal commence shortly. Every single dish was beautifully presented and thoroughly explained. Every piece of sushi was treated as an exquisite delicious art piece. I am not going to list the items I ate simply cause it changes with the season, ingredients and theme. During my visit, yuzu was the main theme/ingredient that threads through the entire omakase meal.

Perhaps because we were slightly late, we felt a little rushed through the meal. There was little room to stop and breathe a little before the next dish. So, remember to be on time. If you are driving, parking around the vicinity is a pain in the butt so do buffer more time for that. 

Nevertheless, it was one of the most amazing dinner I ever had in my life. 

Service was fantastic, attentive and personable. Highly recommend dining here, not the most wallet friendly but definitely one of the most palate satisfying.
author: Cindee T.

description:
Boyfriend took me here to celebrate our anniversary, great choice as this place has been at the top of my list for quite a while now! This was my first Michelin star dining experience and I am so glad it was as it was absolutely amazing. 

We started off with the Omakase courses which were 7 courses for $95pp. I wasn't a huge fan of the seaweed drink they give you to cleanse your palette. My favorites of the courses were the chu toro and copper salmon nigiri, although pretty much all the nigiri they served as part of the omakase were delicious. Each piece was specially seasoned and super fresh. I loved the turtle soup dish (can't believe I ate a cute little turtle), but  shockingly, it was amazing. The dish with two crispy fish in a truffle sauce and shishito pepper was another favorite of mine. Pretty much licked the dish clean because the truffle sauce was so tasty. I also really enjoyed the 5 piece le petit sampler plate of the chefs specials. Huge fan of the crispy eggplant and the tuna over rice piece. 

For the last piece,we chose the a5 wagyu sushi. I gotta say that I was not completely blown away with this piece. I actually think that Sushi Sams in San Mateo has a better A5. I mean it was definitely good, but not as amazing as I was hoping for. 

We ordered a bunch of sushi al a carte. My favorites being the kaisui uni (completely melt in your mouth!!) wish it was a bigger piece though, Santa Barbara uni, bbq unagi (soft and very good), toro (amazing), chu toro (they season this extremely well, lots of flavors). Each bite was complete heaven for me. 

This was my boyfriends first time trying Omakase and he normally doesn't like to eat raw fish other than salmon and hamachi, however, he loved every single bite of their omakase and is now addicted! Uh oh..

Their sake is also very good. I had a glass of reisling, but next time I'd probably refrain from getting this just so I could order more sushi! 

Service was wonderful. The only suggestion that I have is to be more careful and remember if people have specific food restrictions. I asked for no wasabi in all the dishes, however, we had to remind our waitress at least 3 times and there was still some wasabi in my sushi :( which took away from some of the taste for me. They made it up by giving us free dessert for our anniversary. Desserts were delicious, I would highly recommend the pancetta and I'd probably skip out on the corn ice cream next time. 

Make sure you make reservations months in advance if you want to sit at the bar and you can probably get in a months in advance if just for a table. Place is tiny and they have 2 groups for seating, one at 5pm and another at 8pm.

Would I come back? Absolutely! This place is definitely not cheap, but it's worth it to splurge for a special occasion or if you want to take yourself out for some high quality japanese food/sushi. The omakase itself is actually a good amount. It won't get you buffet full, but it's definitely enough and if you order a few pieces al a carte, you should be good to go!
author: Susan M.

description:
Believe the hype.  I was given a surprise birthday dinner here by my fiance, and was treated to a rather amazing omakase experience.  I failed to take notes (it's my birthday so I get the day off, right?) but the short version is that they serve you tons of amazing small dishes including several unique nigiri.  The thing that makes them so amazing here is that they choose rather exotic fish / seasoning / sauce combos that are both (1) unlikely to be found at other restaurants (2) f!cking delicious.  (The closest thing I know to this exotic-nigiri-centric experience is probably Sugoi sushi in the mission, though their special nigiri combos were a bit more hit and miss.)

Anyway, there were probably zero misses on our menu, and of course two of the hits were fatty tuna.  Drool.

Would love to come back here again.  If I can get a reservation.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I came to Kusakabe with very high expectations. Im probably one of the biggest sushi lovers that you'll ever meet so I was really excited to try this restaurant. Unfortunately it didn't satisfy what I was hoping for. 

My friend and I came for our end of the semester celebration. We both ordered the 95 dollar Omakase. The raw fish here is honestly really fresh and it just melts in your mouth. The halibut from the Sushi Prelude was killed 3 hours before it was served to us. However the Dashi broth was too salty for my liking. Also some items from the Hassun were not for my taste such as the lobster salad with the jelly like thing on top and the persimmon salad with the lotus root chip on top. Despite the few items that did not meet my expectations, the rest of my meal was delicious. I especially loved the final course where they served us baby sweet white shrimp and toro. 

The service here was wonderful. They brought out our food really quick and was on top of refilling our drinks. Every time they brought out our food, they would give us a very detailed explanation of what it was which is something that many restaurants lack. There were 7 sushi chefs making our meals and 3-4 servers. 

Overall, the experience was great but I don't know if I would come back again. The service and 80 percent of the meal was wonderful but if I am going to pay over 100 dollars for sushi, I expect everything to be delicious. 

Food: 4/5 stars because of the items I disliked 
Service: 5/5 stars 
Environment: 5/5 stars
author: Joyce C.

description:
No words nor stars can describe how truly amazing this place is.  I've never had omakase in my life because I live in Houston.  Houston isn't exactly known for the best, freshest sushi.  Thus, when I decided to make a trip to San Francisco, I decided that I'll lose my omakase virginity there.  After much research on Yelp, Kusakabe was the one.  

I made a reservation about a month in advance for a seat at the bar.  Note that you'll have to provide them your credit card information in order for them to reserve a spot for you, and you have up to 48 hours before your reservation to cancel.  Otherwise, they'll charge you.  

They serve dinner in two time slots: 5pm and 8pm.  The host informed me that the 5pm slot is a bit more rushed while the 8pm slot is a bit more relaxed.  Luckily, I had picked the 8pm time slot so there was no way they would ever need to rush me out of there.  

I arrived about 20 minutes early since I wasn't sure where the exact location was and didn't mind having to wait, but the host kept apologizing which was very nice of him.  After about 10 min, he was able to seat me and introduced me to my sushi chefs.  It was amazing to see them prepare all the dishes in front of me.  It was a show of its own - no date required to enjoy your dinner.  In the beginning, they ask for your favorite fish as well as any dietary restrictions.  Then, the dishes start coming.  Don't worry, they don't start preparing the next dish until you are done.  They also explain the dish so you know what you're eating.  Once you are done with the omakase, they will also hand you a dessert menu and a a la carte menu in case you want to order more.  The dessert menu wasn't as enticing to me as the sushi menu so I ordered another piece of sushi.  

All in all, the entire meal came out to a little over $100 which was completely worth it.  The meal took about 2 hours, which flew by quickly since I was enjoying my conversations with the chefs.  The environment was fun, entertaining but also relaxing.  I definitely enjoyed it and am glad that I came here for my first omakase experience.  I'll definitely come back if I'm in San Fran again!
author: Miranda L.

description: My boyfriend took me here as a surprise birthday celebration after an afternoon from MOIC close by. We had the Grand Omakase and everything was very yummy, also had a great time with the chef. He introduced us to "cod fish roe" aka cod sperm and it was special because they're only able to serve this during the winter. It was so good we asked for seconds! And of course we got seconds of o-toro, our favorite. The uni was also delicious. I enjoyed every minute of it.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Absolutely stellar. Amazing amazing service and food. I had reservations about a month in advance for 2 and everything worked out pretty well - they have two dining times, 5pm or 8pm (I think) I went for the 5pm as I knew the experience could be over 2 hours long and it was a good thing I did. We arrived early and were able to be served by Kusakabe himself. 

We enjoyed the $150 Omakase tasting per recommendation from a friend. They require that all guests in your party enjoy the same Omakase level. The service was so prompt and delightful and all of the dishes we received were very well presented and tasted heavenly - even down to the desserts! 

I would definitely give this spot a try if you're thinking about it.
author: Kim N.

description: This place is awesome! My wife and I came here on a Thursday night. Being from Michigan, we'd never experienced sushi in this style so we had to try it. We were not disappointed. The amount of food from the 11 course menu was just right. The wait staff is attentive and courteous. Our chef Brandon explained every dish in detail and was very personable. For a better experience, I would suggest sitting at the bar. This restaurant is definitely worth checking out.
author: Harnoor T.

description:
TL;DR - Great omakase, stella sake menu, fun sushi chefs!

I've been to a couple omakase places in SF and I gotta say, Kusakabe is definitely my favorite so far.

The atmosphere is warm and inviting as the chefs are all so friendly (but each with their own fun personalities)

The sake menu is also pretty varied and between the five or six sakes that we ordered, we were not disappointed by any of the pairings. 

Onto the food. We opted for the $95 omakase as we wanted to add more nigiri a la carte. Our chef was so funny and very considerate of what we liked and didn't like. I mentioned that I liked uni and aji the best and we ended up with an amazing nigiri omakase selection.

I gotta say, the japanese uni was definitely my favorite out of the three. If you are between unis and wan to try one, get that one.

OH and desserts. DO NOT PASS UP ON DESSERTS.

Yuzu sorbet and sake creme brulee. Get it. You're welcome.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Zuke was delicious and was my favorite, followed by milt, and the white eel. 

Service was amazing, on point, friendly. 

I had a 5pm RSVP and basically finished around 7pm. 

Did the grand omasake with two desserts (add on) in the end, it was my bff's bday, so one of the dessert was on the house.

All of the dishes were super elegant, different, and fresh. 

One of the finale dishes had a choice between toro vs a5 wagyu beef, I opted for the beef, and it was yummy. 

You definitely do get full, so plan on coming early, with an empty stomach.

I loved the sake creme brulee!
author: Minerva L.

description:
Came here 3/22 for my birthday. There's two dinner times, 5pm and 8pm with some spots in-between (6:15, 8:15). We reserved for the 8pm and hoped for the bar. I truly recommend to read their disclosure prior just to fully take in the experience and understand what they prefer you to do. I.E., eat the sushi with your fingers, no soy sauce, light perfume, etc. 

As many people have seen the Jiro Netflix documentary, I was so excited about finally trying omakase legitly. We were hoping to be seated right in front of Chef Nori as he is the owner and is a daily chef as well.

We got there at 8pm and were greeted right away by the host and the chefs. We were seated at the bar and were brought warm/moist cloth and every single thing brought to us was described intricately with a reason behind it. The chef in front of us managed us and two other parties. Our chef was Patrick and he asked if we ever had omakase before, if we had any allergies, any favorites, etc. We were pretty much open to everything. We did the grand omakase and they have a sake pairing, but I advise to maybe not do the sake pairing so you don't get toooo drunk. Patrick gave us a specific description for each piece and he was super nice to answer our annoying questions of how he started out and ended up at Kusakabe. I really appreciate how super clean all the chefs presentation were as well as their preparation because you literally watch them create the pieces in front of you. We were mainly being groupies watching Chef Nori's every move as he was further down the bar serving someone else. Nonetheless, Patrick was super nice and fun to talk to, making the experience really nice. 

Follow the directions, eat with your hands! For your birthday you have a choice of a complimentary dessert and Patrick recommended the sherbet, especially if you are really full after the dinner. After this experience, I will never look at sushi the same, I think I seriously only want to have sushi from this place. So much that we booked a reservation again!
author: Veronica A.

description:
A long awaited review for Kusakabe. Kusakabe is my favorite from Maruya and Omakase. I came here for Christmas dinner last year. We sat in front of chef Nori and omg it was such a great experience. He was very friendly and explain each of the fish and where it's from. I came back here more recently with another chef and I didn't think it was quiet as good as the first time I was here but it's still my favorite. 

They only offer $95 omakase and then you can order a la carte. My favorite was the golden snapper. Fish was fresh and how it was prepared was amazing.
author: Sherry Y.

description:
Would love to thank Joe, Christina, and Albert for our wonderful experience at Kusakabe. This was our second time here, this time at a table instead of the bar. Food was splendid, better than anything you can get out of a plastic box or local sushi joint. I absolutely love how they carefully explained everything as it came out, and was very mindful of any allergies or dislikes in terms of food. 

They also give you an A La Carte option at the end of your omakase. My girlfriend - being an avid uni lover - ordered Kaisui Uni (most expensive one), while I took two pieces of A5 Wagyu Beef and one piece of Toro. My girlfriend told me the only time I make the face I made while eating those is in the bedroom. 

Service is usually something I pay close attention to, and they were very courteous and cheerful in their delivery. Sincere thanks again to Joe, Christina, and Albert.
author: Daniel L.

description: Amazing meal with great service. Impeccably done sushi and incredibly fresh fish. Service was also good with servers that were knowledgeable and could explain what was being served. I think this is the best value for great sushi in SF. I think this one is going to become a staple for everyone that knows good sushi.
author: Rohan D.

description: I have been to many sushi places from the east and to the west coast , but i have never seen an amazing place like this anywhere ! the sushi is fresh and amazingly tasty ! every dish every nigiri or sashimi is prepared with an amazing level of detail !! watching the chefs work at the bar is relaxing and soothing ! thank you for the experience and the amazing food
author: Edrin O.

description:
The growing trend of Japanese restaurants opening in or near downtown is clearly at a fever pitch.  Last year, a friend presented me with a gift card (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MdG5viokZhOm2Qpn12kRBQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q). Due to scheduling logistics, it's been difficult to find a person and the time to enjoy this experience with me.  On a recent Friday, I was able to make a 5 pm reservation for two at the table near the host stand, basically at the center of the restaurant.  There are only five tables available which explains the difficulty in securing reservations without early notice.  The remainder of the seating is on the L-shaped sushi bar which seats around twelve or fifteen.  After my guest arrived, here's what we enjoyed:

Amuse
Konbu cha - Translates to kelp tea, this is more like a soup to me.  Sorry, I drank this without taking a picture as I thought it was "just tea".  Perfect elixir for foggy SF evenings.

First
Nigiri toro, halibut, bonito (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DmkADPQrPhbu7Ri_PhcvaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - The first and the third were my favorites... how can you go wrong with those two?!

Second
Sashimi scallop and maguro (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rkKjr_pOWEbDC8rDxyMNDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pristine, fresh, and tender.  They were a nice contrast with one being soft (scallop) and the other firm (maguro).

Third
Umami tomato soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KJTATBDka63tOnd0NxlrGw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My eyes widened as I searched for the tomato element.  There is a large meatball at the center of this which reminds me of the chicken meatball at Delica in the Ferry Building.

Fourth
Hassun, oysters served with French caviar and four petit plates (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qyg_iiz7Brq9vioVpmRjcQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Like the second, fourth, and fifth plates (from the left) the most.  The first one was a bit fishy for me.

Fifth
Yuba wrap (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zblfKmWoBNJU3ka25XU1RQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Indulgence!  Probably my best description given that there was foie gras in the center and summer truffles shaved on top.

Sixth
Nigiri Stripe jack, salmon, flounder (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SbCSmsZ56nNn2sCv3h6Tkw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Clean flavors and nice prelude to the highlight.

Seventh
Sushi finale, grade A5 Miyazaki wagyu steak (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oy2eVTsOqhr7JkiXmBY9cQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -  All I can say, is "look at that"!

After completing the tasting menu, our waitress kindly offered us their supplement menu in case we wanted to try something else or weren't full from the original meal.  

I chose the Lobster omelet sushi (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=87ql3El1K0eKkdX_xYd-tw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  It's actually a flavored take on tamago (egg) sushi where the lobster flavor is infused with the egg.  Enjoyed this as it was an interested take, but just don't get caught up on trying to find the lobster.
There were also three desserts on the menu (one being panna cotta), but nothing was attractive to my guest so we passed.
As many described, this is authentic Japanese cuisine served in a fine dining atmosphere without the stuffy dress code.  As I walked to use the loo, I noticed a couple of awards to the proprietor as sushi maker of the year, not something that's commonly seen in these parts.  
Yes, I will be back, but need to make sure my dining companions are as open minded menu wise as me.
author: Mike C.

description:
All around fantastic experience. We sat right in front of chef Kusakabe and it was mesmerizing to watch his craft. Every single fish he put on our plate was absolutely fresh, buttery, and perfectly crafted. 

There are two seatings, one at 5:30pm and one at 8:30pm. The whole omakase experience lasts around 1.5-2 hours, so plan to be there for a while.

As for the omakase, there are two options: grand omakase and omakase. We opted for the grand (22 pieces of sushi - go big or go home!) and even for a skinny person like me, I was able to finish it all without feeling uncomfortable. I also would highly recommend it over the normal omakase, especially for a special occasion.

I can't wait until I come here again :)

Fun fact: on the night we went to Kusakabe, there was a "birthday" for EVERY single table, except one. You get a free dessert and singing if it's your birthday!
author: Claudia C.

description:
4.5 stars. This is probably the best omakase I've had in the city. We ordered the $95 menu and left feeling very satisfied. All the flavors were balanced really well. Definitely make a reservation far in advance if you plan to go!

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description:
Opt for the $150 option. Do it. Don't even think about it. I compared my $150 meal to the table sitting next to us and they were def missing out on the good sushi and plates. 

As good as this place is, it's just not Japan's fish market standard. HOWEVER, it was still pretty damn good in America. 

Also just splurge at the end and get both the waygu and toro sushi. It's worth ittttt. I'll let my pictures speak for itself
author: Sarah I.

description:
Omakase, yeah I know!
You just got nigiri, eat sum mo'

Listen up lovies, 

1) Reservation is a must.

2) Omakase is the way to go.

3) Nice pairing of sake will do.

I'm going to keep this short and simple...

Thank you for taking me here. The nigiri was delicious, the sashimi was alright, the decor was simple, and the staff was attentive. I also like the quality and freshness of the food, but somehow it did not "WOW" me. 

Overall, I hope you give this quality Japanese restaurant a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description: This place is just great. I love the Kaiseki/Sushi Omakase combination that they serve here. The meal is perfect from the opening dashi to their selection of dessert. They have the best saltwater eel preparation I've ever tasted (shirayaki).
author: Andrew S.

description:
What a gem. Kusakabe is easily the best sushi restaurant in the Bay Area and likely California. We opted for the omakase (as everyone should) and thoroughly enjoyed each course. At the end, you have a choice of fatty tuna (toro) or A5 Wagyu, and I would suggest getting both for a nominal extra charge.

I have two criticisms, both of which do not concern the superb sushi offerings. First, the server failed to notice that I am left handed, despite my rearranging of the flatware/chopsticks/tea cup every time she placed something down. Any quality sushi restaurant in Tokyo would have noticed that immediately, but I know I'm just being really nitpicky at this point. Also, I would skip dessert. We split a matcha cake with red bean and vanilla ice cream and it was nowhere near the elevated level of the sushi. Not bad, but it was incongruous with the rest of our experience.
author: Jenn C.

description:
This is officially my favorite place for omakase now. I got lucky and managed to make a reservation one day prior to my reservation date for a friend visiting from HK.  We did $95/person omakase and I thought that was just enough food for me. Sake pairing was very nice too. 


Omakase course doesn't include deserts at this place. 
Wako on clement is another nice omakase and they give you two different kinds of desert in the end which is very nice. 

I would definitely go back to this place again.  Chef was very nice to me and spoke to me as soon as he found out I was from Japan.  Can't wait to go back!
author: C M.

description:
I'm usually not one to drop more than $40 per person on dinner, so coming to Kusukabe was really a special occasion. I took my boyfriend here to celebrate his birthday (and as a treat for myself), and can honestly say that it was worth every penny. At $95 per person for the Omakase and $150 for the Grand Omakase, this place will definitely make a dent in your wallet, but it really is worth it.

We made reservations three weeks in advance for a Thursday night. There are only two seatings: one at 5PM and another at 8PM. We chose the later time so there would be no rush. While they can't guarantee that you will be seated at the sushi bar, you can request when you make the reservation and if you arrive early you have a pretty good chance!

We were lucky enough to have Chef Kusakabe himself prepare our meal and opted for the Grand Omakase ($150 with 15 courses and 25 pieces total). Overall, the pace of the meal was great - being able to watch Kusakabe prepare each piece was a total treat and he explained each piece to us as he was making them. Some of my favorites of the night were the Zuke Chutoro, Hokkaido Scallop and Uni, Cured King Salmon Roe, Ayu, Shirayaki and the Toro finale. The ingredients they use are super fresh (they even fly in eel from Tokyo) and of the highest quality, and it really came through during the meal. We finished the meal with a creme brûlée, and the entire restaurant sang happy birthday to my boyfriend.

Overall, the dining experience at Kusakabe was nothing short of exceptional. From the ambience and customer service to the food, this was one of the most memorable evenings I've had and I hope to be back!
author: Jessica Z.

description: Delicious! The service are so good!! Also, they explained everything to you very patiently for every course!
author: Kathryn W.

description:
OH boyyy. When someone is doubtful that paying a lot for good sushi is worth it, bring them here. 

My husband and I were visiting from Chicago were able to book a spot for a weekday evening with less than a month's notice. We did not make a selection for seating preference, and we ended up sitting up at the sushi bar, which ended up being a great experience as we got to interact with our sushi chef and see how each piece is made. 

FOOD:
We were blown away by the food from the first bite. We went with the full Omakase menu and did not regret it one bit. They have a petite omakase menu which is a little shorter and cheaper, but I would recommend going with the full menu as some of my favorites were in the full menu. They do ask for allergies beforehand, and were careful to avoid any allergens (mine was scallop). Each item is thoughtfully made and presented, and we did feel full after our meal. I loved almost everything they put in front of me, although I felt that the tofu w/carrot could have been a little more flavorful. At the end of the meal, you get an a la carte menu where you can order extras, but we were stuffed. Despite this, we still ordered dessert--not because we had room, but because we were certain that the dessert would be amazing. We got the creme brulee, which was AMAZING. Was hesitant at first because I was not sure I could handle something so heavy while being so full, but their version is definitely lighter and more refreshing, but still creamy. I would say this is my favorite version of creme brulee that I've had. We also got the sorbet, which was also fantastic. I'm not a fan of heavy desserts, so these two were absolutely on point.  P.S. I still dream about the Zuke chutoro and the wagyu. 

AMBIANCE: 
Lovely, warm, serene. Lots of wood and clean lines. Good for both dates and outings with family or friends. 

SERVICE:
Great service. Entire staff is very polite, attentive, genuinely friendly and personable. Very approachable and easy going staff, despite their attentiveness, which I greatly appreciated (overly formal staff makes dining a bit too awkward for me). Did not have to try to flag down help or anything. Fantastic attention to detail. 

PRICE TO QUALITY:
Absolutely worth the splurge! My only qualm is that every time I eat sushi elsewhere, I'll just be sad that it's not as good as what we had at Kusakabe :c
author: Jenny B.

description:
Turned off by server's approach in recommending alternative to sake pairing. I didn't want full quantity of pairings (+$50 for about 15 ounces) so server suggested ordering couple glasses instead. I thought he would bring only a couple selections of same serving size and was surprised when bill was delivered with full single serving prices at almost $40/glass. It would have been far less expensive and more interesting to go with the pairings and just not drinking all of the sake. Instead of paying $50 for approximately 15 ounces I paid $80 for 8 ounces. 

Server was quite dismissive when I told him why I was disappointed in his approach. He claimed to have served larger portion in each glass which I found highly improbable and simply not worth debating. Sake was delicious but left really bad taste in mouth. Won't be back.
author: Ginia P.

description: By far the best sushi that I have ever had. The food was fresh and prepared without taking away from the natural favors of the raw ingredients. The presentation and explanation of each course was amazing, which deepens the appreciation for the food you are about to consume. Recommend getting the sake pairing - you will not regret it.
author: Van T.

description: It's an omakase menu with the option to order a la carte after. We got the regular omakase menu (smaller menu) and ordered a couple pieces a la carte that looked interesting and weren't on either of the menus. By far one of the best omakase meals I've had. The food is very fresh and the flavors used are excellent. The interior is also very nice, small/intimate - perfect for a date.
author: Mona L.

description:
After hearing so much about this place from friends and family, I finally decided to give this place a try. I booked the place for my birthday dinner and psyched myself up for what I was hoping to be an amazing meal. We walked in on a Friday night at 8pm for our 8:15pm reservation. My friends and I were greeted by the host in the front and promptly led to our seats at the bar. The sushi chef in front of us introduced himself to us and asked us about our preferences for fish. We went with the regular omakase over the grand one. The whole experience itself was fun. You got to watch the chef make all the nigiri in front of you. Fresh from their hands straight onto your plate. Our chef was super friendly and let us try to guess which fish was coming next. 

My favorite item of the night was the sashimi of tuna and scallops that came beautifully arranged atop a bowl of ice. The scallops were amazingly sweet and the tuna just melted in your mouth. This item earned 5/5 stars for me and I wish I could have eaten it all night long. Other honorable mentions were the hamachi+mackerel (forgot what the name of the fish was) and the cherrywood smoked tuna. Both were very unique in flavor and the fish was super fresh and supple. 

What disappointed me the most were the hassun, the toro, and the wagyu beef. The hassun was gorgeously presented, but of all the items on the dish, not a single one stood out to me. The toro was chewy and nothing near the melt in the mouth quality I was hoping for. Same went for the wagyu beef. It was so chewy that I ended up swallowing the beef whole. For $15 extra a piece, I was quite bitter about ordering it after eating it. 

For $100 for an omakase, I would most likely not be coming back here anytime soon. The quality of the fish was decent, but the items themselves were nothing to rave over. I will say that if you want to come here, ask for a reservation at the bar. It is well worth it. I honestly think the whole experience was as good as it was because we sat at the bar instead of at the tables. The food itself gets a 3/5 stars for me, but the service was a 5/5. 

Cons: 
- Pricey (but most people come here knowing they are going to have to dish out a good chunk of money for this meal)
- Hard to find parking (true for a lot of places around SF though)
- A lot of courses were lackluster and left me wanting more 

Pros: 
- Great service 
- Sushi chef was super friendly and accommodating
- Gorgeous interior decor and nice ambiance
author: Diana C.

description:
In the last 3 months I went to three different Japanese restaurants that served an Omakase style menu. Omakase stands for a meal consisting of dishes selected by the Chef. I highly recommend this because you get to taste a wide variety of fresh fish and flavors that you may not normally would order. You will likely try something that you have never tried before and be pleasantly surprised. 

Out of the three Omakases that I tried, Kusakabe, by far, was my favorite. (The other two places I went to was Kabuto in Las Vegas & Kru in Sacramento, feel free to check out my reviews for them.)

Kusakabe stood out above the other two primarily because of their flavors. It's been a long time that I tasted something and was wowed over and over again. Servings come in bite sizes so it's okay to eat the whole thing in one bite and wait for it.... ah... foodgasm!!!!  No exaggeration, the food was so good that we kept ordering more and more from the "second menu"; we couldn't get enough.

The second reason why this was better than the other two was the friendliness and professionalism of the staff. From the Hostess, Grace, to all the waiter, waitresses and of course, the Chefs, my cousin and I really enjoyed ourselves. We sat at the bar and everyone was very attentive and was more than happy to explain and answer any questions that we had. The Omakase in Vegas was so rigid that you almost didn't want to ask anything or even speak. I like to learn about what I'm eating and have fun while I'm eating. The Staff at Kusakabe, definitely provided that atmosphere. 

There are approximately 15 seats at the bar, a large table for 8 or so, and three small tables for parties of two. If you go, try and get a seating at the bar; you'll have the most interaction with the Chefs and you get to see how everything is prepared; it's a real treat! 

Our meal started with a Welcome tea made of Konbu cha or kelp tea; it tastes much better than it sounds... drink up!

Our first bite was Zuke Chutoro (lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce), maaaaaaaaaaaan.... ah...sorry... another foodgasm just thinking back... this had such a powerful flavor; you'll be very surprised. And the rest of the meal continued on with every bite just as good as the first.

The most surprising dish was the Suppon umami soup with Domyo-ji Manjyu (Soft shell turtle soup with sticky rice). I know, it's hard to comprehend that you are eating a sweet innocent turtle but you just have to have an open mind and try it. YOU WILL WANT MORE!

In addition to the Omakase menu, we also ordered: 

Ayu (Japanese Sweet fish with grated Japanese cucumbers)
Ji Kinmedai (Lightly cherry wood smoked golden eye snapper)
Umimasu (Tasmanian ocean trout lightly poached)
Kohada (Gizzard shad with crystallized egg yolk)
Kaisui Uni (Deep ocean packed Hokkaido sea urchin)

I would eat each and every one of those over and over again. 

Hot tea came with the meal but we also ordered Yuki no Bosha "Cabin in the Snow" Junmai Ginjo sake which was light and fruity, went well with the meal. 

For dessert we had the vanilla panna cotta with Ume caramel and Fresh corn and white miso ice cream parfait... go for the fresh corn and white miso ice cream parfait... delicious!  

The grand total for our meal was $351.26 (tips not included) but it was worth every penny and I would go back again and again... pocket book permitted, that is!
author: Tinah Y.

description: From the minute you walk in you can tell why they are Michelin rated.  The service is refined and the pace felt just right.  All the fine cuts and variety of fish you'd expect in a high end omakase experience.  Highlights for me were the Uni (Hokkaido) - what can I say, Uni is just the best,  the Chutoro - which I prefer over the otoro, the Shima Aji - love my white jacks, and the Alaskan King Salmon - such perfect fat content .  Was lucky enough to be served by Chef Kasakube which made the experience all the more enjoyable.
author: Wooju C.

description:
#875 =) 

For my best friends birthday we decided to go to Kusakabe to celebrate. 

Ambiance - charming, intimate, welcoming 
Quality- superb 
Service - efficient, friendly, accommodating 
Value - omakase at $95 a person is well worth it when you see the quality and variety of dishes that you get 

Sit at the sushi bar if you can, it's a far better experience! 

Highlights - Kuisui Uni, Golden Eye Snapper, BBQ White Eel, Lobster covered in rice popcorn, Copper King Salmon just to name a few! 

Overall Thoughts

One of the best sushi experiences I have had in SF to date
author: Eddie W.

description:
Excellent sushi that tastes just as good as the ones I had in Japan. If you can make reservation in advance to get seats at the bar so you can watch the chefs make the sushi! They are all so professional, precise, and has so much respect to the food they are making for their guests. You can taste all the quality in the dishes served. 

We did the grand omakase and worrying that the dishes were so small, we wouldn't be full but that was not true ! We were actually stuffed by the end of the dinner and I highly recommend you to savor and taste each dish carefully to get all the flavors. You can really take your time to eat and take on the full experience!
author: Lucy C.

description:
A wonderful sushi and dining experience!  I made reservations early to celebrate my husband's birthday here and we were not disappointed!  The service from the beginning was impeccable, definitely of michelin star quality.  Also, we were seated at the bar, right in front of Chef Nori which made the night even better because we got to see him at work and he was the one that served each piece of sushi to us one-by-one.  We got lucky to get the VIP seats of the night!

We opted for the regular omakase which is $95 per person, as compared to the grand omakase which was $150 per person.  Regardless of which one you choose, you also are given an a la carte menu at the end of the meal, should you want to supplement the meal with any extras.

The regular omakase includes 19 items which are mostly sushi/sashimi but supplemented with a few other courses like a soup and some other small traditional Japanese bites.  Each of the sushi were handcrafted with care and paired and presented with exquisite precision.  I loved the flavors that he would complement each fish with without overpowering its flavor.  The sashimi plate was presented with two sauces: an onion yuzu sesame seed oil and soy sauce.  The yuzu sauce was delicious and just melted in your mouth with the scallop and tuna that it was served with.

The entire night felt like being transported back to Japan.  Even the bathroom was complete with an automatic Japanese-style toilet with too many buttons for me to count.  The night ended with the entire staff singing "Happy Birthday" to my husband and bringing out a yuzu sorbet with a candle.  I would highly recommend this place to anyone who enjoys the intricacies of Japanese food!
author: Jess Y.

description: Celebrated 10th anniversary dinner at an amazing restaurant. Service was excellent. Special thanks to the manager Joju for making our day memorable. It's rare that restaurant makes exceptions due to their popularity. Grand Omakase is worth every cent.
author: Tommy T.

description:
By far one of my favorite omakase experiences behind Maruya(before the chef change, don't know how it is now). My boyfriend and I decided to celebrate our 3 year anniversary here last week and it was a good choice. Getting reservations weeknights was easy but seemed more difficult for a weekend. 

We had reservations at 8, we arrived a little early and were seated at the bar, which is definitely the way to go for any omakase. I forget which chef we had but he was pretty cool to chat with. The omakase had 7 courses which was more than enough. The starting toro was a great way to start the meal. I really loved how they really took into consideration what fish you like and gave you fresh nigiri within the fish groups you like. I can't say that I didn't like anything in the omakase cause I liked everything. Well the only exception would be the ice fish in the chefs petite plate , it tasted ok but not my favorite fish but everything else was exceptional. 

The toro at the end was mouth watering and good! Definitely a great way to end the meal. When the omakase is over they hand you a a la carte menu to order anything extra. We love Uni so we ended with ordering that and extra toro, a5 waygu beef nigiri. A5 waygu was also great, it was fatty and slightly torched but it was so good! I would definitely get this again but I still love toro more! Kaisun and bafun Uni were the two Uni that we ordered and both were creamy with a good texture. It was melt in your mouth good and they did not have a weird fishy taste like some other units we have had in the past. They tasted super fresh especially since they were both imported from Japan. 

Overall, we really liked the omakase, but anything from the a la carte menu really racks up the tab. A
Great place for special occasions and for sushi purists. Definitely a place to try at least once! 

Total for 2 w/ tax & tip: $314
author: Stella J.

description:
Please train your employee what is Omakase.

The chef is nice, at least he apologized. This is a good restaurant and the food are good. I definitely will go back if I get a chance.
author: Chi C.

description:
Thank you Kusakabe for an amazing dining experience to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday.

The grand omakase is definitely the way to go. Although 25 courses may seem like a lot, each course is perfectly timed so that you do not over eat or get too full too fast. At $150 pp, it is definitely a good value for the quality and amount of food.

The atmosphere of Kusakabe is friendly and inviting. My boyfriend and I felt very comfortable sitting at the sushi bar, and enjoyed our time making conversation with our sushi chef Brian.
