After perusing a few prior reviews and photos, I had to see if Kusakabe lived up to the hype...and it did not disappoint! Apparently the place is completely booked for months; my date and I snagged a reservation for 5:15 on a Monday (maybe not an "ideal" time for most, but hey, I honestly don't mind; I'm down for sushi any time of the day or night!) 

I won't bore you with a detailed description of every single item because the menu is not secret; pretty much stays the same between weeks and months except for the seasonal fish of the day. We also shared wine pairing, which was solid. It all was fantastic, and I left very satisfied. 

The only thing that was less than fantastic, for me, was: 
- Umami soup with angel prawn and cod: I'm not a huge fan of cooked prawn, and I didn't like the texture of the condensed block of rice/fish in the middle.

**Favorite pieces**
- Zuke chutoro (melt-in-your mouth, perfectly seasoned and seared!)
- Chef's sashimi, Maguro and Hokkaido scallop (so fresh~)
- Copper river king salmon (with oboro konbu)
- Toro (can't go wrong here)
- UNI !!! I am an uni lover, so I ordered all three types (Kaisui, Bafun, and Santa Barbara) from the a la carte menu. Kaisui was definitely the winner, but they were all delectable. 

Dessert:
- Chestnut ice cream parfait (was delicious, the ice cream was very rich and highlighted the chestnut perfectly)
- Kabocha squash pudding (had an Okinawan black sugar glaze that made it perfect)

Overall, definitely the best omakase & meal I've had in SF thus far.
author: Kiana S.

description: We've been to Kusakabe multiple times now and will continue to return.  We always do the Grand Omakase and a sake pairing and thoroughly enjoyed the dining experience every time.  The food and service are awesome and the sake sommelier is very knowledgeable.  Highly recommend Kusakabe!
author: Leslie Y.

description: Damn this sushi is amazing! Went here on a date and we both left happy. My girl and I ordered lots of sashimi and sake. It's one of those rare gems that actually serves HIGH quality fish. Be prepared to order more than you intended. Servings are not all that big. I ended up spending over $100 for two people.
author: Chris V.

description:
(Huh? Where'd my review go?)
In summary: the food's good.
The omakase serving format's slowww.
My appetite #aintgottimefuhdat.

$95 Omakase Menu
The whole thing (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=tdubOLxMzPcDqjIovlzPnA)
Openers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=B_An94Ur0fGbPanLNUBQnA)
Mid courses (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=ASHz5eED0ZwCA7G-kGoXMQ)
Finishers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=OuMlml5d_5fDQ4gSO5h6Tw)

$?? A la Carte Menu
Mains (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=tadM--7e6Gk7evViopPI7w)
Desserts (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=bohfO3abGAiwOGD06pSq1g)
Teas (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kusakabe-san-francisco?select=BNVVAm-Vk7FdT21yzReX4g)
author: Dan B.

description:
tldr; can be hard to get/make reservations, but well worth it. would recommend getting the shorter (and very affordable!) tasting menu and adding nigiri pieces over the grand menu

Yup. Definitely the best nigiri in SF. I feel iffy about the omakase and my experience overall, but having gone to quite a few different sushi restaurants in the city, Kusakabe was definitely not a disappointment.

Came here on a Saturday night to celebrate the SO's birthday. We got 5pm reservations and I was pretty amazed at how quickly the restaurant filled up. Within 10-15 minutes, almost every seat was taken which gives you an idea of how crazy popular this place is. 

Pro tip. Show up early. I don't think they seat people in a particular order, it was basically just first come first serve for the bar. I noticed the first couple that got seated got the head chef so that's also some incentive to come earlier than later. 

Anyways, we had a super nice dude serve us our sushi. My friend had come before and recommended the grand omakase ($150/pp) so we went with that. Our menu items were: 
-ichiban dashi (fresh brewed broth from dried kombu and katsuo-bushi
-zuke chutoro, bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in soy sauce and four pieces of seasonal sushi
-Chef's four kind of sashimi with Italian summer truffle, and Yuzu onion sauce
-Japanese oyster with caviar
-Hako-Zushi of the day
-Six kinds of Chef's assorted petits plats (oyster, fried crab claws, eggplants, etc)
-Snap pea surinagashi (soup) with crispy Arare Alaskan Kinki and white bean paste
-Hokkaido sea urchin and three kinds of seasonal fish
-Shirayaki fresh BBQ white eel
-Toro or Miyazaki Wagyu beef

In general I thought the nigiri pieces were killer. Super delicious, really well done. Easily the best in the city. Unfortunately, the other things, where were more tapas style, I was not a big fan of. I thought they were fine, clearly well executed, but just not as standout or memorable.

I think the real move here is to actually get the shorter omakase and then if you're still hungry, pay extra money for extra pieces. That additional $50-60/pp I think would have been better spent on actual nigiri pieces which were really just WOW. Fish was super fresh, the combinations that they had were so creative and innovative, it really was a different league. 

What surprised me and disappointed me about the evening was the service. The SO and I had a really unpleasant experience with our waitress. Overall, I just felt like she gave us a lot of attitude, was pretty condescending, and treated us as if we were kids who had never eaten at a nice restaurant before. A couple of examples. I asked for what teas were available, and she started off listing them off in the Japanese form (e.g. hojicha) and the translation, but then stopped, and started to just give them in English cause I presume she thought I didn't know anything about Japanese tea. I'm no expert but I at least know what I'm ordering... then she came back and forgot my order... The SO also asked for sake recommendations, and he admittedly doesn't know a ton about sake, but she gave him a bit of sass about his lack of descriptors for what he wanted. It just gave us a really uncomfortable feeling while we were dining. I was also surprised because generally a Michelin restaurant slays at service. Frankly, I've been to triples when I had less eating experience and people were never condescending to me. That was the low point of our meal.

Otherwise, everyone else we met was fun and great. Our sushi chef was a really knowledgable nice guy, and most people were friendly. They brought out a yuzu ice cream with a candle and the restaurant sang happy birthday to the SO which I thought was cute and a wonderful gesture. 

Ultimately, Kusakabe I think does have the best nigiri in the city. I think people's opinions of the omakase will vary depending on how much they like nigiri, but it's definitely pretty 50-50 nigiri and non nigiri pieces.
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Wanted to hit the three SF Michelin sushi/omakase restaurants, and Kusakabe was our final stop after Omakase and Wako.  At each restaurant, we had the full omakase menu.  

Overall, Kusakabe's quality of fish is on par with both Omakase and Wako.  However, we felt that the execution of many items was subpar.  Several nigiri and kitchen items were overpowered by some component of the dish, whether it be too much cucumber rolled within trout, too much acid (lemon) on the oyster,  or beans that dominated the crab salad.  We just want the fish to shine.

On the plus side, Kusakabe's rice was well cooked and seasoned.  We liked that, proportionally, the balance of fish to rice was just right.  Wako, on the other hand, served too much rice and it was not as well flavored.  The items that really stood out for us at Kusakabe:  Cauliflower/abalone soup, Bonito, Scallop w/uni, Toro, Wagyu beef, Medium blue fin tuna, white eel, and homemade sesame ice cream with hot sauce (additional fee for dessert).

Ambiance wise, Kusakabe is much more casual, loud and impersonal than Omakase and Wako.  The kitchen is busy, busy, busy, and there is much more limited chef interaction at the bar as compared to Omakase and Wako, both of which are quiet, subdued, and intimate.  It really depends on what you prefer.  If you're on a casual friend's night out, go to Kusakabe so you can talk and laugh as loud as you like.  If you're in the mood for ambiance and peace, both Omakase (especially) and Wako should fit the bill.

Speaking of bills, they're all priced the same, but we felt that Omakase served larger pieces of fish.
author: Gina T.

description: My brother is a huge fan of Kusakabe, so I decided to come here for my birthday. You might not spot the sign until you are standing right ouside of the restaurant. I got the $95 omakase, deep sea uni and the creme brulee dessert. Each dish was served one after another, and our waitress talked a bit too fast for me to know what fish we were having at times. The fish all tasted great and fresh like expected from a Michelin restaurant. Let's just say.. there wasn't anything I didn't like or enjoy. I have been to higher end sushi restaurants in Tokyo before, and this place is definitely close to what I had experienced. The dessert was on the house because of my birthday. I'd return in the future for sure. Almost $300 for two people isn't bad and considering the quality of the food.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
The sushi is undoubtedly great. The quality of the fish is extremely fresh, the technique that goes into slicing, seasoning, and delicately balancing the flavors of the nigiri (because rice is important too!) is impressive. You don't *just* get kanpachi or sake, you get the kanpachi belly that's seared in house-made yuzu and torched by the chef. 

Do I think $95 is steep? Most definitely. This isn't the kind of place where you go in and out for good sushi, you definitely go to experience the atmosphere and sample the skills of the sushi chefs. For those who are curious, Mitsunori Kusakabe, the owner, is the only one who slices the sashimi, an important distinction since the way the fish is cut can really make or break the sushi!

I could go on and on about the freshness of the fish, and the never-before-tasted flavor profiles of the omakase, but I'll just let my pictures speak for themselves.

tl;dr - delicious, worth a try, great for a splurge, fish is fresh! We were not hungry but if you do feel like adding to the omakase, the menu has some interesting offerings that you may not find in run of the mill sushi bars.
author: Kate M.

description:
After hearing my friends rave about this place, I finally had the chance to experience it for myself. This was one of the best omakase I've ever had (and at such a reasonable price, too!).

Chef Ngai was so friendly and skillful. He was happy to explain where the fish came from, how the taste and texture could differ based on location, and gave us some great recommendations for a la carte dishes at the end. My friend got the Hokkaido uni and seasonal white cod "male caviar," which was a hilarious topic of conversation. I was very impressed by every single dish, and I think that Kusakabe has the best sushi rice in SF.

Incredibly fresh sushi and playful banter made for a fantastic dinner after a long day at work. We'll definitely be back for more!
author: Kelly L.

description:
I was really excited to try Kusakabe based on all the stellar yelp reviews and it did not live up to the hype. To be fair, I had just returned from Tokyo and after eating live sashimi from tsukiji fish market, my expectations were a bit high. However, I still feel that Kusakabe does not compare to many of the bay area sushi places... much less the michelin star rated places that I've been to. 

I did not feel that any of the dishes were particularly innovative. The worst part was the texture of the sashimi dishes. The tuna's texture was chewy and unpleasant... Furthermore, it was very bland. I did enjoy the selection of sake but then again, it's hard to mess that up. 

Overall, I think Kusakabe deserves 3.5 stars for the impeccable service and atmosphere. Personally, I wouldn't spend ~$150 per person to eat here again.
author: Xinxin W.

description: There is an unhappy combination here: very small portions at very high prices. I left with a bill of over $300 for relatively little. This included only the lesser ($98) of omakase menus for the two of us plus three sakis, a beer, and tip. The selections were fresh enough, properly marinated and well enough presented, but when you come right down to it, not all that special or unusual.I have dined in Japan and this was fairly standard fare, but would have been overpriced even in Tokyo. They seem to get away with it though; a lot of young and inexperienced folk willing to toss around their money.
author: Francis S.

description:
Great all-around experience! While it's definitely pricy, the quality of sushi you get is totally worth the money! The nigiri was the best I've ever had (although I'll confess I'm no sushi expert), and I like that the kaiseki style incorporated other non-sushi dishes for a well-rounded meal. However, my bf and I both agreed that the weakest course was the soup course. 

The staff was also very attentive, and described all the ingredients in the dishes placed before us. The omakase menu + dessert took about 2 hours in total, and we never had to wait long in between courses. Furthermore, it was great to be able to sit at the bar and watch the chefs prepare all of the dishes. Will be back again!

PS: My bf wrote a Medium post if you're interested in seeing the menu we had course-by-course: https://medium.com/@kzmeyao/kusakabe-san-francisco-f06ca18630a7
author: Audrey G.

description:
Such a lovely experience with divine omakase! We were lucky enough to be seated at the bar and were able to watch them make our food. The staff was attentive and very friendly. 

We went with the Grand Omakase, $165 per person. Hubby had the sake pairing, while I opted out of the wine pairing. Maybe next time! We also ordered sushi ala carte - zuke chutoro, uni, and wagyu. All the fishes were "melt in your mouth" like butta!!! Make sure to reserve in advance.
author: Vangie D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place and rate it four stars, but simply couldn't. I feel like I have eaten at many good sushi restaurants across both sides of the country, but this place was an experience in itself. I got to sit at the bar and observe the sushi chefs, who no doubt were quite skilled.  The service was good overall, but the reason behind 3 stars was the fact that there were too many hit and misses. 

Some of the pieces of fish I ate like the zuke, was simply fantastic. However, right afterwards, the halibut I had, that supposedly came in live that morning, was overpowered by the lime zest and citrus juice sauce that they use, where the fish wasn't even tasted. All I could taste was an overpowered citrus taste.  I'd have to say this repeated itself over and over again throughout the omakase meal. 

My part also ordered a large amount of Ala carte items after the tasting menu. This was probably the best part of the meal. The buri, a wild Japanese yellowtail was the best piece of sushi all night. The wagyu while delicious, had the same problem as other food items where the citrus was slightly overpowering the delicate taste of the meat. It was better balanced than some of the other items, but when I have such good ingredients, I want to taste the ingredients more so than a house made citrus sauce. 

Overall, I would recommend coming here once to try, but wouldn't come back.
author: Kyung R.

description:
The problem was the service. Res requires a deposit of $100 for a party of 2 on a weeknight. So they have you over a barrel when you show up and they still make you wait in a long line. Normally I would just leave if some place wasn't ready for my reservation and made me wait for more than ten minutes...in...yes a line. I think we waited for almost 30 minutes.

Disrespectful. Cheap. That is my impression.

There were a lot of other problems. Maybe it was just a bad night for them, who knows.

The Sushi was good. Would put it in top 100 in California, but not top 20.
author: E C.

description:
Oh the hype is real.

I was afraid coming here that it might be over hyped but Kusakabe definitely lived up to its reputation. 

The fish here is obviously superior in quality. The presentation is spectacular. The atmosphere is very trendy, open, and modern. I want to say this place has a more modern approach serving the fish than other omakase places. I loved how creative the dishes were and how intricate each plate was perfectly presented. It did not disappoint. 

If you're looking to have a great omakase experience without breaking the bank too much then Kusakabe is the place to go! Make sure you make reservations :)
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I requested anything special possible for my SO's birthday, like a little card or cake; anything that could surprise him during our experience here. The server kindly said "happy birthday" as we arrived and gave us a dessert on the house with a cute candle on the side of the dish as decoration. Although there were some difficulties prior, such as an employee calling me rather confusedly not knowing what to do even though I clearly stated in the notes on my online reservation on the lines of "anything birthday related is great, if not, that is absolutely okay too", they still went through with making our time special in the end. We chose the petite omakase; I thought it wouldn't be enough, but I was VERY full and satisfied at the end of the course. There is a wide variety of seasonal fish served as nigiri (3-4 courses), one course of sashimi (I've never tasted tuna like this before-- barely fishy, so tender) and a couple of other eccentric, almost experimental looking dishes because of the choice of plates/dishes/cups and interesting concoctions of food. Service was fast and everything was handled professionally. The first nigiri served to us blew our minds away with the seared nigiri (I forgot the fish but it was so good); it was clear that they planned out the order of the courses to leave us constantly amazed. 

Of course, I don't understand the point of reading reviews for high-end or reservation-only restaurants. The experience is entirely up to you and your previous similar experiences. Many negative reviews I see on here are because of people being overly critical of the choice of the chef (again, all about the experience... the chef's choice of serving is theirs, not ours) or purely because they do not respect the orderly fashion of omakase and complain about the staff showing any kind of opposition. If you want a good omakase experience, here is a great place to try.
author: Christy N.

description:
I really want to tell you not to go here, so those that know it can keep it to ourselves.  I'd hate to see this little place become overrun & impossible to get into.   This place is a great experience.  It is small, only seating a maximum of about 40.  And they only have a 5:15 & 8:30 seating.  

Perfect date spot.  Sit at the sushi bar and watch your chef masterfully prepare every bite for you.  We had one chef for 4 people at the bar and they all help prepare the food for the 4 tables in between the bar courses.  The chefs are very attentive and sociable.  They will answer questions and are very informative.    

We ordered the Omasake.  For us it was the perfect amount of food.  Every course was a work of art.  I tried new things and found a new take on old standards.  I didn't fall in love with everything but I didn't hate anything.  I'm glad I tried it all.  Our favorite was the Cherry Salmon.  The texture was perfect and the cherry leaf gave it a taste of cinnamon.  It was almost dessert-like.  

Between this and the sea lions at pier 39 I have plenty of reasons to return to San Fran as soon as possible!
author: John G.

description: Food prepared by owner chef Kusakabe is the best. Fish melt in your mouth like butter and the food are very fresh.   We enjoyed eating here like you are transported in Japan.
author: Alfredo T.

description:
Last night I went to sushi heaven!!! "Zuke" is to die for!

Atmosphere: 5/5 Kusakabe is a bit misleading from the outside. You walk through curtains to get to the door. As you enter the small restaurant you get a very personal feeling. Everything is very modern and the decor is sleek and clean. 

Service: 5/5 We were lucky enough to get a place at the sushi bar (definitely the place to be!) and were never unnoticed. Water, champagne, and sake were refilled almost magically, as I rarely noticed our server filling our glasses! What I loved, was how friendly and attentive everyone in the staff was! 

Food: 6/5 Fresh. Delicious. Melt in Your Mouth. Sushi Perfection! Toro and Wagyu are must haves! Those are the first thoughts that come to mind! The amount of detail that our chef, Ken, put into every single dish was astounding! After we finished the omakase menu, we ordered several pieces a la carte and Ken personalized each one to our tastes. Ken is not just a sushi chef, he is an artist and makes every dish into a flavorful masterpiece! 

Overall:5/5 With a Michelin star, Kusakabe is not cheap, but it is by far the best sushi I've ever had and worth every single penny!
author: Korinna C.

description:
Really really good sushi. My SO and I were joking about how this may have ruined sushi from other places for us. Each dish and each piece of nigiri was deftly created and well thought out. Unlike most places, the sushi is served with the sauce brushed on, and each bite delivers a satisfying balance of flavors that brings out the natural taste of the fish. My favorite was probably the bonito, which had this nice smoky taste and a little bit of heat from the wasabi.

The attention to detail really is extraordinary. We were watching the chefs prepare the chi ayu (basically long thin fish) for frying and they were dusting every fin and tail and then painting their bodies with flour in preparation for frying. Speaking of which, the chi ayu was served with a charcoal miso sauce and peppers which was really tasty; it had a nice earthy quality to it. 

Service was attentive and though dinner was long I never felt bored because it was a joy to watch the staff at work. Overall I great dining experience.
author: Becky L.

description:
HORRIBLE HORRRRIBLE service!!!! When my dad pulled in his chair to sit down, there was a NEEDLE / nail stuck on the chair that punctured a hole on his thumb! His thumb was bleeding and everything. The manager apologized for maybe 1 second and left. And the waitresses simply did not give a crap. They didn't even switch out the chair! For the rest of the evening, the waitress was just very rude. They barely explained what each food item in front of us was and didn't even offer any dessert at the end. Just.... unacceptable.

1 star for the kobe beef nigiri + 1 star for the toro nigiri (chose both for the "finale" course). Overall, the food was just ok. Nothing spectacular. Many pieces were very bland. Expensive and not filling.
author: Betty T.

description: Delicious and good place for dating. I tried it out on Chinese Valentine's Day with my boyfriend. Food looks pretty attractive. I am a person not that into raw fish. My boyfriend likes it a lot!
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Kusakabe has good value for their omakase. The crowd was pretty casual, not fancy at all. Unfortunately we didn't get the chef himself. 

I thought the food was good, but sort of unmemorable. Didn't really leave an impression, but I am a tough critic when it comes to sushi. I will say that sushi ran is not the same caliber without kusakabe.

Would come again if in the mood for a real omakase. The truffle miso is a bowl of savory goodness. Best way to end a meal.
author: Stine H.

description:
Our monthly girls night out took on an entire new level of amazing when we found ourselves here. I am sure this place does not require any reviews because the food, service and alcohol list all speak for themselves but I would be remiss if I didn't scream it from the roof top! 

The sushi was amazing. Sitting at the counter bar made for an even better experience. Our Sushi chef was great. He was so funny and it added to our experience. 

We did the Grand Omakase without the wine/sake pairing. While this isn't an everyday experience, it is absolutely worth a try.
author: Debbie B.

description: Loved the sushi! Very fresh and traditional. The uni was melting in the mouth. They have a great wine and sake list. Great atmosphere and the chef who took care of us,  was very friendly and he  explained every course carefully. Great service. Highly recommend.
author: sladana v.

description:
I've been back quite a few times since the first review, and I think it's gotten better in the last year as they re-structured and changed up the menu. 

We started with a sake flight - three 4 oz pours that were all quite different ($50.) We ended up getting two more 8 oz sakes, and in the end, the sake and food cost about the same. Sake definitely complements the sushi, though.  I love their glassware (design, thinness). Sadly, it's pretty much all from a special source in Japan and is not easy to get

We did the grand tasting ($150/person) and some add ons.
1. Dashi to start: served warm in a small cup

2. Sushi: I love their rice, and I liked each piece of the sushi to the point that there was no clear cut favorite
  - Seared chutoro: nice and fatty, cured with soy sauce, love the sear 
  - Hirame: wild halibut with halibut liver and shiso leaf
  - Katsuo: smoked in cherry wood, topped with garlic, chives, radish, and it tasted almost like bbq  
  - Hotate: super sweet and tender, topped with uni 
  - Baby snapper topped with crystallized egg yolk 

3. Sashimi: the maguro and barracuda were meant to be dipped with either house grated onion with yuzu, chive, and salt or traditional soy sauce + wasabi
  - Thinly sliced salmon wrapped around cucumber with a bamboo charcoal miso: the miso was very unique 
  - Red snapper: wrapped with ankimo, topped with Italian summer truffle and sitting on a ponzu truffle gelee.  I couldn't taste the truffle much, but the gelee was good 
  - Kamazu: barracuda with micro onion
  - Maguro

4. Hassun: this was a beautifully arranged platter with lots of flavors and textures
  - Oyster with caviar
  - Tempura crab: coated in rice crackers
  - Shrimp cake with sweet corn: best eaten warm; good with dipping salt 
  - Nasu agedashi: served in a little glass bowl with kani and ikura; this dish is very light
  - Squid: very thinly sliced, with baby kiwi, toasted pine nuts, and wakame. The wakame was my favorite part of the dish
  - Box sushi: tuna topped with bonito flakes
  - Box sushi: tamago with a layer of crab underneath, topped with a goji berry 
  - Fried fish with red onion and a vinegar dashi

5. Soup: Puree of cauliflower, which was very rich tasting. It came with a sweet potato paste in the center for more sweetness and thickness, abalone, trumpet mushrooms, abalone mushrooms

6. Sushi Chic and Sushi Finale 
  - Shima aji: topped with daikon and yuzu
  - Arctic char: with sea salt and yuzu 
  - Sanma: with grated ginger lime zest, and chives
  - Uni, but I opted for non uni, and it was a torched oily snapper cured in kombu, which was really good 
  - Shirayaki: BBQ white eel, finished with a light drizzle of sauce and sansho pepper. I like that the sauce doesn't obscure the fish
  - Wagyu (you could also choose toro): A5, super smooth and buttery

Extras: prices range from $6-15 per piece (tamago vs uni)
  - Jin kinmedai: golden eye snapper smoked in cherry wood
  - Kisu: whiting cured with bonito and konbu

We were too full for dessert by the end.  It ends up being a lot of food.  My only complaint is that there's only one bathroom, so there can sometimes be a wait. 

Service is always impeccable, and Chef Ngai did a great job of educating us on the dishes. Definitely get a seat at the sushi bar. I've done a table once, and it was NOT the same.  I think it's a party of 3 or so max for the sushi bar; otherwise, you get seated at the table.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Took my girlfriend here for our 1 year anniversary this past weekend. I had previously only heard about the restaurant by name, so I didn't have many expectations prior to our visit. I booked our reservation months in advance (it's near impossible to get a reservation on a weekend without booking weeks/months in advance). A few days prior to our dinner reservation, the hostess gave me a call to confirm. She asked if there were any special occasions that we were celebrating; I told her it was our anniversary.

We were warmly greeted and seated in front of our dedicated sushi chef right next to the head chef. My girlfriend and I decided to go with the $150/per person Grand Omakase, which was a 25 item dinner. The sushi was some of the best I've ever had and the experience was very intimate -- our sushi chef making conversation throughout our meal and explained each course as he made it right in front of us. Service from the staff was excellent throughout our entire dinner. 

After our dinner, my girlfriend and I ordered one of the desserts. When they brought it over, they lit a candle, congratulated us on our anniversary, and said that the dessert was on them. I thought this was a really nice gesture.

The bill ended up being ~$400 for 2 people. Expensive, but if you're willing to spend a little money to treat someone out for a special occasion, I'd highly recommend this spot.
author: Steven O.

description:
As good as it gets when you want a true kaiseki (omakase) dinner. I was lucky enough to be brought here for my birthday dinner by my lovely girlfriend. Everything from the traditional "Welcome" that the staff uses when you enter to the fantastic desserts that end the meal, Kusakabe defines what it means to have a truly incredible dining experience.

Food speaks for itself, many of the items on the pre set menu is determined by the Chef so it differs according to who you have and what is in season. The only thing that matters, is that it tastes wonderful. One quick note, the Chef will ask you if you have any preferences or dietary restrictions at the beginning of your meal and will cater around it which is a nice plus. Luckily for me, I was a free canvas to eat whatever they put in front of me.

Service is what really shines here. From the super polite Manager, to our incredibly nice Server (I wish I got your name), and of course our personal Chef, Chef Matthew, all our interactions were on point. Everyone made it very clear that they wanted to give us a terrific experience. 

Special shout out to Chef Jin for explaining some of the special details surrounding Japanese cuisine and the tools they use and, of course, Chef Matthew for truly making our time the best. Creme Brulee is bomb.
author: Edmond H.

description:
I believe there penalty on not show up is too unreasonable.

So I had a business trip last minute (24 hours before the reservation) and there cancellation policy require 48 hours in advance. I booked for a party of 6 for my guests. Yes I know its a lost to a restaurant but charging $570 for not show up is too much. And its really hard to contact the restaurant. I booked through Reserve and I cant contact them. And I also cant contact the restaurant. 

Not a happy experience.
author: Logan T.

description: Kusakabe sweep us off our feet. It is hands down one of the best omakase experiences ever! Reservations are required and fill up quickly. Ambiance is great. Bar seats are the best seats in the house because you get to interact with your sushi chef and watch them make each piece. Our chef was super tentative and friendly. Each piece was perfectly executed and A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. I highly recommend this place if you love sashimi (raw fish). Overall, this place will blow your mind and is worth every penny!  I will definitely be back!
author: Lynn T.

description:
Absolutely amazing dining experience. Everything about this place is awesome. I love the exclusivity of only two seating times (5:30 or 8). I also loved having the sushi chef right in front of us telling us about the fish, etc. Try and get Ken, he is awesome, kept us laughing all night!

The food is just spectacular. We did the standard Omakase and it was definitely enough food. The meal takes a while so you're stomach has time to fill up. The waitresses are also very knowledgable about sake and let us try a few before deciding which one to get.

Although it is an expensive dinner, it's definitely worth it! Again, all around amazing dining experience.
author: Julia M.

description:
I feel like places like this are wasted on me, since my idea of quality sushi is a Lion King roll. Some foodie out there probably cried while reading that last sentence.

All joking aside, hats off to Kusakabe. They seamlessly blended cordial service with excellent sushi (from Tsukiji Market!) and fully deserve their Michelin star. Regarding the actual food: I enjoyed sushi that was seared with the blowtorch most. I had to get the zuke twice from the "a la carte" menu because I loved it so much from the tasting menu.

When making a reservation (that's several weeks out), make sure to specify a seat at the sushi bar. Watching and chatting with the chefs is pretty dang cool.
author: Aileen L.

description: I was super excited to try this place, plus its a "Michelin Star" restaurant. My favorite type of food is Japanese but I was not impressed with Kusakabe. You have no idea how excited I was to try this place, especially it was OMAKASE and having me giving it a 3 star, it hurts. Everything was good but it wasn't great. No wow factor. My first piece was the blue fin fatty tuna, lightly seared. That was pretty good but that was the best piece all night. Everything else that came after was not as good. Maybe that is why I was disappointed. It's not like I didn't enjoy my meal but I wish it was better. Maybe because the owner/head chef wasn't there? I'm not sure but I don't think I will be coming back.
author: Sandy B.

description: I think I've gone full circle and think Kuskabe is one of the top 2-3 sushi joints in the city.  Don't think I appreciated the attention to detail in the chef's preparation until I've tried other sushi joints.  Also have learned to appreciate more of the Kaiseki style preparation at this restaurant.  Excellent food at a "relatively" reasonable price.
author: Joe P.

description: One of the best I've had! Got seated right when they opened, service is fantastic, chefs are not intimidating, they are very friendly and approachable. My faves are otoro, bluefin, crab leg, and unagi. Everything was good. I'd definitely go back!
author: Gwen M.

description: Made reservation two months ago, finally tried out Kaiseki food in Bay Area. We selected Omakase Menu and enjoyed very much. However, I still like the one in Japan.
author: Shrabbit A.

description:
Parking wasn't too bad, excellent service, high quality sushi.
This is a kaiseki style meal ($95 pp) with option to add a la carte sushi at the end.  Everything I had here was very good and there were a few cuts of fish I've never had before.  Only complaint was that it wasn't super filling and if I hadn't added ankimo and toro at the end I probably would have been hungry again shortly after our dinner.
Try to get a seat at the sushi bar - watching the chef cut fish was mesmerizing.
author: Selina T.

description:
I was very fortunate enough to be served by Chef Nori when I paid a visit to Kusakabe. Chef Nori does not speak as much as his fellow chefs, but his cooking is an art. I enjoyed every moment of watching the omakase dishes being prepared!

My favorites from the night are listed below:
- Zuke Chutoro Nigiri
- A egg sponge cake with lobster paste (I think)
- Beef croquet in dashi sauce
- Uni Nigiri (perfect balance of rice and Uni)
- Wagyu Nigiri (lightly seared and drizzled with lemon to bring out the full flavor of this amazing cut of beef)
- Ankimo Nigiri

There were some interesting dishes such as a tuna bone marrow gelatin that I had never tried before.

In my visit, I learned that the menu doesn't change too often, but items do get substituted out based on what is fresh. Will definitely have to visit again in the future!
author: Jeff M.

description:
Ard $95/person
Preix Menu- 8 different dish (one peice of sushi each time and some small dishes)
Very good quality of fish
Very good experience 
We were so full after we finished all the dishes
Great place to celebrate Birthday 
They will give you a free bday cake
Must try once in a life time
author: Che K.

description: One of my favorite Japanese restaurants in SF Bay Area. You are required to select the Omakase option, in which you are presented with many kinds of sushi. My favorites are the toro (fatty tuna) and uni (sea urchin). Usually the omakase is enough to fill a person, but you may also order sushi a la carte afterwards. I've been there a few times, and the quality has been consistent. I was served by Kusakabe himself the first time I went. Kusakabe's staff are all extremely meticulous and professional. I can't wait to come here again!
author: Michelle C.

description:
This place is the bomb. Personally I think it is a top 3 sushi place in California and the best sushi in the Bay.

You have no choice but to sit back and relax and enjoy the Chef's Omakase menu (12 courses) which is priced at $95 a person. From the top of my head if I can remember:

-Welcome Tea
-Blue fin medium fatty tuna
-Two seasonal sushi of the day
-Sashimi served on shaved ice
-Snapper Soup
-Chef's petit plates
-Alaskan Halibut
-Three more seasonal sushi

And last but not least a pick between fatty tuna (toto) and A5 Wagyu. Get both if I were you at 12 dollars extra. Oh and also if you're feeling rather indulgent order more pieces that are not on the Omakase menu. FOR EXAMPLE THE UNAGI. Best unagi I have ever had hands down.

Over and Out.
author: Ray H.

description:
This place sits about 4.5 stars. This is kaiseki style sushi, So its has some cooked dishes as well as nigiri.  This place is was very good in both terms of its sushi and cooked food. The omakase contained
1.  Kelp tea
2. Zuke chu toro
3.  Hirame nigiri
4. Boniton nigiri
5.  Sashimi akami and hotate
6.  Soft shell turtle in riceball soup
7. Platter with raw baby sardine and daikon, deep fried sweet fish, chu toro pressed sushi,  shigoku topped with caviar
8. Lightly fried abalone with uni soba risotto
9. Stripe jack nigiri
10. Barracuda nigiri
11. king salmon nigiri 
12. Otoro nirigi

In addition to these I also ordered bufan and kaisui uni.  Though a bit pricey I highly recommended the try both because they are both awesome but do taste different.  Kaisui being more sweet and softer than bafun.  They deserve their michelin star.
author: Richard M.

description:
One of the best restaurants in Bay Area.  Well deserved of the Michelin star.  We came here for our anniversary and appreciated the little touches and thought put into the meal.  Also they comped us desert when they heard it was our anniversary.

Our interaction with our sushi chef was such a highlight.  He taught us a lot about each type of fish, was willing to answer questions we had, but also let us enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Dined here about 5 or so times and I never left disappointed. The only thing I dislike is how you can only call between 1 to 4pm to make a reservation and sometimes I call 10x in a row with no answer. I never get a call back either from the vm. 

Thank goodness the food is so good otherwise I would not go through great lengths to get in. Its also very close to my work and I can walk. The $150 Omakase selection is the way to go. It may fill up some people but I eat a lot and need to order extra a la carte items so that I dont need to grab a burger afterwards. 

The only thing that didnt impress me was the wagyu. It didnt melt in my mouth like Akiko's wagyu but this doesnt deserve a star deducted. Everything else was excellent and this place is one of my top 3 sushi joints!
author: Stephanie P.

description: Nori Kusakabe and Ken Ngai never disappoint. Unlike many places, they are almost always there, adding to their amazingly high consistency. Of Sushi Ran fame, the duo have been working together for almost 14 years. Their sushi/sashimi dominated Kaiseki menu is a delight. Imo, they started the limited seat omakase trend that has become so common in SF last few years. They won me over the first week they opened and its hard going anywhere else.
author: Young J.

description:
Amazing omakase experience. 

Not only Chef Kusakabe but every chef is attentive to the every piece of your meal and will thoroughly explain the piece (how it's made, where it's from, the flavor profile, etc.).  You have the option of choosing $150 Grand Omakase and $95 Omakase.  You are not missing out by ordering the $95 but $150 menu does give you more nigiri and sashimi.  If you decide to go with a $95 Omakase, spend the extra $12.50 and make sure to add on a Wagyu at the end after your Toro.  Actually, even if you order the $150 Grand Omakase, just order the Wagyu piece also.  Toro is amazing.  It's probably going to be in your top 10 toro, no doubt about it and Wagyu with a sprinkle of sea salt and cracked pepper taste exactly like you would imagine but it's worth trying it.  If I had to choose between Toro and Wagyu, I'll choose Toro but for an extra $12.50, I would always get both every time.  

Service is great as expected from a Michelin star restaurant. 

Easy to find parking on Washington or Jackson.  

Would definitely come back again.  Prefer over Wako and Omakase.
author: Inseong J.

description:
Around this time last year I booked (far in advance) via OpenTable seating for 2 at the bar for my boyfriend's birthday. Being an avid sushi lover, I knew he would be thrilled to be treated to one of the town's boasted Michelin star Japanese restaurant. Not only did I note on the reservation, but also called & left a voicemail to confirm that this was a birthday celebration. Sadly, there was no mention or even the slightest acknowledgement of my requests. Call me naive, but I was hoping/ expecting better service at a Michelin star restaurant- $400 meal.
 
Any ways, whomp whomp- at $95 per person, you'll get an omakase (set prix fix menu). No doubt, it's some of the freshest sushi I've had in SF. However, there were also items I didn't thoroughly enjoy, such as the kelp tea (known to help cleanse palate- left a weird after taste) and the soup (which I found rather on the saltier end). 
As for the grand finale of the omakase, I'd highly recommend the A5 wagyu beef nigiri, from the texture to taste, it was utterly orgasmic (this means a lot coming from a person who doesn't even like beef).
For the uni lovers, one MUST try the Kaisui uni (14.50 a piece- hokkaido sea urchin) and Bafun Uni (13 a piece, Hokkaido short spine sea urchin). I can honestly say that each bite was simply heavenly & worth every darn dollar. Hands down the best uni I've had in my life thus far. 

Verdict: avid sushi lovers should come try out this place. it's by no means a place to regularly frequent for date night, but it's totally worth a try. (Just make sure you're not coming to celebrate a birthday. HAHA- guess I'm still not over the mishap a year later).
author: Ada C.

description: Go for the Grand Omakase as it has more and better pieces. You may want to add a few à la carte items; for instance, the best uni is not included in the oma. The food is quite good, but far below the stuff you'll get at the top sushi restaurants around the world - in terms of creativity (no 'wow' dish here!) or freshness. Pretty long sake list, although the waitress is not helpful in advising.
author: Lam N.

description:
Good, but not the best. I had the omakase here and thought everything tasted pretty good, but there was just something missing. I can't quite place my finger on it. You know when you know it's the best sushi ever? This place didn't hit it for my sushi snobbery.

And what the hell with that kelp tea/soup thing? That was just funnkkyyyy. Not exactly the way I wanted to start my meal, however maybe that's just a Japanese custom I'm not familiar with.

For there being so many great sushi places in the bay area, I wouldn't jump at coming back here right away.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
Most innovative Omakase that SF has to offer.

PROTIP:  
Don't forget to tack on extras that aren't included in the Omakase.  We tried pretty much everything but what left a mark in our memory was:
-  Bafun Uni
-  Lobster Tomago
author: David C.

description:
Wanted to try a one Michelin star restaurant, very  small place. They have two set menus, one for $95 and the other $150. The differences are more pieces and a few high quality fish.  Besides the sushi dishes, everything else was good.  I wouldn't say amazing. 

I'm super surprised that the menu didn't come with deserts, you have to buy it separately . 

Sake or wine paring also had two menu, $85 and something . 

I honestly think other non sushi places like sushi Sam offers the same or maybe better quality sushi.

3.5 stars
author: Nhung T.

description:
Finally I got a chance to try this place out.

Dined in with James M. (check out her ratings ya'll) on Thursday and we both got the $95 omakase, a few more from the a la carte menu and sake (Yuki no Bosha).
The meal was beautifully presented and it was delicious. Our favorite from the omakase menu are: toro, bonito, buri and Santa Barbara uni. Didn't realize how sweet Santa Barbara uni is, and the bonito, OMG, delicious. Bonito usually have  a fishy after taste, but this was an exception. The cauliflower soup was delicious; the mushroom and the abalone was so meaty, and all the flavors of the soup combined, it was amazing. And the oyster with caviar in the Hassun, flavor explosion. Delicate simple flavors brought everything together. The ankimo from the a la carte menu, delicious. 

Will definitely come back here again to try the grand omakase. I think getting the omakase then order more from the a la carte works better, since that's what we did. We were stuffed after the meal. Do not believe the reviews where they say it's okay sushi, or there's nothing special about it, try it yourself and judge. Because I think this is one of the decent sushi I've had in the Bay Area compared to sushi from the fish market in Japan.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
The Grand Omakase menu is a must do!

The star was the A5 Wagyu at the end - I could have ordered another 5 pieces a la cart but refrained
author: Bobby S.

description:
My boyfriend and I are sushi avids and were looking for a special date night restaurant at a nice sushi restaurant. A friend recommended this place and we decided to try to get a reservation through the Reserve app. 

We have had mind blowing sushi before, and I'd have to say that we sat at the bar and got the Grand Omakase, and nothing was mind blowing throughout the whole meal. In fact, the final pieces of fish- the chu toro and the wagyu beef- which I looked forward to the most, was the most disappointing. 

The chu toro was what you'd expect, but there was no special touch from the chef that brought out anything remarkable about it. 

The wagyu beef, I expected to melt in my mouth like a buttery fish. However, it was stringy and I ended up having to spit out a portion of it that was unchewable. My biggest culinary regrets was that wagyu beef.

This was extremely disappointing, as the bill ended up to be almost $500 for the two of us. This is the most we'd spent on a sushi omakase, and it was extraordinarily... unremarkable!

Perhaps it had to do with the fact that our personal sushi chef (he made sushi mainly for us, but also made some dishes for people at the tables) was extremely young and was making sushi only for a year or two. He did not seem to put a personal touch on anything and made the pieces as if following a cookbook. Reading some other reviews, it seems like Kusakabe simply lacks creativity in their work.
author: Valerie L.

description: I would rate this second best high end sushi establishment in the city. Great chefs and ambience.
author: Herb L.

description:
Chef Mitsunori Kusakabe has emitted his global culinary footprint at various Nobu establishments as well as his Michelin star restaurant, Sushi Ran. In 2014, he opened KUSAKABE, the brainchild of his life's work, which features sushi and other plates prepared in the "kaiseki" style. "Kaiseki" style is typically a multi-course meal that features "Five Colors, Five Tastes, Five Senses, Five Methods" - a little bit of everything, if you will. 

Omakase means that you'll leave it up to the chef to determine a series of plates for your meal. Our server happily obliged to accommodating any allergies or preferences.

Welcome Tea: Kelp Tea
The kelp tea tasted more like a palate opener broth than a tea.

Sushi Prelude: Zuke Toro, Halibut with Halibut Liver, Smoked Yellowtail with Daikon Radish
Each of these pieces of sushi were prepared with the utmost attention to detail and they were presented so beautifully! Be sure to sit at the bar to take in the full experience.

Chef's choice sashimi nestled in shaved ice with fresh Wasabi & Yuzu onion sauce: Tuna & Scallop
The presentation of this dish was very pleasant and unique. The yuzu onion sauce had a tangy, salty flavor that paired perfectly with the sashimi.

Miso Soup with Homemade Duck Meatballs:
Not my favorite dish of the meal, but definitely one of the best miso soups I've ever had.

Chef's Petite Plates:
The petite plates were served on a rectangular dish with separate compartments that tasted just as good as it looked. 

Egg Custard:
I loved the medley of mushrooms and thin slices of green onions in the egg custard here. The texture was great and the flavors were not too overwhelming salty.

We polished off the rest of the meal with a few other sushi pieces like the King Salmon and finally came to the pièce de résistance, a choice of either Toro (Bluefin fatty tuna) or Grade A5 Miyazaki Wagyu beef. I opted for the Toro, which did not disappoint. If you find yourself curious to try any other varieties of fish or the Wagyu beef, you can order it a la carte at the end of your meal.

I only have one recommendation for this place and that is: go! (And try to get a reservation at the sushi bar!)
author: Morgan W.

description:
WOW -- this place is amazing, and it might be my favorite sushi restaurant in all of California. 

Snagged a last minute reservation for 5pm, and ended up getting bar seating. I would HIGHLY recommend trying to get a spot there -- it's great entertainment watching the chefs carefully prepare sushi, and you get to eat the pieces one-by-one just like in Jiro. We got the grand omakase, which was well worth the upgrade, at $150 per person instead of the $95. All the fish were incredibly fresh, with fantastic pairings of roe, caviar, green onion, and other house made accoutrements (they even make their soy sauce in house!), and just the right amount of soy sauce and wasabe. The sake was also very nice, and the restaurant let us try a few samples before we decided on one. Some of the best service I've encountered here in SF! We had to run to catch a flight, so couldn't order more off the a la carte menu post omakase, which was disappointing given how much we enjoyed the dinner! 

Would definitely come back for a special occasion!
author: Christine H.

description:
Chef Nori Kusakabe created this new sushi restaurant, across the street form the Transamerica building, based on ancient Japanese dining traditions of "Goshoku, Gomi, Gokan, Gohou" one of the essential tenet in creating Kaiseki menu that is translated to "Five Colors, Five Tastes, Five Senses, Five Methods." 

This is a meld of European Fine dining meets Omakase Sushi from a skilled chef. They have recently received a Michelin Star for their efforts. 

It is essentially a fixed price, set Omakase (Chef's special choice) that everyone eats, in a multi-course fashion, for about $95/person. You can go a la carte and off the menu, but only after your Omakase fixed menu commitment. So it is a little bit Sushi Nazi, but in an elegant way. 

I came some time ago with a sophisticated international dining companion. I was ecstatic with the real Japanese traditions and quality, she enjoyed it, but thought it was a little too controlled theatrics. But that is the nature of Michelin starred, fixed priced Chef's menu dining in most cases anywhere.

Chef Kusakabe does all the knife cutting of fish. His 4 young assistants, 2 on either side, help prepare the other dishes in the Omakase. He personally presents and announces the dishes to you. Seating is limited to a long sushi bar. 

Don't ever come here looking for cheesy mayonnaise rolls and oyster shooters that you like at your local Korean/Chinese owned, Mexican made, "sushi" joint. It would be an insult to everyone here, and a total embarrassment to yourself. You might have to commit Harakiri.   

Highlights from our meal (see pics)

Welcoming Tea: Konbu cha -  kelp tea - very soothing

Sushi prelude -  Zuke Chutoro - lightly seared bluefin medium fatty tuna cured in a soy sauce, plus two other seasonal nigiri sushi

Sashimi - Chef's special sashimi nestled in shaved ice with fresh wasabi and Yuzu onion sauce

Soup - Italian black truffle miso soup with Eringi and Shimeju mushrooms
or...
Kamo-Dango, duck miso soup with Mitsuba leaf

Hassun - Shigoku oyster with French Daurenki Caviar and four kinds of Chef's assorted petite plates

Warm Dish - "Kinki" big hand snapper, "Mizoreni" (ice/sleet-like) with Matsutake mushroom

Sushi Chic - 3 kinds of seasonal sushi of the day

Sushi Finale - Toro - bluefin fatty tuna
or....
Grade A5 Miyazaki Wagyu beef

Honto ni oishikatta!

If you want a dining experience of high end elegance, combining thoughtful fresh ingredients with simplicity and harmony, in the Kaiseki tradition, come here.  

If you want a roll dripping with velveeta sauce, go to Safeway.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
We sat at the sushi bar and watched the highly skilled chefs prepare the food. What a treat it was to watch. The chefs were friendly and informative. Every seat in the house was occupied. Service was timely and polite. One of my guest dropped his chop sticks 4 times, no problem. The staff quickly and discreetly replaced them. The food was outrageously delicious and creative. Perhaps better then Maza in New York City. We ordered the $150.00 fixed menu. My guest and I were extremely full when we left. Alcohol was reasonable priced. 
Definitely looking forward to another meal here soon. Reservation are difficult to obtain, book in advance. 
My 2nd meals, 4 months later, was once again absolutely fabulous! We all ordered the $195.00 meal and again the chefs dazzled our eyes and impressed our palates.  Still Feeling pleasantly full  this morning but smiling about  the memory of this experience. Thank you Chefs.
author: J C.

description:
THE REAL DEAL!

Yup, this place is the real deal.  I got a seat right smack in the middle of the sushi bar and right in front of Chef Kusakabe himself.  Omakase is the only option ($95).  At the start of the meal you will get a menu for sake and drinks as well as the option for a sake pairing ($75).  The chef will also ask you if there is any foods that you are allergic to or don't like to eat (e.g. shellfish, etc.).  I like everything.  He also asked me what my favorite fish is and I told him "uni" although I don't know why he asked me that (uni was not served in the omakase to me).  He also asked what I wanted for my finale (toro or a5 wagyu beef - you can read my choice below).

The waitress will give you a hot towel to clean  your hands and a small finger towel to clean your fingers after each piece of sushi.

The omakase started with a small cup of kelp tea.  It was good and had a good taste of the sea in the tea.

We then had 3 pieces of sushi - Zuke chutoro was very good and smokey.  Perhaps a little strong to start the meal but it certainly hit you over the head with flavor.  He then served a hirame (halibut) which was very fresh and subtle and salmon.

Next up was the sashimi.  There were 2 pieces of scallop and 2 pieces of trout.  The trout had an almost salmon like consistency and slightly smokier taste.  The sashimi came in a small bowl on top of crushed ice.  There were also some small vegetables as well as a dipping sauce of soy sauce or grated onions w/ lemon.  The onions with lemon went well with the delicate flavor of the scallop.

The soup included a piece of cooked red snapper as well as some soba noodles.  It was hearty, warm, and comforting.

The petite plates included baby squid in soy based sauce, egg and shrimp wrap, oysters, small block of rice with negi-toro and caviar on top, and a fried ball of rice with seasoning.  The small block of rice with the caviar on top was the clear winner here.

For the warm dish, it included risotto with wild small mushrooms, monkfish, and ankimo (monkfish liver).  the ankimo was not prepared like little soft blocks but was instead seared similar to how one would prepare foie gras.  It had the texture and taste of foie gras as a result.  Very nice.

We then had 4 more pieces of sushi including kohada (nicely prepared and not as sour as most other places serve it) and some others.  For the finale, I had the A5 wagyu beef.  My logic was that toro is awesome but I eat a lot of toro.  I rarely eat A5 wagyu beef.  The wagyu beef is seared on one side and then flipped over so that the top is still raw.  It was full of marbling and flavor.

After this, you can choose from the a la carte menu.  I chose to add the kamasu (japanese barracuda) which was good.  I also got the shirayaki (white eel) which was cooked with the torch and tasted more subtle (in a good way) that most unagi sushi.  And I got the baby squid as a sushi.  This was the same baby squid that was served earlier but it was still excellent.  Most of the sushi on the a la carte menu ranges from around $8-$15.  The best item is probably the kaisui uni which is a hokkaido uni brought in from Japan.  The uni is caught in Japan and rather than take out the uni and put it into a wooden box, they put ocean water with the uni and transport it that way to the US.  I have had this before so I didn't order it but if you haven't tried it and you like uni, I recommend giving it a try.  It is served on a spoon with sushi rice and uni on top.

The dessert menu is separate and I ordered the yuzu sorbet.  The sorbet was an excellent palate cleanser for the night.  The sorbet broke apart easily which showed that it's freshly homemade.

My meal for 1 sitting at the bar with tip was around $150 (I didn't drink alcohol).

Speaking of palate cleansers, the ginger was also pretty good although the taste was a little more lemony than other restaurants.

Overall, I think this is the best sushi in the city.
author: Dan P.

description:
Two days later and I'm still thinking about the toro...

Had a great birthday meal here. The omakase offers a fresh, creative, and visually pleasing dining experience. Super satisfied with the quality of each bite and overall quantity. I didn't realize that everyone in your party had to order the same omakase. Naturally, I would have opted for the lesser of the two, but in retrospect, I'm glad I had the grander experience.

We sat at the bar and were treated to three hours of Chef Nori's masterful sushi skills. We were well taken care of - 5 stars for the stellar service! I enjoyed Chef Nori's explanation of each dish as well as learning about the fish's origin. 

If you appreciate high-quality sushi and sashimi, I highly recommend a visit to Kusakabe.
author: Brianna M.

description:
Yummy yummy in my tummy!

Came here with reservations for my birthday with my boyfriend. We got seated as soon as we got in. There's only 2 seating (5:15pm and an 8pm one) - we had the earlier seating. The hostess was super friendly and gave me great recommendations for the right sake to pair with my omakase. I had the Tedorigawa Kinka "Gold Blossom" - and I usually don't like alcohol, but it was very light and smelled sweet and INDEED went well with my meal. The omakase each night may change, but it is a set menu for everyone and you can order more nigiri at the end of your meal if you're still hungry. Everything was delicious and the executive chef was the one serving me the other night so yay! The setup is very traditional seating, but they also have tables if you wish to sit there - but I would recommend the more authentic route and getting to speak to your chef throughout dinner. We started with Chu Toro with the sides seared - yum!  Halibut with the mint leaf were an interesting combination, but super fresh fish throughout the night. My boyfriend's favorite was the Alaskan King Salmon - he says its the best salmon he's ever had haha - he ordered seconds after our omakase meal. I had another toro because it's my favorite! The Miyazaki Wagyu was also phenomenal - makes me miss Japan so much! The best part of the night was everyone singing happy birthday to me, and to my surprise - they all knew my name! Got my complimentary sorbet with a candle in it too! Bathroom smells good and is super clean too. Would love to return :)
author: Amanda C.

description: I ate at kusakabe a few months ago and I'm still dreaming of the sushi from there. This restaurant is definitely an experience, the food was exceptional. We sat at the counter top and had an amazing chef taking care of us, he was younger and had tattoos on his arms ( I cannot remember his name for the life of me). Everything was from the best quality, very good selection of beer and wine as well. I cannot wait to go back again!
author: Carlia R.

description: Ok, I went a 3rd time, and it dawned on me. These sushi chefs are not trained professionals. They just look the part. At this price point, I would expect some actual expertise.
author: Richard L.

description:
I had so much fun!

The whole experience is definitely worth it, when you get to sit at the bar/counter spots. Each piece was delicate, pretty, and of course delicious. I loved watching everything get prepared. I play off of people's energy, so our sushi chef Brian(?) really made the whole dining experience laid back and enjoyable. A fellow native SF foodie! 

Also we had shirako.. (we all loved it).
author: Donna H.

description: Being from Austin and spending a good amount of time in SE Asia has turned me into a bit of a snob when it comes to high end sushi restaurants. This was the first I've been to that had a Michelin star and I have to say I was underwhelmed. For $425 between 2 people I've certainly had better food. The food itself was quite good, service was fantastic, wine was also really good. Giving them 4/5 stars and not 5 because of the price vs quality. You can get as good of sushi in other places for $100-$200 less.
author: Mark H.

description:
It's been almost a year since I came here. But the sushi was phenomenal! Probably the best sushi I have had, so fresh so flavorful and the staff realllly knows their food. 
If you want to make an impression for a sushi lover In your life this is the place to go
author: Natasha I.

description:
This place is godlike. I can not describe it any other way. 
I came here with my girlfriend for our anniversary, with reservations of course. They cannot guarantee seating at the bar, but luckily we got it. We even sat next to the executive chef, who made most our food.
There's 2 options for the Omakase: a $95 option and a $150 option. The $150 option has a few more pieces and some rarer fish/meat. The $150 option comes with the grade A5 Wagyu beef, which is probably the best piece of meat I've ever eaten. 
Since everything is amazing and there are way too many pieces of sushi, I'll highlight the best ones.
There are about 22 items total in the $150 menu. 
-The lightly seared bluefin was amazing. Explosive start to the meal. Then it's 4 pieces of sushi followed by a small plate of sashimi. All sooo delicious.
-Then its a plate of assorted pieces such as an oyster with French Daurenki caviar, a Hako-Zushi and some delicately made finger foods. 
-Next dish is a Hamaguri soup with bamboo shoots and mushrooms. The soup was pretty good but there was some broken shell in the clam.
-The next 5 pieces are different types of sushi. Our chef asked us if we have any favorite fish. I said hamachi and my gf said salmon. So the chef made us exactly those and it was amazing. Then theres the Uni and the BBQ eel, which were both way better than I expected. The Uni was so fresh and the eel was cooked to perfection.
-The finale: The A5 grade wagyu beef and the bluefin fatty tuna. A perfect end to the best sushi restaurant I've ever had. 
I was really full after all this, but it was so good I wanted more. I cannot wait to come back here again. The price is quite expensive but it's definitely worth the experience.
author: Max T.

description: Wow.....Jiro experience locally here in SF! Ok, not like I've been to Jiro's, but I'd imagine this is how it will be! Serene, beautifully paired and exquisitely prepared food. Just a wonderful dining experience. I'll let the pictures to speak for itself.  And I also tried the Hokkaido deep sea uni, the intensely velvety flavor was...I died and went to heaven!
author: May W.

description: Wasn't impressed! The quality and service were good but portion size is too small for the price. The chef didn't seem nice and was very greedy. We walked out hungry after dropping $300 for 2 and had another dinner elsewhere! Now I know why this restaurant lost the Michelin star!
author: Ilya K.

description: Finally have time to sit down and write a proper review for this place. I've eaten here 3 times: 1st was for my friend birthday, 2nd is for my birthday, and 3rd is my gf birthday. Each and every time the food is different and none of which are disappointing. Sure service can be a bit better but you're really here for the food. Each and every course is fresh and pack full of flavors I wish I can describe all the courses that I've eaten every time I've venture here, but that wouldn't do the course or the experience any justice. Also this is a very late review and I don't want to repost the photos from before. I will be visiting again very soon and provide a more indept details of every course. Overall the experience is amazing and there's new courses every time I revisit.
author: Reeve N.

description:
We love the sashimi and the sushi here. We were told that this is a sister restaurant of Shiro's in Seattle. So if you're a fan of Shiro's, you can expect a meal of the same caliber, but slight tastier. 

The courses here are kaiseki style, which we took it to mean dishes prepped with a variety of cooking techniques. What this means for guests is that we can expect to have our minds BLOWN away by the unique combination of tastes and textures.

Get the omakase (last course is either the toro or the wagyu beef); don't fuss over which one to choose, you can always order a la carte after you're done with the omakase so I suggest you order the one you didn't order then.

Be sure to also get the dessert. The yuzu one is a refreshing way to end the night.
author: Lee T.

description:
Fantastic! Been there twice now and both times did not disappoint. They have two set menu's at $95 or $150. I usually wouldn't say good value to a $100/head meal but in this case, it's worth it. Realistically, you should expect to spend about $350/couple after tax and tip. I believe that's approximately what I spent both times, no drinks other than tea this most recent time. 

I recommend ordering the smaller set because after your set meal they will bring you an ala carte menu. 

I ordered the Hokkiado uni from the ala carte menu and it was better than uni I've had in Hokkiado. Cleary they do a very good job of sourcing product.
author: W C.

description:
This was my second time here. Everything was beautifully presented and delicious again. Service was a little, hmm, I'll say relaxed. It's nice not to feel hurried, but at the same time, sometimes you want to order a drink or add on. 

We had 8:15pm reservations, I believe there are two seatings each evening. We had to wait a little bit to be seated and since the restaurant is so small, we waited outside, there was another larger party waiting just inside the door and spilling out into the doorway. 

My friend and I aren't large eaters so the portions were perfect for us, but I've heard from larger eaters that the $95 omakase menu is not filling. At the end of the meal if you would like to order more, you can add more ala carte. Last time I went at the end of February and this time it was mid-May, the menus were definitely varied which goes right along with using seasonal ingredients, everything was super fresh and great quality. My favorite dish of the night was the Crispy Alaskan Kinki with Maitake Dashi Soup. Fish was crisp and tender, mushrooms were flavorful and broth was delicious. Will definitely be back!
author: Sarabeth L.

description:
If you are dining in front of Head chef, u will be lucky "Fish size & Quality were 1/5 star for the price w/michelin expectation! 1star for sushi rice, 1 star for: 3 items out of 7 courses in Omakase menu that cost$95! Wtf?  And the rest items on Omakase was very depressing! 3 ppl complained this is an imitation Michelin star restaurant. Especially A La carte: hokkaido Uni $11 per pc x2pcs was bitter & not fresh! Obviously, this restaurant's sushi vendor's quality was not there. Seems the head Chef lacks expectation with quality control behind the sushi bar & knowledge of "Michelin star's expectation".  

Ambience: sure, it's really nice but I'm paying for Michelin star price means the food that's goes in my mouth!!!! 

Like Tiffany D. Said, Michelin star means michelin price w/high expectations for High Level of taste buds!  

Sushi rice: red vinegar, quality rice, great mix of flavor 

Omakase: $95 
(Impressive items)
Bluefin chu-toro: A 
-smoked torched, not oily and tasty! 

Umami Tamoto Soup: A+ 
shiro dashi soup base: light, clean w/natural seafood taste w/tai, shrimp balls, nasu was point less, but they added sweet Chinese red sweet herbs which was well balanced. 

4 kinds of chef's assortment: C 
Only one item stands out: 
1. Crispy chip wrapped w/garlic soy chili     tuna, was very impressive! 
2. oyster:
   -not fresh 
3. some anago: 
   -topping didn't go well, no taste. 
4. crab claw: 
   -tasted like I'm eating at a Cantonese flavored restaurant. (What's your point?)

The rest courses was depressing: 
King Salmon: D
-was so thin like paper, couldn't even taste the quality 
Shima aji: B
-Nothing special
Tairagai: B 
-close to mirugai but similar like hotate w/miso sauce 
Katsuo Bonito: B
-Cold smoked w/momiji aroshi & chives 
Alive Hirame: A 
-Shiso leaf & fish liver mousse, the mousse pretty good. 
Lobster omelet w/organic egg: C
-didn't taste lobster or any organic egg. 

Sashimi: C 
Japan hotate & ocean trout was so small, didn't taste the Michelin star's expectations 

A5 Wagyu: F 
Yes, the quality was there, but it was super thinly sliced, raw with salt & pepper did not match to michelin star's level and the preparation & execution wasn't there. 

Crispy deep fried fish (Chi-Ayu) F 
After putting to my mouth, it taste bitter, the fish was bad already! Does the kitchen ever check their vendor's quality? 

Panna cotta w/plum Carmel sauce: C 
-quality of panna cotta was there but why they over squeezed the plum sauce which made point less of a Michelin star's expectation!
author: Le Chef

description: A place like this is sooooo hard to find in the U.S. Authentic Japanese sushi but also innovates on other dishes. Awesome omakase. Although it is quite pricy but definitely come here for a special occasion, you won't regret it! Everything was amazing, no complaints at all. Make sure you sit at the sushi bar. The experience is so much better in front of the chef versus at a table on the side (and the sushi is more fresh! Yes a few seconds makes a difference!)
author: Rohenne L.

description:
For now, in our "Michelin quest", Kusakabe is our best 1* michelin star experience so far. Wouldn't be surprised if it gets its second one in the next years.

We had the grand omakase menu at $150, with a $120 sake pairing. 
I definitely recommend to get at least one sake pairing for 2 if you don't know much about sake like us - it was great to try different types and to learn about the varieties. 

Each item of the menu was full of sophistication and delicacy. Presentation was flawless, service was solid. 
It was my wife birthday so they actually didn't charge us for the dessert - and the whole staff sang for her. As the atmosphere was pretty quiet/fancy that's was kind of weird, but in a good way. Nice touch.
author: Lionel F.

description:
Ok, I love this place...but I hate this place. Why do you hate it Aaron? I'll tell you why, imaginary person...it set the bar so high for me from a sushi standpoint that any other sushi spot I've been to, thus far, is now mediocre (at best).

Sadly I can't remember most of the nigiri I had. Mainly due to the fact that I slept on posting this review, and have therefore let too much time elapse since I was at Kusakabe to remember the names. BUT, I will say that there was this egg soup something or other that was divine. A clam nigiri that was CRAZY good. The first nigiri was also really good, maybe because it was just such a KAPOW to my taste buds. There are plenty pics with this post, so fear not, you can see the artistry that was so beautifully put together by Shinsuke. 

While I'm on the subject of Shin, this young man deserves a mention. He's very interactive and friendly and just an all-around cool guy behind bar. He took the dining experience to the next level. Why is this important? It's not just about the food, it's the overall dining experience that makes the visit GREAT. And I'm glad we had Shin serving us that night.

This place is dope and I'd definitely coming back.
author: Aaron C.

description: I was looking for try Kusakabe  for a long time, finally got chances to go, over all the food is okay too expensive , but the services was great !
author: Vicky K.

description:
This is a very special experience: kaiseki omakase sushi, prepared before your eyes, with a 'personal' chef for each group of up to four diners at the bar (there are a few tables, too). 

My own dining, seated at the bar, was exceptional: morsel after morsel, made from the freshest ingredients and with a satisfying variety of styles. 

It's easily worth $95 - go for it!
author: Alex V.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for our one year anniversary and it was such an mazing experience! Kinda felt like i was in japan. Kusakabe made me love uni! Everything was very fresh and melted in my mouth. Even the basic items, like the soup was delicious. The environment was so authentic. We had one chef prep all our food in front of us, I felt like a celebrity. lol 

The only downfall was that the food came out a little too slow for me personally. I understand that how authentic Japanese sushi is served, but I am a fatty ^_^
author: Chantel H.

description: Actually came here in June for my sister's birthday. We both got the $95/person and added two other nigiri. Overall, the omakase was very fresh and tasty but it didn't make me go "wow" nor did it melt in my mouth. The staffs and chef were very nice and attentive. Tea was always filled without asking which was a plus for me since I hate waving down staffs just to ask for more tea. This place deserve the Michelin Star that they were given but I was just disappointed since I had higher hope and expectation that it would make my taste bud go wow!
author: Wing C.

description:
So glad I found this place! My friend is really into sushi and I wanted to find a nice restaurant for his birthday since he's pretty picky. I made reservations online two weeks ahead of time - make sure you specify that you prefer bar seating. When we got there, we actually got seated right in front of the chef - although I didn't even realize it at first since I was too busy watching all the food. 

My favorite parts of the meal was the sushi prelude and the warm dish, which was a halibut. Looking back, I almost wished I told them I didn't eat shellfish either since my friend's substitutions looked better. The scallop in my sashimi was replaced with tuna and the fried crab leg in the small plate was replaced with wagyu. Overall, everything was still really tasty, except the kelp tea..

If you're deciding between the toro or wagyu at the end, definitely go with the toro! It was amazing. I ended up ordering the wagyu during a la carte, but it was not as impressive.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Best sushi I've had in my life... in the US.

I was too embarrassed to document the food here because I hate taking my phone out on dates. I came here not knowing what that this was a multi-course prix fixe menu (Kaiseki cuisine), so of course I was delighted. But everyone else has done a pretty good job of that. I'm just here to verify that this place was, in fact, awesome. I would come here again in a heart beat.

Make sure you don't eat right before you come because the amount of food you get will fill you up perfectly. No, it will not stuff you, but it will fill you up as you slowly let the rice and other food expand in your stomach. Don't be a lard. The a la carte menu is totally unnecessary. What IS a necessary addition, however, is sake! Because why the hell not? You're going to need help washing it down!

What else? It's an awful place for groups. Great for one on one dates. Keep that in mind. I plan on taking my old roommate here for his birthday. I hope he doesn't read this. 

Service is also great, blah blah blah. Last seating is at 8:30, so keep that in mind! And make a reservation!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Kusakabe must be on a bad streak. I had the Omakase and 4 other pieces from the A-La-Carte menu. The rice was overly vinegary the entire night and took away from the taste of the fish for me. A couple pieces of fish had the chewy sinew and it wasn't palatable. Ambiance is very casual and does not feel like a 1 Michelin dining experience. Your money is better spent elsewhere.

Winners: Zuke (so good I had a second) and Kan Buri

Chesnut ice cream for dessert was unexpectedly pleasant with their homemade cornflakes
author: Jessica P.

description: 5 star for service. We was seated in front of chef Ken, he was so amazing and willing to answer all of our questions. We actually gained knowledge after dining here. We got the Omakase, it was good, not super super tho', but the fish was all fresh and the rice was excellent. I love the Kinmedai, the Shiro Aji and the cup with a kind of clam, corn and soy cream (I forgot the name). I think their menu changes, so depends on your luck, or it's best you tell the chefs what's your favorite, you could get more surprising pieces and experience. We definitely will come back on special occasions :)
author: Grace N.

description:
